<question from>



xXx Crystaillee The Second xXx
Member since: 16 October 2008
Total points: 1065 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Do you think words like "smarticals", "funtastic", etc. Confuse our children?



My son - who is only two so I don't think he fully understand yet - is watching The Suite Life with his cousin. I was listening to something they're talking about - on t.v - and one of them keeps saying something about her smarticals - along with numerous words that are just a combination of other words.



Did you think this will confuse children at some point? I know they're more for humor than anything else, but aren't majority of these shows geared towards kids who are 10-14 (give or take).



Do you think the "teachings" of television and movie stars will eventually catch up to our children?



Thanks! Just trying to get a general opinion.



</question>



<answer from>



Crys L
Member since: 09 September 2008
Total points: 316 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Children learn from their surroundings. If they watch programs that continually misuse the language (I'm sure it happens in others, but it predominantly happens in English), then they will begin to use those words.



Biggest case in point:



Guesstimate - A combination of Guess and Estimate. These terms mean basically the same thing; there is no reason to combine them to create a new word.



Source(s):



Majored in Communications, with a minor in English



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks. OMG I hate the word "guesstimate". Thanks for the answer!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



frank...
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 2835 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i would say it would. have you ever heard a child that only watches the telle tubbies? i had a neighbor that sat her kid in front of that show for hrs. and he talked just like them. of course if they are older i wouldn't really see a problem with their language unless it becomes a constant thing.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emmy
Member since: 16 May 2008
Total points: 3351 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It was the children who those shows are aimed at who made up those words. Anyway the character in question was supposed to be sounding stupid, something most 10 year could probably figure out.



</answer>



<answer from>



Peregrin...
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



yup. not only TV but they might take words from other languages. Take fake leather for example. It has turned into faux leather. Faux is french for false. and this word has reached articles and even a press release of a car I saw once.



</answer>



<answer from>



FieryDra...
Member since: 15 July 2006
Total points: 4421 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah, absolutely. So, when the children are still in elementary schools. It'll absolutely be a good idea to keep them from learning these strange words until they are smart enough to learn right from wrong. Agree?



</answer>



<answer from>



sammi
Member since: 06 September 2006
Total points: 11221 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



no chill out



</answer>



<answer from>



GOING ON 3 IM BRILLIANT ME 7
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3456 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



i kept a tight reign on the tv before my kids were about 4. i agree with you completely. have you ever noticed parents who continually talk to their children in "baby" or whiny voices-the child is still doing it at 4-5 years?? i see it all the time.



they are too young i think to differentiate between a proper word and a slang word at this age. no big deal when they are older. it is even fun to make up silly words when they are about 5-6 and they understand that it isn't really a word, my kids & i used to do that.



i stuck with only things like sesame street, blues clues, dora etc. even spongebob was okay, because they talked in proper english. im not a prude or anything-i just have had the opportunity to see what it does.



i don't know about anyone else, but i don't want people looking at my child like they are uneducated-and really, that is what is makes them seem like if they aren't taught by us as parents to correct them if needed. nickelodeon is great, don't get me wrong, but there are age appropriate shows for pre-teens and young children both.



</answer>

<question>



What do 7 year olds act like (for my book)? ?



I am writing a book and the main character is about a 7 year old girl, but how do they act? what are their responsibilities? bedtime? anything would be great thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Peregrin...
Member since: 07 November 2007
Total points: 195 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



not as foolish as boys of the same age. most are good in studies, like to dance and some take interest in playing musical instruments. they like to try fancy costumes like feathered scarf, high heels, make-up etc. Some can be a bit bossy and want to be dominant in their friends group. responsibilities...  studies? they sleep during bedtime. soft toys in their bedrooms. themed bedroom in demand.



Source(s):



had a friend like that.



</answer>



<asker's comment>

</asker's comment>

Pregnancy & Parenting

<question from>



Patrick
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 92 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What are some fun activities for kids that are 1-10 years old to do in a birthday party?



10 easy points!?



Kids like to get involved in activities but many do not suit all age groups, what are some activities which kids from 1 up to 10 years old can all do together in a birthday party?



</question>



<answer from>



ati
Member since: 20 February 2008
Total points: 790 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



pass the parcel, everyone loves presents



</answer>



<answer from>



Carrie L
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 102 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The pinata seems to always work at b-day parties.
Also I'll have "door prizes". Years ago I went bought a roll of raffle tickets (the roll is so huge it will last till my grandchildren's parties) and every kid will get 1-3 tickets. I will then have goofy to good prizes to give away. The kids enjoy this because they can walk away with something too. Party stores, Clearance bins, and Dollar Stores are great for this. It's amazing how a child gets excited over a dollar toy.
I just finished a Hanna Montana themed party. All the girls dressed up and then voted who looked the best. Winner got to have the sparkly microphone and a Hanna Montana t-shirt (Walmart and Kohls has all this on Clearance) We also did Karaoke. That was tough, lol! I did a  party for my son, Favorite Super Hero!!
My trick is to start early and plan. The ideas tend to come to you. I've become known for my b-day parties. As the years have gone on I've had zero no-shows, because they're different from the others. Which is great because your child gets the toys, always good.



</answer>

<answer>



I guess it would all depend upon at what age they approached me with the information.  If they told me at the age of 6, I would discuss it with them but I wouldn't jump to any conclusions.  If they approached me at the age of 10 I would discuss it with them and really get down to the matter of what they truly mean.  If they were a teenager I would discuss it with them and then tell them my point of view.  But at any age I would always make it known that I love my child unconditionally.  Being gay doesn't banish them from the family.



I think that is such a travesty when a family rejects a family member because of their sexual orientation.

Mommy of a 2 year old daughter and a 7 month old son

<question from>

<question>



Advice on dealing with  a sulky child?



work as a groom for a family. Their daughter is aged 10 and throws big sulks and uses them to maniuplate people. What is the best way for me to react to her when she does this to me. (it hasn't happened yet but it's only a matter of time, she does it to everyone else and I am new in the job)



</question>



<answer from>



aiihunte...
Member since: 09 May 2008
Total points: 251 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Let her sulk, just don't give into the reason why she's sulking. She will eventually figure out that sulking won't get her what she wants.



</answer>



<answer from>



Schlopfa
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 116 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer from>



dunne980...

</answer from>



<answer>



Do not respond to her sulking or demands.Respond to her without letting her know you are annoyed at all.I found with my kids that what they really want is to know that no matter what,there are boundaries in place(this makes them feel safe) and that even if I don't approve of their behavior,I will always respect them as people.Not responding to her bad behavior,but responding to HER kindly will give her the clear message that she is a person worthy of respect,and SO ARE YOU! After a steady "diet" of this response from you,she will not pull this sort of thing with you anymore.So at least there will be one person in her life affecting her positively! P.S. Miss Prosthetic...I would respectfully suggest that ignoring the child will only make this problem worse.Ignoring the behavior,however is the way to go.So,you just carry on a normal conversation as though she is not sulking,and soon she'll stop.See the difference?



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 19 September 2008

<question>



How to raise confident, resilient and well behaved children?



I always wonder if I would be a different person, more confident and resilient had I been raised a little differently. Over fifty years of child development research shows we may be making a few minor parenting mistakes that could have major impact in how our kids turn out. Here I give 5 major parenting mistakes, their impact, and simple corrections to turn them right. Research shows that using these simples parenting techniques--the right way--can help our children become more resilient and confident, as well as better behaved.



I found out this article in the internet hope it is useful for every parent who reads this



http://www.clicka2z.com/How_to_raise_con...



</question>

nursings...
Member since: 17 January 2008
Total points: 181 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I



I would not try to define "spoiled"...it is too subjective a term. Parents should be looking at how they can socialise their children most appropriately...not trying to make a diagnosis which would only (ultimately)  be diagnosing their own parenting techniques so far...



Also, any diagnosis is  dependent upon the individual kids, and the behaviours exhibited. Every behaviour must be interpreted within the context of its society and family context.



My own personal belief (I am a single mother) is that I must be both kind and authouritarian, within strictly defined limits. I do not punish my child physically through hitting etc. and I do not believe that it is ever necessary...I have been been challenged by my child's behaviour in the past but all behaviours have been able to be resolved successfully without physical punishment. I do believe in consequences...when a child consistently has the (fair) consequences for bad behaviour enforced for them...they learn what society naturally teaches to them eventually...one way or another. Better that they learn it from their parent than from an external source.



Do not make excuses for your child, to make them feel good. If you do that it may make them feel good now...but terrible later, when society teaches them differently (through better or worse). Treat them fairly and consistently, the way that a good and just society would. That way they will learn fast.



I



</answer>



<answer from>



Jacob's Mommy
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 19784 (Level 6)



</answer from>

Mozz
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 9827 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, what's maternal?



I have that sixth sense that is such a mystery.  I know when someone is sick, hurt or in fear even if they're not around.  But I don't make Betty Crocker cookies in the kitchen wearing a dress, apron and high heals every day.



I let my kids watch TV, but I don't let them watch inappropriate shows.  I will usually succomb to chicken nuggets for supper if it's going to be a battle, but at least it's not poptarts.



I have woken up in the middle of the night, shoved Mr. Mozz out of the way because I "know" Gina's got a low blood sugar (I'm never wrong, and can't explain it).  Does that make me maternal?  Does the unexplained, out-of-no-where wild blood sugar reading somewhere else negate that?



I would rather jump in puddles with them than read them books.  But we read books.  Where does that put me?



I love to chat with my friends on Y/A, but my kids are fed, happy, homework is done, they're bathed and overall pretty content.  I would think that makes me a good mom, but someone else's definition might challenge that.



</answer>



<answer from>



Empathee...
Member since: 11 February 2008
Total points: 448 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What an interesting question.
My first is on her way, so i don't know if i'm maternal yet, i've been told i'm a natural with young kids, so i hope that translates to maternal. I'm sure you are maternal in your own way.



Come to think of it, my mother is a great mum and was very maternal towards me, but i highly doubt she gives off that kind of 'vibe' either.



Source(s):



30 weeks preggers

<answer>



I LOVE this question.



Funny story. When my youngest was 1 year old and my oldest was 5, we passed by a local park Haunted Trail a week before Halloween. My oldest was feeling so brave and BEGGED us to take her. Our youngest was falling asleep in the back. My husband had some ear phones and suggested he could just hold our 1 year old and if she got scared he would just leave. He put the ear phones in her ears and we stood in line. She yanked them out and just watched people for a while- then it was our turn.



Through all the screaming and the chainsaws etc, she slowly just drifted off to sleep. It was actually not that scary (it looked sort of silly- because it was for kids). I still can't believe she was drooling and snoring through the chainsaw noise. We couldn't stop laughing.



Oh yeah- we've never taken her back to any haunted houses, though!



</answer>

<answer>



We had a biggish party for his first birthday - i don't think i would bother doing this again for my second child but it was nice anyway and he is my first child so i'll let myself off :-)

Third birthday we just had a small gathering of friends and family, maybe about 5ish kids went!



4th birthday we had a big party at home with all his friends from playschool, maybe 15 children ish came!



For hs 5th birthday we are going to invite his school friends for a party at an indoor play area.



All have been low budget so far so i would class his 5th birthday as his first proper party because it's going to cost a lot of money and he will invite most of his class!

I’d prefer to arrange get-togethers at non-birthday times when there’s not the gift-giving expectation.  One exception might be a single birthday party that marks some major milestone of entering into young manhood or young womanhood like 13 or so.

<answer>

<question from>



rdtotten...
Member since: 21 September 2008
Total points: 1289 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Do you know what an ER is for? Do you use it the right way?



My 2 year old daughter has a severe life threatening condition (her pituitary gland does not work at all). She had to go to the ER tonight and people were complaining because she went ahead of their kid who has a cold.



So I would like to know:



1) How many parents out there know what an ER is for?
2) Do you use an ER for the right reasons?
3) How would you deal with some ignorant fool complaining about your child going before them?
4) When your child is really sick (like in danger of their life) how do you not knock some fool out for taking up the hospital and doctors time with something stupid?



OK, I know I am borderline ranting but I really want to know the supposed logic behind using emergency resources for simple things that should go to the doctor in the morning. Any help would be appreciated and I do rate best answers.



</question>



<additional details>



Sorry for complaining but this really bothered me. The ER was full of a lot of "blow off" cases the nurse said. And I'm not happy about the complaints.



</additional details>



<answer from>



msteache...
Member since: 11 August 2008
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



An Emergency Room is for emergencies.  Way too many people abuse our Emergency Rooms.  This is not a place to go to for a cold, but a place to go when you CANNOT wait until the next business day for a doctor's office to open.  I see it as abuse when people sleep late or let his or her child stay sick and then wait until midnight to take the child to the ER.  We even had to start rating patients (triage) since most people come into the ER for reasons that a family physician should be visited.



Your child with a life threatening disease should always be taken back first.  Do not let anyone make you feel bad.  You are using the resource in the right way.  HTH



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the support.



</asker's comment>

THEY ALSO DON'T CARE!

Best wishes to you and your family.
Good luck.

<answer from>



Jennifer L
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 13909 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, technically, hospitals would rather it be called ED (Emergency Department) because it is a department, more than a room.



1. An ER is for life threatening or otherwise serious accidents/injuries.



2. I am an nurse. I have called an ambulance for my child once, which was for respiratory distress.  Otherwise, I use urgent care clinics for the "urgent, but not emergent" things that I can't fix myself and can't get in to see our regular doctor.



3. If said ignorant fool is complaining to me I'll ask them if they'd like directions to the nearest urgent care clinic.  Otherwise, I'll ask them to look up the word "triage" in a dictionary.  If they got majorly in my face, I'd call hospital security.



4. After they look up "triage" in the dictionary, you borrow said dictionary and look up the word "assault".



As to why people use ER/ED as a doctor's office or an urgent care clinic, I think it comes down to convenience and insurance.  The ER can't turn anyone away, regardless of inabilityto pay.  I am hoping that the "Minute Clinics" and other easy-access, low cost clinics will help reduce the burden on the ER/ED staff.  I agree, it's completely out of control.



Source(s):



RN and a mom



</answer>



<answer from>



LC
Member since: 26 June 2008
Total points: 4992 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, I agree with you. I have taken my son to the ER once, when he probably didnt need to go, because he was crying incessantly, and I didnt know what was wrong. It turned out to be just a severe ear infection, but just in case I didnt want to wait 2 days(he was born with respiratory distress, and on oxygen). However, if someone who had a child who was seriously ill, I would graciously agree to wait. In fact, I would insist. I dont know why people are so rude, but I hope all is well with your daughter, and that people would understand that sometimes the world doesn't revolve around them.



</answer>



<answer from>



desmeran
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 3539 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



I've taken my kids to the ER for major asthma attacks where they couldn't breathe well enough to complete a sentence and needed to be put on oxygen, broken bones, and cuts that needed stitches.  Even in the first instance, I went prepared with books and toys for my daughter because scary as her condition was, I knew it was always possible that someone would be even more critical and we might have to wait (though in those cases, we never did, and got ushered ahead of the people who were waiting to be seen for other things).  For the breaks and stitches, I was prepared to camp out for hours -- and did.



But look, most parents are at the ER because their pediatrician suggested it or they are genuinely scared (rightly or wrongly) that there's something desperately wrong with their child.  And a few are there because they lack any health insurance and don't have any primary care doctor for their child.  I don't begrudge any of those people the right to be at the ER.  The ER staff is there to triage and make sure that people get seen in the right order.  (Usually.  A friend of mine went in complaining of desperately bad stomach pain and they told him it wasn't urgent so he needed to wait.  He went back and told them again, and they told him to sit down and be quiet and that he didn't understand the nature of triage.  On his way back to his seat they finally took notice of him when he suddenly passed out from his ruptured appendix.  Sometimes people who don't look like there's anything that wrong with them really do have something that wrong with them.....  It's possible that that kid with the cold at the ER came there after a febrile seizure or who knows what else.  I wouldn't be too quick to assume).



But it sounds like the comments might have seemed personal to you at the hospital.  And I can relate to being mad if someone's suggesting that your very sick daughter doesn't deserve immediate attention.  Hope she's doing better.



</answer>

<answer>



Id take a look at the praise she's getting.  Use wording like "you should be proud of yourself" versus "Im proud of you" this builds more of an inner confidence versus trying to please someone else.  Also make sure specific things are praised versus "good job"



Then look at what she enjoys doing, and go from their.  If its something like art, just sign up for a simple beading or project class at Michaels.  Or start of with an individual sport, like swimming, where you are trying to beat your own bests.



</answer>

<answer>



Girl scouts really is different now, than when I was growing up. I have 2 of my girls in it and they absolutely LOVE it! All the girls are very encouraging of one another and the skills they learn are fantastic! As far as the sports go, I really would just ask her if there is a sport she is interested in. Explain to her that it is about having FUN- find a recreational team, not a competitive one. My girls are in soccer and no, they don't always win but its not a big deal. Both teams celebrate eachother for just playing! They really don't even keep score. Even if she is a sore loser or very competitive, she will learn that its not the end of the world, the more she is exposed to it!

<question>



How can I be a good person in school, home and to other persons?



I can't be perfect right? Since I realized that I've done so many bad things like watching porn, chatting in chatrooms, back fighting my classmates, not following mom and dad , shouting my siblings.....etc.



I indulge myself in prayer and Bible Study. But still, i don't know how can i start changing to be a good person. How can I do that?



My main question is above,"How can i be a good person in school, home and to other persons?"



Please will you please help me.



</question>



<answer from>



dunne980...
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 321 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



This question just breaks my heart! You must be a good person already if you can even ask this,honey. The best thing I have found is to treat others exactly as you want them to treat you.In every situation that comes along,ask yourself how you would like to be talked to,responded to,helped out,encouraged or corrected.Then, respond that exact way to them. It's a balancing act to treat others well without letting yourself get stepped on, though.So try to treat yourself well,too!



</answer>

<answer from>

Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 13734 (Level 6)



Contributing In:

Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



There are all kinds of programs, but not specially made for single parents.  There are Food Stamps, welfare...shop for clothes at Goodwill, etc.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jacob's Mommy
Member since: 15 June 2006
Total points: 19794 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is WIC for food for kids under 5 and then there is food stamps or EBT cards. Check into Section 8 housing...although there may be a wait, and then there are day care vouchers you can get as well.



I believe WORKING parents, single or not, should get all the help they possibly can if they need it and those who choose to be lazy and not work should get nada. (this does not go for those actively trying to find work...just those who choose to sit on their butt all day and collect all the help under the sun)



</answer>



<answer from>



80sGoodG...
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 804 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Check with your local utilities companies:  Most have assistance programs for those struggling with their utilities.  Also, check with your local Department of Family and Children's services - food stamps could definitely put some relief on your budget.



Don't be embarrassed to ask for help.  It's not a 'handout' if you actually work (or have worked) and pay (paid) taxes that help support these programs.



</answer>



<answer from>



Esmereld...
Member since: 11 May 2007

<answer>



First off-remember that really well behaved,well-loved children lie.They usually all try it at one point.Probably spanking isn't the way to go,because the reason children lie in this situation is to avoid punishment-they are afraid.So,if you can teach them that they don't need to be afraid of you and their Dad,they will learn to trust you and come to you with bigger "wrongs" as they grow up.Try having them pay for what they broke,and to give them an example of the harm lies cause.Also-it's hard not to take lying as a personal reflection of your parenting skills.It hurts when they lie to you,until you remember that this is a "teachable moment",and it's how they turn out at the end that matters more than this one incident.What will they take away from this lesson?



</answer>

<answer from>



Kaliu3W
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 646 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



When I was a child, we (my six sisters and I) got spanked.  SOmetimes we got beaten, too.  It only encouraged us to become more crafty, (sneaky) and more creative with the lies.  It didn't teach us anything but fear and resentment.



When I was raising my children, I continued with spanking, but MY kids didn't give a darn if they got spanked.  They were determined to do what they wanted regardless of what I said.



Then I got smart.  I realized that if I were to continue with the spankings, and the yelling, my house would be just like the house I grew up in.  Everything always in chaos, somebody always crying, being afraid to come home from school....you get the picture.



So, I tried to 'let the punishment fit the crime'.  If they lied, then both kids lost privileges until the guilty one admitted. (no tattling was allowed).  Then I would sit down and with them and give them punishment options from a list.  They would choose their own punishment, (none of which were pleasant), that usually consisted of chores.



Of course, one time I got fed up and told my kids that we were going to go somewhere really special. I got them all excited and gave a time of the day we were going to do it.  WHen the time came, they were asking why we weren't leaving.... Then I said, "Oh, I'm sorry!  I Lied!"  They got the point.



</answer>



<answer from>



Keith
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 99 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



spanking time



</answer>

<question>



Just wanted some advice from strangers... (really really long)?



I know that Y!A is definitely not the best place to go for advice, but I would like to get a few opinions from outside, ininvolved parties on my situation--to broaden my perspective a bit. I'm 21 years old, almost 22, and 11w2d pregnant. I work full time at a great company, pay all my bills myself, and take care of what needs to be taken care of. I quit smoking and drinking as soon as I learned of the pregnancy, and mostly just go to work and come home to rest. My boyfriend is the opposite. He is not working. Hasn't worked much the whole 3 yrs we've been together. It never bothered me before, I don't mind being the breadwinner usually. But now he has a family to take care of. I can't make the money I am now on maternity leave, and I would like to be part time closer to the end of my pregnancy. He is trying, sort of half-assed to find work, but I guess it's better than nothing. We recently learned we have til the end of the month to find a new place to live (long story), and I'm not sure what to do here. I'm sick of being the only one doing anything--coming home from working a 10 hr day just to hear him complain about how bored he's been all day and then proceed to take my car to stay out with his friends until all hours of the night. But I also don't want to do this alone--I want to have a family. He can be really good to me at time, and he does my laundry, cleans the house, cooks me dinner, etc etc etc--he is sure to tell me I'm beautiful even when I know I look awful. Emotionally, he's a pretty decent boyfriend, mostly. But, also, as I said, he can be very selfish and tends to only want to do what makes him happy--if he wants to go out and get wasted with his buddies and leave me at home all alone, then he will. And he won't see any wrong in it. Anyway, my question is this: when we move out of our place, I have the option to go live with family, which, although is probably more stress than it's worth, is free rent to save money for the baby. But if I do that, my boyfriend isn't even allowed within 10 feet of my house (another long story), so if I choose that option I will be going through this pregnancy alone, and possibly raising my child without a father. And as I said, I want a family. I'm not prepared to do this on my own. So, which is the smarter choice--moving back home, living for free, leaving the boyfriend, and being all alone in an extremely stressful enviroment for my pregnancy OR paying higher rent to stay with the boyfriend and the hope of him someday making a contribution and growing up, all the while scraping money for food, barely getting by, home alone most nights while he's out with his friends?
I'm lost here. Both situations have such strong negatives and positives. If anyone read this whole thing, please let me know what you would do.
Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Stephanie C
Member since: 21 April 2008
Total points: 2730 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think you know in your heart what the better choice is. Get rid of the stress, go home, save your money, and set up a strong foundation for your baby.



I know you want a family, but there is no such thing as a 'perfect' or 'traditional' family. The best home environment you can give your babe is one of stability. You know he is not going to get his act together anytime soon. If he does decide to get himself together, get a place, and a steady job, let him do it on his own. In the meantime do what is best for yourself & the baby. Be selfish right now. You and your baby deserve the best. Good luck.



</answer>

<question from>



Mummy Moo
Member since: 20 April 2007
Total points: 842 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Do you parent differently in front of others?



We went to my mother in laws house at the weekend, and my husband commented on how quiet it was there and his mum asked why it was noisy at home.  He said that I am always singing, making stupid noises etc. with our daughter and it occured to me that I am different in the way I parent at home - we have songs for bathtime, for nappy time, for getting dressed etc. but I never do these in front of others - mainly because my singing is so bad!  Haha.  My husband is different too, in that if our daughter has a tantrum at home over nothing, he will leave her to it as long as she is in a safe place but in front of others he will pick her up and try and calm her down.  How about you, do you parent differently in front of others?



</question>



<answer from>



the capybara
Member since: 31 July 2008
Total points: 642 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



yes i do because i become conscious of how others are viewing me  unfortunately

<answer from>



mistydee...

<answer>



I live in a predominantly blue-collar community.  If my daughter misses the bus, I throw on a sweatshirt over my jammies, run my fingers thru my hair, and go!



Some other moms are all "done up" and yes, I've received some looks, but I don't care!!!  The funniest is at the beach (I live in a lake community), where some women feel a need to wear all their diamonds and gold.  I suppose they think they look rich, but I think they look ridiculous (who wears all their jewelry to the beach?).  After a day of painting or housecleaning, when I run to the milk store, I just pick up and run and I really don't care who I see!!



I grew up in a very wealthy community, where women had to wear their minks to go to the grocery store.  I found that to be so shallow, that I vowed to never be like that.  Having seen both sides of this coin, I choose to be who I am.  If people don't like it, it's their problem, not mine.  The women in this town have seen me both ways anyway.



Be who you are and to heck with everyone else!!



</answer>

<answer>



My kids each received a religious tract titled "The Halloween Rescue".  ::sigh::



It was about some poor kid named Adam, whose parents were too cheap to get him a REAL costume (so he had to cut up a sheet to make a ghost costume).  Adam wanted REAL candy for Halloween, instead of apples and such (which aren't safe anyway, right?).  The poor kid had to walk alone through a dark forest, and ended up getting stuck in some briers.  His lazy Dad sends out Adam's brother, Jesse, to find Adam, instead of going out himself, thereby managing to get two sons torn up by brambles (instead of just one).



In the end, poor Adam gets *nothing* for Halloween.  Not even apples.  The moral of the story: We must often travel through the dark and forbidding forest in search of the good stuff, but if we get stuck in a prickly spot we had better hope we have an older brother to get us out of it, or else we're totally screwed.  At least, I think that was the moral of the story.  I'm not quite sure.



Anyhoo, religious tracts don't taste nearly as good as candy.  (o_O)



Source(s):



Hopefully life will ease up a bit soon, and I will return to Y!A to plague everyone again.  For now, I'm off to try and eat a few more religious tracts.  ::lol::

<question>



What do I tell my daughter?



I recently got a DUI and was sentenced to 10 days in jail. I go in tomorrow and don't get until Sunday the 15. I am a single mother with a 6 year old daughter and I don't know where to tell her I am going. Any suggestion??
(I don't need to hear any lecturing about getting the DUI in the first place...I know I screwed up)



</question>



<answer from>



leila
Member since: 31 August 2008
Total points: 493 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Mommy made a mistake.  And I got a punishment, it's sort of like when you get a timeout.  I have to go have a timeout for 10 days and think about what I have done, so I don't do it again.



If she asks what you did you say. " I wasn't driving safely, and I could have hurt other people by not being safe"



But I will be back and I won't ever make this mistake again.



</answer>



<answer from>



dunne980...
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 327 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Tell her the truth-Mom did something wrong and has to have a time-out. She will understand this,and it leaves you with the ability to explain consequences to her. That's valuable!And you are right; you shouldn't listen to anyone lecturing you-we all do stupid things. Reassure her that you'll still love her when she does something wrong,and forgive yourself.too,okay? I always remind myself that "mistake" is a word that can really be interpreted "life lesson".



</answer>



<answer from>



Leigh
Member since: 12 August 2008
Total points: 608 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can tell her it's for your job, like a business trip. =)



</answer>



<answer from>



Jason H
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 179 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think that this may be a very good time to teach responsibility to her, and tell her the truth, but put it in terms that she can relate to.  You don't necessarily have to tell her what you did, but you can say that you did something wrong, and that you are getting punished for it.  Also, make sure she knows you are coming back and that you are not abandoning her, that it's only a temporary situation.  Remember, this could be traumatic for her as well.  Best of luck to you, I hope your 10 days goes by quickly and without incident, and that you never have to end up in this position again, but I think you should be honest with your daughter.



</answer>



<answer from>



keshequa...
Member since: 02 November 2007
Total points: 16473 (Level 6)



</answer from>

<question>



My son who is six has a bad cold any advice to speed up the process?



He is a little warm but bunged up, runny nose and tickly cough.



</question>



<answer from>



Sicilia
Member since: 04 February 2008
Total points: 6139 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



i have a bad a cold now too and i find i can't speed it up since there is no cure to the common cold.



</answer>



<answer from>



dunne980...
Member since: 18 October 2006
Total points: 329 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Vick's chest rub,lots of fluids to drink,and raise him up on pillows a little while he sleeps or lays down.Helps them to breathe easier.



</answer>



<answer from>



g s
Member since: 30 May 2007
Total points: 769 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The cold virus will run its course and can't be sped up.  Keep him comfortable, plenty of liquids, and children's acetaminophen



</answer>



<answer from>



ANF
Member since: 05 January 2007
Total points: 17672 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no cure, therefore no speed up process for the cold. Treat the symptoms for better comfort. Hot or very warm drinks no junk food as this ruins the system. Keep warm in a not too dry atmosphere.



</answer>



<answer from>



mi_rho20...
Member since: 09 July 2008
Total points: 1175 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Lots of fluids and rest. Force him to drink water and pedialite to rehydrate.



</answer>



<answer from>



Valentines baby on the way
Member since: 04 December 2007
Total points: 10925 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If he is feverish, do not bundle him up a lot. Give him a cool, wet wash cloth to put on his forehead because he needs to cool down. Give him some cough medicine for the cough and put some Vick's Vap o Rub on his chest to help him breath easier. Give him lots of fluids like warm tea, orange juice and other juices with vitamin C. Keep him hydrated and cool with a fever.



</answer>

<answer from>

<answer>



Seeing you accidentally is one thing-there's no harm in that.But the issue here that needs to be addressed immediately is the spying.It's not only not okay,as an adult he can get into extreme trouble for it. Tell him how serious it is to invade someone's privacy.I explained it to my guys like this-" Watching someone when they don't know it is a form of stealing.What you are taking from them is the sense of feeling safe and free to be alone.It is also a form of lying,as they don't know you are there and in families,we trust each other.I need to trust that you will tell me when you are coming near.Just like you don't want me to watch you in private moments,I don't want you to watch me in private moments." It's so important that you establish boundaries now.He'll thank you later,and so will other people he's around,because boundary issues come up every day.



</answer>

<question>



Parents...how would handle this situation (a little long)?



Last night i had a 13 year old girl come to me practically in tears because she had a really bad fight with her mom and she was kicked out of the house. The fight was about the girl's sister's boyfriend living there and how he makes her feel uncomfortable (not in a sexual way -- just angry and depressed). She was trying to tell her mom about how him being there affects her but her mom basically said "If you don't like him living here, you can get the hell out."



For some background information. Her sister is 19, almost 20 and her boyfriend is 22 and almost 23. He's been living in their house for a good 3 years and he graduated college a year and a half ago. Her sister is 3 hours away in college but he didn't want to move because he has a good steady job here so her mom, without any consideration for her youngest, said he's more than welcome to stay as long as he needs. For the first 2 and a half years of him living there, while everyone else was gone, he would find the 13 year old and pick on her. Scream in her ear, push her around, hit her...it was just non stop. And her sister and the boyfriend would gang up on her when their mom wasn't there too and end up screaming at her. She would try to tell her mom but her mom would never believe her because she put a lot more effort into believing and respecting her sister and the boyfriend.Finally it got to the point where the 13 year old said she would just go live with her dad (who lives a good 24 hours away - divorced) and her mom didn't want him to have her so she told the boyfriend he was not to interact with her. But it's hardly gone down at all. She's the happiest girl when he's not around but as soon as he walks in the door she deflates kind of. She is to the point of being really depressed and she's always angry and sad when he's around. But her mom would rather kick her out of the house than ask him to move out. And it's not like he doesn't have the money, he gets paid 500 dollars a week from his job so he can afford to get an apartment or house, he's just too d*mn lazy to do the things having one entails.



She wants me to help her figure it our and do something but i honestly don't  know what i can do. I'm only 17 years old and sure, i had a ton of problems with my mom and i moved out at 16 and in with my boyfriend but i would definitely not suggest that to her. Especially at this age. It's tough being out on your own and she won't be able to handle it.



Any suggestions on what i can do for her?



</question>



<additional details>



He can't live with his parents because they treated him very badly also, that's how he ended up at their house in the first place...his parents kicked him out.



And her mom isn't getting anything out of it. She covers all of his expenses...the only he pays for is stuff for his girlfriend, and yes...i'm sure they're not doing anything in a sexual manner.



I can't go to my parents because i'm not in contact with either of them.



And her mom is very back and forth. She kicks her out one minute...but then is asking her her back the next.



She stayed in my apartment last night and her mom has already been calling about when she's coming back and it's only 9:30. I have contacted her dad to let him know what's going on. And he does love her and wanted her to come stay but her mom got custody and hasn't been following visitation orders.

<answer>



My kids have never had a pet frog. We had a frog during the summer months that would come on our porch every few nights to catch bugs, but I think our dog chased it off. They eat bugs and like to be in water sometimes depending on what type of frog it is. Let the frogs stay in your back yard, but roam around freely as they please. Tell your kids the frogs may leave, but that is ok because they do not need to be caged up. It is their nature to go about where ever they feel free to. They like bugs to eat.

<answer>



I have not - but I would advise you to call a vet or do some searching online to find out what type of frog it is, and then what is required for care.  Is it really a frog or a toad?  Does it need heat or cold?  Does it require a water environment?  What does it eat and how often?



If you do not find out this information, chances are you are just slowing killing an animal.



I think you got 'attacked' because it really isn't a good idea to take an animal from a natural environment and putting it in an unnatural one.  It would be like saying, there is a deer in our yard and we want it to be a pet.

<answer>



Where I live, to keep on inside you need a reptile licence. It's also illegal to take a wild animal, and domesticate it, unless you have a license to do so. In some places, you can go and catch tadpoles though.



I live on an Island State, and they are super strict what you can, and cannot keep.



Try ringing you local pet store, and finding out first if you do need a license to keep them.
Then hit the books on what to feed them. I've had very interesting pets over the years, and my local pet shop has been very helpful.
You'll also need to set the aquarium up.



Source(s):



I work with Animals.



</answer>

<answer>



We have kept a frog from out side it had gotten hit by a car but was still alive so we helped him get better. I would suggest after you get one take it to a pet shop they will set you up with everything you need. The one we had ate pin head crickets and wax worms.

<answer>



go to the county courthouse and file for custody and child support. let the courts decide a reasonable agreement for time well spent with each parent. he'll have to pay about 100 bucks to file in court but you don't need an attorney to do it. it'll take about 2 months for something to go into place. i highly suggest paying the 400 bucks for a DNA test though just to be sure he doesn't start spending time with and paying for a child that isn't his (especially if they weren't exclusive). the judge will most likely do every other weekend with the non custodial parent, and he will have to pay child support. unless of course he's fighting for full custody and in which case HE can ask for child support from her. Just make sure he has an appropraite work schedule, home, income, etc. to prove he's a fit parent. The courts are usually fair in splitting time and then if she doesn't hand the child over, he files contempt charges and the judge will order her to. :) good luck.



</answer>

<question from>



I LOVE VEGAS!!!
Member since: 20 April 2008
Total points: 3619 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Questions for parents that do NOT vaccinate their children?



I asked this last night, but barely got any responses



I'm not putting you down. I respect every mom's decision for what they do for their child. I just have a few questions.



When you were in labor, did you take any pain meds and if you did, which ones?  (The reason I ask is because if you did, you are putting something in your body, while your newborn is still in your belly.  Yes, doctors say that the medicines don't harm the baby, but anti vaccine mom's believe the dr's lie to them about what's in vaccines, what's to say they aren't lying about medicines they give you while in labor?)



If your child gets sick, do you give them antibiotics?
(I've heard the arguement from anti vaccine parents that "there is too much risk" in giving their child vaccines, isn't there just as much risk giving your child antibiotics?  They can have a reaction to the antibiotic just like they can have  a reaction to vaccines.  A child can die from an allergic reaction to antibiotics, do you risk that?  I do vaccinate, but I rarely EVER give antibiotics.  I have seen first hand a severe reaction, my son had one.)



When you are around newborns and children with immune disorders, do you inform the parents that your child has not been vaccinated?
(The reason I ask this is because newborns that have yet to vaccinated are at high risk of contracting the illnesses that are vaccinated againts.  And kids with immune disorders can not get vaccinated and are also at high risk at contracted these illnesses, do you tell the parents?)



Thanks in advance to everyone who gives me real answers and that aren't rude about their answers.



</question>



<additional details>



mom+5-I respect why you did not vaccinate your children, BUT, reality is an unvaccinated child has an extremely high risk of contracting any of the childhood illnesses, whooping cough and measles can kill baby under 3 months old and can kill a child with an immune disorder.  A child is contagious before they show any symptoms.



</additional details>

If you want her to think there is nothing wrong you have to act like there is nothing wrong.

<answer from>



Robin G

<answer>



First, take away all other options.  Tell him that it's time to say bye-bye to his summer shoes and hello to winter shoes.  Make it fun for him!  Make a game out of it.  Read some wintry stories with him and show him pictures of what people wear during winter and point out why it's different.  Yelling and spanking (hitting) are not good ways to get a child to do anything for you.  Be patient, and think of creative solutions.  Since the school most likely doesn't allow open toed shoes, perhaps get his teacher involved?  If all else fails, seek help from a school counselor or parent support group.



This is an example of your child taking control over you, and you should be the one in control.

<answer>



First of all, spanking is completely unacceptable for this situation, please don't do it again.

There are no absolute answers, in the end you will find a way to make this work.  I wish you the best of luck with it.

<answer from>



Anna T
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 199 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



First of all, never spank your child.  You don't want him to respect you only out of fear, which is what spanking inspires.  This is probably a phase of not wanting to wear socks, but you can fix it.  Set aside a lot of time to do this.  Tell your son that you're going somewhere but that he can only go if he wears shoes and socks.  He will probably fight you in which case put him in a time out for as many minutes as his age, so 4 minutes.  If he sits in his time out quietly and without trying to leave, after it's over go to him, give him a hug, tell him to apologize for yelling at you, and tell him to put on his shoes again.  If he will not put on his shoes the second time repeat the process.  It will be VERY tiring the first few times, but eventually he will get the message that he needs to do what you are asking him.  If he does not sit in his time outs quietly and tries to get up and leave, you need to go get him and put him back, each time you do this tell him you are starting the 4 minutes over again.  Like I said, it will take a while, but it WILL be effective in the end, you just might have to use this form of punishment for a while before your son understands that if he doesn't do what you tell him, he will be put in time outs and then have to do what you say.  But remember to give him a hug when he's done with the time out and have him apologize.  This way you will not leave the fight both feeling horrible.  Hopefully this will help!!!



</answer>



<answer from>



redshort...
Member since: 05 August 2006
Total points: 2635 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Try this. Go to the store and pick out like four pairs of shoes that you want him to wear and let him pick which one he likes the most. Most of the time if they have a choice and pick it they will wear it with no fuss because it was there choosing. Hope that helps. ( try some shoes with cartoons or something on them that he likes alot)



</answer>



<answer from>



Jeffrey P
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 461 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why not just let him wear them until it gets cold. I'm sure when his feet are cold, he'll want to wear other shoes and possibly boots. Most of the time these little battles have to do more with the parents not wanting to lose control. The little ones want to start making their own decisions. So. let him pick out his own clothes, even if they don't match. Let him pick out some socks at the store and maybe he'll be excited to wear them. Let him pick what shoes for now, I don't think it's cold enough that he'll get frostbite. Let go of the control a little and don't lose control of the temper.



</answer>



<answer from>



cresun
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



don't force anything upon him and don't project your anger upon him



let the kid learn from experience



let him walk bare feet in crooks if that's what he wants



just don't make things any worse!



punishment is DEFINITELY NOT gonna serve anyone, and you should know that



be an example of a mother who allows her child to be and learn from personal experiences



anything else will cause wounds, so please listen up



</answer>



<answer from>



Kevin L
Member since: 21 November 2007
Total points: 799 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As the parent you have to figure out how to get what you want, and make it seem like a good thing to the child. Otherwise they will disobey.
I would start off by telling him in a calm an understanding tone that, he can get sick if he allows his feet to get cold and wet. Point out the things he likes to do, and how he won't be able to do them if he gets sick. You may even compromise a bit and strike a deal that he can wear whatever he wants in the house, but when it is cold outside, or he is going to school, he must wear shoes and socks.



A four year old needs to understand that the parent is in charge, and needs to make sure their child is well looked after. Time outs work well if you stay level headed about it. No screaming! Sit them down in a time out spot, or put the crocs in a time out. Bisobedience gets no reward, and if you allow yourself to cave in, plan for failure. Be consistant in the punishment, and when the time out is done, explain why the punishment was done, and what you expect.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jayde--x
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 436 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>

<question>



Is it time for a new pediatrician? My oldest was repeatedly getting "strep throat" despite having a very ?



scarlet fever type rash on his thighs (yes it really turned out to be scarlet fever). My youngest has had asthma/allergy issues since a year old and I have practically begged her to spend more time diagnosing him only to end up at urgent care or the ER because I knew he would get worse w/in a matter of hours only to have her dismiss my concerns. An urgent care doctor told me that his adenoids should come out.....she said no but sent me to the ent who immediately said, yes, let's get them out. She's very sweet and my children like her but I feel like she's overlooking some things. My youngest sees an allergy/asthma specialist now. Should I continue taking them to her for the basic illnesses or scratch her completely?



</question>

<answer from>



ceegt
Member since: 22 December 2006
Total points: 11028 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your number one concern has to be your children and just because she is very sweet, doesn't mean she is a good doctor. I would be looking for someone who is more thorough. I have a friend who took her child to a pediatrician that was not a believer in  prescribing antibiotics and rarely did so. Her one year old baby was running a very high fever and they rushed him to the emergency room. Her doctor was there that night and sent him home without an antibiotic after getting the fever down. She barely got home and the fever spiked again. She rushed him back and again the doctor got the fever down and sent the baby home. On the third trip back he died. An autopsy showed he had a bacteria infection and if the doctor had admitted him into the hospital and started him on the antibiotics there is a chance he would have lived. Of course no one will ever know for certain, but in my opinion, he may have. Don't let this happen to you. If your pediatrician is missing things, this could become serious.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mom+five
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 2315 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, it is time for a new pediatrician.



</answer>

<answer>



Many children are afraid of being alone.  Many have common fears: spiders, snakes, things in the dark. But, they won't think a thing about doing double back flips on a trampoline, or things like that.

Chinese saying

<answer from>



Mary C
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 3745 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Kids go through stages of being afraid of different things.  I can remember when my daughter (now 35) was terrified of wolves.  She was about 3-4, and was just sure that a wolf would find his way into the house and eat us all up!  I assured her that wolves were just a 'different kind of dog,' and even took her to a wolf shelter where she could interact with them.  She still didn't care for wolves, but her brother, who was a year younger, has always been fascinated by wolves.



But here is a weird one!  My son (now 34) at age 5 was terrified by the ladies at the local Women's Prison.  To get to my MIL's home, we had to drive by the prison.  He would hide on the floor of the car.  Once, there was a highly publicized escape by an inmate, and my son was in a constant state of terror that the lady was going to come and get him.  When he was in college he worked as a meter reader for our local electric utility.  The Women's Prison was on his route.  At 21, he was still fearful of going there!  He preferred to reading the electric meter in the worst drug house in the city to going into the Women's Prison!



My 3 year old granddaughter is afraid of wolves, blood, and loud voices.  She falls apart if someone gets hurt and bleeds!  If she hears raised voices, she is sure that people are 'fighting!'  I guess I need to take her to the wolf shelter to see that the wolves are just a 'different kind of dog'!



My 2 year old granddaughter is only afraid of loud noises and being startled.  A car backfire will send her on a crying jag!



Fortunately, my kids and grandkids have/had no fear of bugs.  We all think bugs are cool!



</answer>



<answer from>



Leci
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 208 (Level 1)

<question>



Parents with teens at home?



I moved back home when I found out I was pregnant (at my mom's insistence). I do all the cooking, cleaning, and getting groceries, cleaning supplies, etc for the house and stick to a budget. I occasionally take my sister places so my parents don't have to. My mom "pays" me $20 a week (its really more of an allowance, as I can't work).



What's some extra stuff I can do for them to show them how much I really appreciate everything they've done for me?



</question>



<additional details>



The money really just goes for gas or my cell bill.



Actually I volunteered to do all the stuff around the house. And they weren't happy with the situation, but are REALLY looking forward to meeting their grandson lol. He's also named after my dad and grandfather.



Mom never really has to ask me to do anything, I even fix her lunch at night so she doesn't in the morning.

<question from>



Lauren
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 418 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What can i do for my daughter?? how can i be there for her during this horrible time?



My family recently moved from a place we had lived for 16 years....her friend who she lost touch with sort of has developed a type of lympthatic cancer...its not lyphoma but its a type having to do with lymphnodes? We think. Her ex-friends have not really filled her in on everything she knows--
1. She will have 6 months of chemo, and won't be able to go back to school for the rest of the year and will be in the hospital for atleast another 30 days.
2. It should go away and never come back after 6 months.
3.Shes in cook childrens.



I wanted to ask you, so i can comfort my daughter, if this girl will loose her hair due to chemo? and if she will have to repeat the year? and if there is anyway she can send her a card or stuffed animal?



One friend told her that no one had seen her because she just started chemo and she couldn't be around germs, but yet another told her that she had been there everyday that week for moral support since she has had surgies on her legs plently of times.



My daughter is very heartbroken, and i was wondering...can u answer those questions? I am quite clueless when it comes down to all this sort of stuff. I feel bad.



</question>



<answer from>



Kate
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hi Lauren,



I'd suggest your daughter phones or sends a letter to her friend...Personally, I think at difficult times we all take notice of who takes the time and trouble to get in touch. I'm guessing your daughter's friend would like to hear from her and will appreciate her efforts.



Particularly with things like cancer, some people worry they will say or do the wrong thing and so they stay away or hang back, but that can leave the sick person isolated at a time when the more love and affection around them the better!!



One question is why are they former friends? From what you say it sounds as though your daughter is wanting and trying to keep in touch...perhaps you can help her? You haven't said how far you've moved but it is possible for her to reestablish contact? Letters, phone calls, visits - all good options. Perhaps she could call and ask what her friend is up for? The main thing is to think of her friend's needs.



Please don't feel bad about it - if you're feeling bad you won't have the energy to do anything about it. I don't think anyone's an expert in this stuff but just getting in touch and doing it sensitively is a great thing to do for your daughter and her friend. Trust your instincts.



Good luck!



kate



</answer>

I handle it because I'm lucky enough to have a decent job with health insurance, a decent car that I had before my daughter came along, and we have a great babysitter and family who is there for us when we need them.

<answer>



And it's major why?



As far as I can tell, a person has been elected president and hasn't served yet.  Whether he turns out to be a good or bad president and have a major impact on the direction of the country still remains to be seen.



If you're going to say that it's because an african-american was elected I think you need to realize that's probably not a major event to your kids in quite the same way it is to you.



I don't know that politics are any different than when I was a kid except maybe more divisive.  Can you really say the country is more united now than when you were younger?  Before you start basking in the joy of an Obama victory let's just be honest and say it wasn't a landslide in terms of the popular vote.



</answer>



<answer from>



forever5
Member since: 13 August 2007
Total points: 14276 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your kids will realize it when they are old enough to take history classes.  You were taught about Abraham Lincoln and you realize the importance of his presidency.  You were taught about John F. Kennedy and you know the importance of his presidency and the importance of his subsequent assassination.



If my kids were around the age of 10 and up, I would discuss it somewhat with them but it wouldn't be a big topic unless they wanted to continue it.
It didn't matter who won last night, history would have been made.  On one side there would be the first black president, on the other side there would have been the first female vice president.
Someday, our children will realize it and hopefully they will see more "changes".  Maybe a female president, maybe a minority president, maybe a president that follows through on election promises (had to throw that in!).  Who knows where we will be in 20 or 30 years.

<question>



What should i do please help?



My son is nearly 4 years old and just started nursery in september. He really enjoys it but now for the last week he has been coming home upset and saying a boy keeps hitting, biting and pushing him of bikes etc. It started last week when the teacher got me and said that another boy had bitten him and they had to tell me because it left a big imprint and made his hand bleed. I was willing to let it go as that what kids do and he had been told its wrong. The next day my son came home with a cut ear and he told me the same boy pulled him by the ear. My son is very quiet and didnt tell the teachers but someone else did but they did not tell me. I had to find out off my son. Yesterday he came home with a cut chin where the same boy scratched him apparently he told teacher but they stuill did not inform me. Are they taking this seriously as everyday he comes home with a different mark on his tiny body. This boy is alot bigger than him and he is now scared to go to school. I have informed the teachers but it does not seem to be stopping. What should my next step be, should i approach the mother or should i take him out? My son would never hurt anyone and i would not condone him hitting back what should i do?



</question>



<additional details>



the same thing happened to my daughter at that age we managed to sort it (different teachers) she is now six and very reserved and shy i dont want the same to happen to my boy. I could change him to the morning session but y should i. I had parents evening and spoke to teachers who said they were 'monitoring the situation'.



</additional details>

<answer from>



mom2baby...
Member since: 18 June 2006
Total points: 4814 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Where do you live?



In Texas, preschools are held to the same standards as daycares.  This means if they fail to report an incident of injury, regardless of the reason, an inspector comes out and talks to the director.  Serious consequences can occur for the preschool if they fail to take action.



Those preschools that are also part of a school district have the additional protection under the district's anti-bullying policy.  The teacher could acutally lose their job for allowing it to occur.



You really need to tell the teacher that you require an incident report each and every time your child is injured, and that she is to fully look him over before sending him home.  If you find any injuries or he tells you of an incident and you did not recieve a report, that you are going to document it in writing to the principal/director.  At the same time, go over her head and talk to the principal/director, and insist that this bully be removed from the classroom or otherwise be separated from your son or you will be forced to take legal action against them and the other parents for these assaults and emotional trauma.  Tell them in no uncertain terms you are NOT going to switch your child out of his class when he has done nothing wrong.  He's not the problem, the other kid is, and demand to see all documents regarding parental notification to you and the other parents.



If you're in the states, by law, they have to notify you and the other parent each time this happens.  If they have an anti-bullying policy, point this out to them and suggest that if they are not going to follow it, regulators should probably be involved to show them how to implement it.



Source(s):



Raise hell!  You have the right to protect your child!



</answer>

<question>



Do I ask too much of my 13yr old? ?



I am on permanent disability. I developed a blood clot in my thigh when I was pregnant with my 2 1/2 yr old. I am in pain quite a bit as the clot is still there, and my legs swell all of the time. I am not supposed to sit or stand for longer than an hour.
So-
my 13 yr old is very lazy. She comes home from school and sits in front of the tv and watches the food network. I will ask her to change the baby's diaper and keep an eye on him so that I can get a little break. I ask her to help me pick up or go get the load out of the dryer and she gets an attitude. She is supposed to do dishes, but doesn't. If I yell at her or take her phone away, then she is mean to her brother. My house is a complete mess and I am overwhelmed by it because I can't do it on my own.



If I am cleaning my room, or the kitchen, I expect her to at least make sure the baby isn't in playing in the toilet, since all she is doing is sitting on the couch. But I will walk out there, and he will be coloring on the walls, or there will be stuff everywhere. How can I get her to help me more? She does not care about my disability at all, it seems. She is also very rude to me.



</question>



<answer from>

Member since: 10 July 2007

<answer>



Well, the laundry and dishes I agree with. She needs to do some household chores- that is absolutely not too much to ask. Children should start helping out around the house even earlier than that. She needs to adjust the attitude and realise that if she lives and eats in the house, then she needs to help maintain it.



As for watching the baby, I don't think she should have to do that. Just because she is 13 doesn't mean she should become the "in-house babysitter"... I mean, what would you do if she wasn't there? You'd have to hire someone and pay them. Remember that it was your choice to have your child, so it's not her responsibility to care for him. I don't realy blame her from wanting to relax after school and not go straight from schoolwork to babysitting.



</answer>



<answer from>



Laura

</answer from>



<answer>



Based on what you describe you are not asking too much.  It sounds like some things she takes for granted should be re-framed as privileges.  She likes watching TV?  That privilege is earned by watching her brother while you clean.  She wants to use the phone?  She needs to do the dishes occasionally.  You get the idea.



As for her rudeness, again it comes down to rewards.  Rudeness results in having something of value denied.



It sounds like both of you are having a hard time.  Maybe it would help if she had and/or you saw a therapist?



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...



</answer>

<answer>



When kids are that age, they feel tired from a full day of school and all they want to do when they get home is rest and watch tv before they have to start working yet again on homework. Kids are going to complain when they have chores. I remember I would complain and get mad when all I had to do is the dishes. This girl has to not only do the dishes, but help with the laundry, watch her little sibling, and change diapers. It's not your fault that you can't do these things but you need to calmly explain to her that you both need to work together, and whenever you can it would be best to ease up on her workload because after all you are the mother. It's hard for a girl to have so much responsibility at a young age. Coming home from school then helping her mom raise her little brother and doing homework doesn't give her a lot of time to be a kid...
Good luck, I hope my opinion helped.



Source(s):



me



</answer>

<answer>



You have a disability in which you need extra attention. You've got a toddler that needs extra attention. It sounds like your daughter is screaming for attention too. It sounds like she's unhappy and just ignoring your and your toddler. That's her way of asking for attention.
Get someone to watch the young one once a week and try spending some one on one time with her.
She's watching the food network, ask her to look up some recipes on-line and help you cook them. After a few weeks of spending some one on one time with her, tell her how much you love her and how tough things are for you right now. ASK her if she could help you out and tell her thank you when she does.
Treat her like a daughter and not the hired help.... and stop yelling at her. believe it or not talking does more good than yelling.
As for her being rude to you... she's 13.



Good Luck



Source(s):



Father of a 14 year old boy who used to act the same way.



</answer>
