<answer from>



ceegt
Member since: 22 December 2006
Total points: 11030 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Being at school can be like being at work. When one first gets in the door from work the last thing they can handle is being bombarded with things they have to do. Try having a heart to heart talk with your daughter and come to a compromise. Perhaps you can agree to allow her some down time when she first gets home from school. Give her maybe an hour or an hour and a half to unwind as she pleases. Once the time is up, let her know she has a chore or two to do, but don't overwhelm her. Remember that she also has homework to think about and that's a lot for her. Kids need time to just be kids. All too soon they are no longer a child. Watching her little brother constantly will only make her resent him. She is a child and not a parent. If you ask this of her, then she deserves to be rewarded. Talk about this with her as well. Rewards always work much better than punishments. You could even go so far as setting up a chore chart and giving her a star for every time she does a chore and two stars if she does the chore without complaint. Tell her she needs to earn a minimum of stars per day. Example: if she has 3 chores to do she must earn 3 stars. At the end of the week if she has met the minimum of stars reward her. If she gets an allowance you can give her a few extra dollars, or it could be a new blouse or something she has been wanting. At the end of the month if she has completed her minimum every day, then give her a bigger reward. It doesn't mean it has to be expensive, it just should be something she will want bad enough to work towards it. With my kids it could be something as simple as a special day spent with me. You and her can work out what works best for you. Everyone needs to feel appreciated and a little appreciation goes a long, long way! Also, don't give her too many chores; like I said, she is a kid and it isn't fair to dump all of your responsibilites on her. If you can afford it, consider having someone come in once a week to clean house for you. If not, then ask your doctor to declare you temporarily disabled and look into IHSS if you live in a state that has this program. It is a state program that will pay for someone to come in and clean for you and do chores that you are unable to do for yourself. It is free if you are low income. Best wishes to you!



</answer>



<answer from>



cresun
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



punishing her will not serve anything good



what other children do in their homes to support their families is completely insignificant



do you understand why?



because each individual is different; each individual have different needs; each individual have different issues goin on in their lives...and that includes your daughter



if she is not giving, she is not capable of giving, because unconditional giving is an act of love



if she is not connected to love, something is blocking her connection...which is most likely an issue or a fear



i understand this is a frustrating situation from your point of view, but you have to change your view of your little princess



there's a reason for everything



the best thing you can do is trying to show her that you love her as her mother, before she blocks you from anger and frustration



try to communicate



if she is not able to give any support, and please understand that it doesn't have to be a matter of physical capacity, do not fire up on her



ask her what is going on in her life and see if there is anything you can do for her to help her lighten up



if that won't do, focus upon getting your support elsewhere



start by playing this out in your mind; visualize it and reach for the feeling place of it



if you can solve your personal issues and let go of your negative thoughts, you will also be able to naturally heal, if that is what you intend...



</answer>



<answer from>



Mary C
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 3749 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here's the thing...Somehow, you have to get your 13 year old daughter to become a contributing member of the household.  I would suggest having an adult talk with her -- no criticism or anger.  Let her know that you really need her help to do certain things -- for example, the laundry, picking up the living room, and setting the table for dinner.



I think that your "scattergun" approach isn't working.  "Watch the baby, if you won't do that, then clean the kitchen, if you won't do that then fix the dinner, if you won't do that then..."  This is not working!



If you have any way of 'rewarding' her for doing her part, that is great!



The secret to success is getting your daughter on 'the same page' as far as contributing to the family.



She has to know that she is really NEEDED, not just 'put upon' to live in the home.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



My daughter's father and I split up when she was 1 yr. old.  In a lot of ways, it's been much easier on my own.  I don't have someone bitching when I call my mom for advice, I make all the decisions regarding my daughter, I don't have to deal with a partner who you don't know when you can rely on them or not (like when he was supposed to watch our daughter during the day while I worked, but at times when we'd fight he'd take off at night and I never knew if he would be back to watch her in the morning or not - a bunch of B.S. like that...)  I handle it because I'm lucky enough to have a decent job with health insurance, a decent car that I had before my daughter came along, and we have a great babysitter and family who is there for us when we need them.



</answer>

Mary C

<answer>



Cripes!  Our kids are going to do the same things that we did but only worse!



As a small child, you were probably influenced by the arguing in the home. which made you mean to your younger siblings.



Rule #1:  No arguing in front of the kids!



Rule #2:  Treat your spouse and your kids with respect.  Although my husband and I had not discussed child rearing  prior to our marriage, we were on the same page as to treating the kids with the same respect that we expected from them.  There was rarely a raised voice in the home.  When our kids' friends ate dinner with us, they would comment that "your family treats each other like company!  You are so polite to each other!"



Rule #3:  If your parents don't back you up, who will?



That's all!



</answer>

<question from>



Mountain Sunset
Member since: 28 October 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Dealing with temper tantrums? ?



I was just curious how other people deal with tantrums? Yesterday my four year old daughter had a bad one while we were at my mother's house. I told her she could not have something and she just had a fit. Kicking, screaming, and yelling. I tried to ignore, but it went on and on. Finally I told her if she did not stop, then she was going to get a spanking. Then she kicked me. I stayed calm, picked her up and took her to the guest room. I gave her four swats on her bare hiney, and surprisingly she calmed down. She sobbed for a minute or two and then it was over. Now usually I only spank for lying or doing something dangerous. However it worked well in this situation. I was just wondering if other people spanked for tantrums or do you use some other method? I usually ignore them, but I may change now



</question>



<answer from>



dsbettyb...
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 683 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I really don't think spanking is the right thing to do.  The only reason it ever does work is because it makes the child scared of you.  You don't want your daughter scared of you do you?  My parents spanked me and it never really worked unless my dad did it, but it never made us any better...we learned that part ourselves.  I have a son and I always said I would never spank him..and I don't.  He has time-outs in his playpen and that is all it is used for.  (He's 18 months, but has temper tantrums like a 2-3 year old.)  You can do whatever you'd like I just don't think spankings are the way to go.  My son is in time-out for 1 minute for his age.  Try putting her in time-out for 4 minutes, if she gets up keep putting her back until she sits there for her 4 minutes, whether she is screaming or not.  Tell her before why she is going in time-out and remind her after she is done why she had gotten in trouble.  Hope you find something that works, it works fine with my son :)  Good Luck!!



</answer>



<answer from>



x-winter...
Member since: 05 June 2008
Total points: 1569 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



For temper tantrums or ignoring me, I usually use pick them up, carry them to their bedroom, or just the sofa even if I'm at someone elses house. Then I normally put her in on her bed, shut the door and wait outside for three minutes- one for every year of her age. I don't talk to her, don't say anything to her, apart from no. You have to be authoritive for it to work, not saying 'oh, don't do that' but 'no'. If she does it again, she goes in again. I normally only have to do it if she's having a really cranky day otherwise the 'no' works and she stops. It just gives them a while to calm down.



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



qpdoll
Member since: 06 July 2006

</answer from>



<answer>



i am a mom that believes in spanking.  it has worked for my son.  i only do it when like your daughter, throws major fits.  like you, i tried to ignore him at first but realized he wanted more attention and thats why it would escalate.....when he realized, from then on,  that i was going to give him that kind of attention (spanking), when i warn him now, he usually calms down and we talk about it.  i know most people do not agree with spanking, but if it worked for me and my siblings, then i knew it would work for my son.  my second is on her way and it will be no different, although my son might warn her that mom is not joking.



the one thing people have to remember, is the difference between spanking and a beating.  keep it a quick spanking and its gonna work.

<answer>



I think you did the right thing.  Yes, I did spank but only swats to get attention and spankings for out deliberate defiance.  When our kids would have a fit and need to cry we would send them to their rooms( even our 2 year old) and tell them that we understood if they were upset and needed to cry but that they were not permitted to cry in a room where other people were and that they needed to go to their room until they felt better.  People always laughed at us for this but it worked and as they grew older, they would run to their room, cry a bit and come out and say, "I'm done now".  We praised them for getting themselves under control and now at 13 and 15 they are mild-mannered kids who know how to control themselves.  I would also deal with the fact that she kicked you.  Make sure she knows that this isnt permissible and that if she is frustrated, she can use other ways to get her anger out.  As a Christian parent, we always prayed after the spanking or incident and asked God to help us behave better in our actions.  That worked well to.  Good luck, it sounds like you have things on the right track.  Oh, as far as ignoring goes, you can do that to a certain extent but I never felt comfortable letting my kids scream it out in front of others.  I never wanted them to feel like they had the power to control the room or the situation.  That's why we sent them to their rooms to have a fit.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



For this particular instance I think you handled it fine.  I would never suggest ignoring it completely.  Addressing it and then setting her in a separate room is appropriate.  But when she kicked you, that right there crossed a certain line.  That was an act of deliberate defiance.  If spanking was the best solution and was effective for her, then kudos to you for effectively and calmly handling the situation.



For our two and a half year old, I give him two choices: 1-Keep on having a tantrum and spend time sitting in his room on his bed until he can calm down or 2- Straighten up and behave like the big boy I know he is and we can go back to having fun.  Nine times out of ten, he chooses to straighten up on his own.  We have spanked him for tantrums on certain occasions, but I don't feel that it's always necessary.  I, like you, only tend to give harsh consequences in the event that my son does something to place himself or others in danger or in the event of deliberate defiance.  But like you as well, I'm also seeking out more positive ways to enforce the good behavior and cut back on the unwanted behavior.



In short, you handled it appropriately for your daughter.  Don't second guess yourself.  Be consistent and make your decisions rationally.



</answer>

<evaluation>Answer hidden due to its low rating</evaluation>



I just ignore.  I go into another room because generally I get so mad when she has one that I need some time alone too.  My daughter is 2 and she can get pretty violent with me sometimes during her tantrums.  She pulls hair, she hits etc.  But I just say - "Don't hurt mommy" and I just walk away.  I then wait until she is calm.  I give her a big hug and say that it doesn't help things to get so angry.  I tell her being angry is fine, but yelling and hitting is not. But I am not a believer in spanking.  It might work for some people. But when I was spanked as a child, I learned nothing.  All I Iearned was to resent my mother and fear her.

<answer>



Sadly, I will tell you my children have heard this repeatedly. They were angry with me and my support for Obama because every-single-one of their friends at school were calling him a terrorist. We just continue to teach our girls that everything they hear doesn't mean it's true and just because it's different doesn't mean it's bad.



This morning, I told my girls Obama is our new president. My oldest daughter was upset, at first. I showed her the electoral votes and explained that if Obama was so bad then he would have never got that many votes. Americans are NOT stupid. Just talk to your daughter. Explain how he won and why he won. Explain how it had nothing to do with the color of his skin, only to do with his popularity and what Americans think he can do for us.



Furthermore, tell her she can not go to school or anywhere and repeat that comment. It will hurt peoples feelings and make people angry with her.

Mozz

<answer>



Wow, tough one.



Is the choice you made (19 year old SAHM) a choice made for financial reasons?  The 1:1 interaction?  Without asking you what your son's situation is (don't want to pry) I'm trying to understand more.  In other words, IS there a daycare setting that WILL work for your son?  Then they get the social interaction they both need, you are right, it's important for development.  At the same time, I don't think it'll stunt either one of your kids not to go to daycare.  Lots of kids don't.  As long as they're not shut in the house all day/week/month, they still have plenty of social opportunities.  They don't need it every day throughout the day.  Dont you think?



As for being her hostage (I don't like it here so I'll just get us kicked out), my son tried this.  I sat with him and said "Understand this.  I get that you don't want before-school daycare.  I get that bigtime.  It's the way it is right now.  Know that if you get us kicked out of Miss Christina's, it doesn't make daycare go away.  It makes us have to find a new one.  Think about what you've got that's great at Miss Christina's (friends your age, she doesn't make you eat vegetables, we went over several of these).  Might not have this at the next one.  Furthermore, you WILL be punished beyond your wildest dreams for deliberate bad behavior."  And poof, it all stopped.



</answer>

<question from>



uh-huh

<question>



Little sisters (6 and 8 years old) are telling stories of what boys do to them at school?



I'm 18 and 3 of my little sisters are 8, "Sarah" and twin 6 yo's, "Sally" and "Sue". they all share a room and i was carrying my youngest brother upstairs to get him cleaned up after a major "accident", and i noticed they all stopped talking as i went by their room. so after i got him cleaned up I kinda dropped in on them and was all "what's up guys" ya know. so they did their little "excuse us for a second" and then quietly debated on if they should tell me. of course by now i wasn't going to leave until i knew. then Sarah went and closed to door and they told me all about these 5th grade boys at their school.



apparently after school a group of 5 older boys gang up on my younger sibs. 2 of them take my 9 and 7 yo bros and get them pre-occupied with something else while the other 3 show my little sisters "boy things". and i didn't get details but from what I gather these boys are dropping their pants, showing my little sisters their private areas, and then trying to get my little sisters to do the same. which they proudly told me they haven't done. but these boys are "nice and cute and not mean, etc."



i was first revolted and disgusted by this. and after i was sworn to secrecy i was going to head strait downstairs to tell my parents. but i don't really know how to tell them. do i say "hey dad, go talk to the girls about boys at school" or do i just say "hey, this is what they told me".



1) my sisters would never trust me again, but right now i don't really care about that
2) my dad would be at the school within' 10 seconds raising hell in the office trying to get these boys expelled, in the middle of the school day



i just don't know how to tell him, or when?
advice on how to approach the subject?



</question>



<additional details>



and also the 8 yo is a compulsive liar, so there is a slight possibility this isn't true, but of course thats not a reason not to tell.



</additional details>

Now, having said that, obviously, this is not an appropriate activity at all, and must stop immediately. <question from>



Rosie
Member since: 12 April 2008
Total points: 4051 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



Working mothers who have become SAHM,?



I need some advice.
My bff has just lost her job and is now a SAHM, her bf works and is supporting the household for now.
She has a 3 yr old and has been telling me that she yells alot at her child because she can't handle her crying all the time. She get frustrated and is having a hrd time adjusting. Did you go thru this as well?, is it a phase? How long does it last?
I have never been a SAHM, so I don't know what its like to all of a sudden be a SAHM.



</question>



<answer from>



Due with #2 June 09
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 6013 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



The only time for me was after I had my first baby and was on mat leave for one year.  Although I found the first three months incredibly difficult (had post pardum depression and severe sleep deprivation!), I loved it.



For me, though, working two days a week would be the perfect combination.  I would love to spend more time with my daughter than I do since going back to work full-time, but I would also like a couple of days of using my brain!!



</answer>



<answer from>



pinkpigl...
Member since: 01 June 2007
Total points: 9375 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Why is a 3yr old crying all the time?  That's something to look at right there.



Is she crying because she's getting yelled at instead of the other way around?



Is she yelling because she's upset she's lost her job and is taking it out on the child?



Do they get out of the house and do things?  Story time at the library, playing at the park, playing on the front lawn, getting exercise?



Being active is important.



No I didn't go through that.  I was SO glad that I was finally able to stay home.



I have fun with my kids and am so thankful I've been able to be at home for 13 years now.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle
Member since: 03 March 2006
Total points: 6006 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's easier if you willingly become a SAHM. But when you are forced into it like your friend was - it's stressful. You feel like a failure and now, all of the sudden - you are stuck with this little person who constantly requires your attention. Sometimes all you really need is a break to unwind and get your thoughts together. ... Plus, a lot of moms don't want to cry in front of their children. You have this need to relieve some stress, but you can't and this little baby is just sitting there crying, being loud, and it is your job to fix it when you already have enough problems of your own! It's a bit overwhelming.



Don't take me wrong. I love my daughter and cherished our time together when I was a stay at home mom :) But at times, it really is too much. Your life feels so out of control and when you feel motivated to go out and do something about it, you can't because somebody has to be at home with the kid.



I don't think this is a phase. Your friend needs help. It may take a few months for her to get into the new swing of things. It should help a lot if somebody can watch her daughter for a few hours while her husband is out or maybe even for a night. And having a friend to talk to can help too. (I am guessing you are willing, but maybe she isn't ready or maybe she doesn't know it's ok to talk to you.)



If she is looking, I hope your friend can find a new job soon. Even something part time can help out a lot. She probably needs to get out and experience the satisfaction that comes from challenging the adult side of her brain and knowing that she is helping to provide for her family.



Source(s):



I was constantly stressed and having to remind myself to control my emotions when I was unable to find a job. ... I felt so much better when I went back to work part time! (which turned to full time within a year)



</answer>

<question>



Private verses Public school?



What are the pro and cons of both? I attended a public school for 13 years (K-12) and to be honest I don't want to send my son there. I was intellectually BORED, especially in high school. I seriously could have gotten my GED at 15 and not missed anything.



</question>



<additional details>



I was in the Gifted (higher IQ) program, took all college prep classes.... My parents were involved. I just was too far ahead.... I know how it is to get in trouble for reading in class when supposed to be working on work but was already done....



There is only one private school in my area, no charter ones.... I mean I still have 5 years before he even starts, but if I decide on a private one I'll start saving now for it.



</additional details>



<answer from>



njnic
Member since: 18 March 2008
Total points: 2418 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think if you are an interactive parent within you child's school and learning process that it doesn't matter private/public.  Each type of schools offer different types of learning and if you are gifted even public schools have great programs - I think the trick is knowing that they are there and using the resources. - Good Guidance Counselors and active parents.



</answer>



<answer from>



Blob
Member since: 30 July 2008
Total points: 7787 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



I went to public school in junior high and a private school in high school and the difference is amazing! I will never send my children to a public school. Here is a list of pros and cons I've come up with:



Private
Pros-students get a better education, students get more one on one attention from teachers, students are nicer to one another, less alcohol and drug use from students, looks great on college applications and so many more.
Cons- it's expensive, not as many classes offered



Public pros and cons-basically complete opposite of my list for private.



I strongly recommend sending your children to a private school, if you can afford it then go for it. It is completely worth it. I worked in an elementary private school for three years and I was amazed by the amount of respect those children showed not only their friends but their teachers as well.



</answer>



<answer from>



teri
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 3339 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



private..
pros- small class rooms,more teacher attention
cons- cost, other kids living in different areas



public..
pros- no cost, kids live in the neighborhood
cons- larger classes, less teacher attention



</answer>

<answer from>



redessa
Member since: 20 August 2007
Total points: 2900 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I went to both private and public schools as a kid and I really prefer private school.  I like the smaller classes, the level of parental involvement, the ability to choose the type of education your child receives.  Do you want a religious school, one focused on the arts, one that more academically competitive.....?  Of course, they can be quite expensive.



You can be very involved in public schools too.  In fact, the teachers NEED much more parental involvement than they get.  And if you do your homework, you can make sure to put your children in the best public schools in your area.  Look for ones with gifted programs for example.  Or consider a charter school which is publicly funded but is run much the same way as a private school.



I think the school experiment is largely what you make it,  But if I could afford it for 5 kids, I would send mine to private school.



</answer>



<answer from>



Christine M
Member since: 27 July 2007
Total points: 1685 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I guess it depends on the school's itself.  I will probably send my daughter to public schools because I feel like that is where she will get the best world experience in dealing with real people and real life issues.  Private schools are good for people with lots of money who want to shelter their kids.  However, the thing about no drugs and stuff is complete crap.  I know of a lot of private school kids who can afford better and more quantities of drugs.  I think it all comes down to the parents and the interaction they have with their children.  I know several private school kids who changed to public schools.



</answer>

<question>



My child doesn't act his age?

Granted my child is very smart in his own way and at times you would never think he was 4 because of his verbal skills. But at times he comes off to act under his age. I wanted to know if this has to do with him never going to daycare and not being interactive with other children? Or is this just a mama's boy act? <answer from>



Michelle

<answer>



I don't see any of these as the fault of the daycare center. I think they do an excellent job of taking care of my daughter! I can tell that she feels safe with and loved by the workers. That is the most important part. (well, that and the fact that they actually do go out of their way to keep the kids safe and show they care)



It would be nice if they could help my daughter with her homework so we could have more fun time at home. But honestly - I can't afford to pay the higher rates that I am sure would accompany that service. (since they would obviously have to hire more workers)



There are some kids that are hurting my daughter's self esteem. ... They make comments on her clothes not being nice enough or her taking so long to get a Nintendo DS and then not bringing it with her every day. ... But my kid has to learn to deal with the shallow people in the world at some point.



And when I was a kid, going to the same daycare center that I send my daughter to, we use to go on trips in the summer. Bowling, swimming, etc ... I was a bit disappointed when my daughter didn't get to do stuff like that this summer. But I'm sure they had their reasons. (money being tight, overprotective parents, or simply too many kids that )



</answer>



<answer from>



Johnny's Mommy
Member since: 04 March 2008
Total points: 14308 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I feel really fortunate that I've found such a great daycare for my son.



I really have no serious complaints.



One day, there was a 'substitute' teacher in my son's class and I walked in and heard Katy Perry's "I kissed a girl" song playing... Normally, they are listening to the "Farmer in the Dell" and "Old McDonald", etc... I wasn't too happy about that, but I didn't make a big deal out of it.



Other than that............ Not really anything.  I feel a little bad for my son right now, because he's still in the Newborn/Baby class and he's the oldest one in there... He's 1 year old and the closest other baby in age is like 7 months, so he's always wanting to go play with the big kids.... But they have a rule to not move Babies to the Toddler room until they are walking and he's not walking yet.  But I agree with their rule, so that's just something we are dealing with, LOL



</answer>

<question>



Sons schedule is all messed up due to daylight savings time?



he goes to bed an hour later (which is 8:00-- and was 8:00 before falling back an hour)... however hes waking up 2 hours earlier in the morning... has anyone else have this problem or had this problem.... what did you do to get him back on his schedule??



</question>



<answer from>



Christine M
Member since: 27 July 2007
Total points: 1685 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Got the same problem here.  This morning was the first morning since Saturday that I didn't have to get up at 4:30.  I would suggest that you continue with your regular schedule, he will catch up.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle
Member since: 03 March 2006
Total points: 6006 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I am just going with the flow. ... Instead of sending my daughter to bed at the new 8, I am putting her to bed at 7 something - moving it a little closer to 8 each night. Last night, she went to bed at 7:40pm. She woke up almost an hour early Monday and about 20 minutes early today. I think she'll be back on track by the end of the week.



Also, for a week or 2 before we "spring forward", I set our alarm clocks a few minutes earlier each day so we get use to the new times before they get here.



We made up for the earlier bed time by doing half of her homework this morning before school.



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



Joleen's Mommy
Member since: 07 February 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



what's 4'cs?



</answer>



<answer from>



curious
Member since: 18 September 2006
Total points: 9220 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on your income & how many children you have.  Right now I watch someone who has 4C, & 4C covers 75% of their day car expenses.  Here's an estimate on what your household income needs to be less than in order to qualify for 4C:
Household size 3
annual income $31,765
Household size 4
annual income $38,203



</answer>



<answer from>



Hgjghhhgj G
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 141 (Level 1)

<answer from>



Obama won! Quit sulking! ♫

Total points: 1735 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



4C's a low income day care service in certain states. They go off of your income. Make an appt. and bring in 4 pay stubs to find out how much you'll pay. If you make very little it will be free.



Source(s):



Used it once



</answer>

<question>



6 y/o son vomited 3 times, has nausea, but no fever?



I had to go pick him up from school this morning because he threw up 3 times they said(all at the same time/in a row, I guess).
He's home now and has not gotten sick again, but he said his stomach still feels sick. No fever, he's resting right now and has been drinking water.
Is there anything else I can do for him? Anything I can give him to help with the nausea? I don't have any pepto, but I can get some if needed. Or anything else?
Thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



He just threw up again, it was the water he's been drinking...Rechecked his temp, it's now 100.5



</additional details>



<answer from>



T MAC™
Member since: 20 October 2008
Total points: 217 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



He just has a virus, or the stomach flu



</answer>



<answer from>



Christine M
Member since: 27 July 2007
Total points: 1685 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It sounds like something he ate.  If he has no diarrhea or fever, it probably isn't a virus.  I would continue to give him water and anything like toast or bananas that he may be able to keep down.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mozz
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 9856 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



If it's projectile, call his pedi right right away.  If not, consider what he ate (ie., all junk with no substance-food, or snuck halloween candy in his backpack).  Give him a piece of toast or saltine cracker for a little substance.  It'll alleviate some of that nausea.  Ride that out for an hour or two.  If he doesn't continue to vomit, you might be home free.  If he starts again, with or without a fever, you need to call a pedi (dehydration can land you in the ER).  Stay on top of fluids even if he doesn't feel like drinking (no milk).  Good luck :(



</answer>



<answer from>



pinkpigl...
Member since: 01 June 2007
Total points: 9375 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



He could nibble on crackers slowly.  They help absorb the acid in the stomach and calms things down.



</answer>



<answer from>



tararodr...
Member since: 09 May 2008
Total points: 471 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



i just took my 6 year old to the doctor yesterday for that exact reason. the doctor perscribed mylanta and told me to feed her crackers, applesauce and gatorade. today she was fine. doctor said a tummy bug was going around. anyway, for 6 years old, you might want to run to the store and buy a bottle of mylanta, and give him 2 tsp every 4 hours. thats what i did, and it worked. for the fever, i gave her tylonol cold, which is for fever, cough, and runny nose. she was all better today. poor little guy. give him hugs for me.



</answer>

<question>



Need Some Advice From All You Mamas Out There!!!?



Well---Saturday I will be 41 weeks pregnant & as of yesterday at my doctors appointment I am 1 cent. dilated,50 % effaced, & -1 station. The doctor asked me if I wanted to be induced this week or give it one more week to see if he makes his own appearance. Now I know labor & timing of the actual labor is unpredictable so I would like to hear some of your experiences(for peace of mind) with being induced just in case the little guy doesn't decide to come on his own!



</question>



<answer from>



mommy of 5
Member since: 13 October 2008

<answer from>



Emma's MumMum & 20 Weeks #2
Member since: 20 March 2008
Total points: 10767 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



If your only dialated one and you get induced, you will likely have a c section.  Recovery is worse, breastfeeding is harder, and you may have to have subsequent c sections.  I'd wait another week.  Lots of first babies come at 42 weeks.



</answer>



<answer from>



marlenek...
Member since: 24 May 2006
Total points: 8889 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



He will decide to come on his own, when he is ready. I would give it at least another week then if needed be induced. I was induced with my first, the day after she was due, but because he thought it was her butt he felt instead of the head. After she was born he said she could have waited a couple of weeks to come out. But she was healthy. My other two were natural and they came a week after the due dates.



</answer>



<answer from>



Lillyian's Mommy♥*~
Member since: 29 March 2007
Total points: 532 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was almost 41 weeks when  they finally induced me. My daughter didn't want to come out. When I went to the hospital to be induced I 1 cm dilated and that's it. Nothing else. I went in Monday night at about 7, and by 5:48 Tuesday Night I had my beautiful bundle of joy! I was induced with piticion(SP) and I also had a cervidal(makes your cervix dilate). But I didn't have any pain due to my doctor giving me an epidural 30 min, after they broke my water. I had about 30 min. of contractions and they were really bad, until I got the epidural. If you are really wanting your baby I would say go for it! He is fully developed and everything will be fine. The longer you wait the bigger he will get! Good Luck and Congrats!



Source(s):



Proud mommy to



Lillyian Camille D.O.B. 11/13/2007



</answer>



<answer from>



Landon's Mommy!
Member since: 21 August 2007
Total points: 2438 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced. It had good points and bad points. I really liked knowing when I was going to deliver, I got my hair cut, got a shower, went out to eat with my husband and family that was in town, had everything all packed up, and relaxed until I left for the hospital. That part was great. Actual labor was a nightmare. 17 hours, first epidural failed, second epidural dropped my BP to a dangerous lvl, it wore off at 8 cm. at 9cm my cervix swelled and my body wanted me to push but I couldn't so I spent about an hour trying my hardest not to push (worse part of the whole thing) then I got a fever right before my son was born so he came out with a fever and I didn't get to nurse right away b/c he had to go to the nursery. I did not have to have a c-section, and both me and my son were just fine, so everything ended up great, but if I had the choice again, I don't think I would induce. Either way you choose, you will have your baby soon!!!!



Edit- I was able to nurse later just fine. I was Almost diliated 1cm when they induced, I wasnt even all the way a 1.



</answer>



<answer from>



tessajan...
Member since: 24 June 2008
Total points: 3983 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have never been induced and carried my kids 42 and 41 weeks. Both my babies were huge (8 and 10 lbs) and I am little (heaviest weight before pregnancy 125  and always a size 4 or smaller). My best friend was induced and is planning to just let it go this time. It was terrible she said. My mother was induced twice and went natural once. She says that the pain was 10 times worse with the induction.



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle
Member since: 03 March 2006
Total points: 6066 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Unless your baby appears to be getting too big, I'd wait one more week and see how things are going.



I waited until my daughter was 1 week late to be induced. ... I guess the pain levels vary by person. Yes, it hurt, but through most of it I was more "extremely uncomfortable" than hurting.



I never made it past 4 cm and ended up having a c-section. That wasn't as bad as people told me it would be either. (although, i never had a natural birth experience to compare it to) The first 36 hours or so were exhausting. But I only ended up taking like 3 of the pain pills the doctor prescribed me. And those were after dumb moves like trying to get to my bedroom after my cousin left a piece of sheetrock in the doorway.



(I know this may be more info than you asked for. But people made me so scared of pain before my daughter was born! ... I did all that worrying for nothing and would like to help ease the minds of other mothers.)



</answer>



<answer from>



Tammy
Member since: 27 October 2008
Total points: 550 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with my first, and it was very painful. The doctor even told me (after wards) that inducing makes it more painful. I'd wait if I were you. Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



goingcra...
Member since: 27 July 2007
Total points: 3354 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I was induced with all three, actually with my third my water broke on it's own but I went for the pitocin. My first two labors were great. But my third was really painful. they kept on pumping up the pitocin. but I wasn't progressing that well. But if you are patient enough to wait then wait another week, if not go ahead for it. I have heard lots of stories that the contractions are harder with pitocin, for me that wasn't necessarily true, I think it hurt worse with my third because I was fighting the contractions and not relaxing with them. (yes it's possible). So if you can wait then go ahead, it's very rewarding being able to go into labor by yourself, that is something I was never able to completely do my self and I wish I had been able to.



</answer>

<question from>



:(
Member since: 12 February 2008
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Are my parents over protective? HELP!! How can I get more freedom?



I am 15 and my sister is 14



They will not allow me and my sister to go to the mall by ourselves, even if we stay together and bring a cellphone.



We are both homeschooled. My parents WILL NOT let me go to public school or anything.



If I want to ride my bike, I only get to ride on the part of the road where my parents can look out the window and see me.



I'm also not allowed to lock or close my room door unless I'm dressing.



Me and my sister are allowed to stay home alone TOGETHER (if that makes any sense) but only if my parents will be gone for a short amount of time, like 20-30 minutes. I am not allowed to stay home alone by myself.



These are only SOME of the things they do.



Are they overprotective?



If so, how can I make them give me some freedom?



I know they do this because they care about me, but I want to be able to look back at my childhood and remember having freedom and fun. I dont want to look back and remember having a boring and sheltered life.



PLEASE HELP!!
Thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Mozz
Member since: 09 January 2008
Total points: 9885 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



I was raised the exact same way (cept there were no cell phones).  Yes it's overprotective.  I have news though, it's not likely to change.  They're not trying to be mean they believe it's the best thing for you.  What I mean is, reasoning with them or changing your behavior isn't likely to change their minds.  You sound like a good kid already.  You are me 20 years later :(  Got to stick it out and keep focus on adulthood.  My problems lasted long after 18 (adult).  It was one of those "as long as you live under my roof" things.  I had a curfew at 22, and they had no problems taking my car keys away or limiting the phone.  I'm really sorry I don't have better news for you.  They're still good people, you wont grow up to hate them.  Resent them maybe, for a while.  But you'll never lose the love you have.  You'll just understand better why they did it, even if it was over the top.



</answer>



<answer from>



Claire Williams
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 170 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'd say they are way to over protective!



When I was young my parents let me do anything I wanted basically, they believed that I should learn from my mistakes and find my own way in the world. Im now 23 and have been independant since about the age of 16. I found I grew up really quickly and was really mature by te age of 17. I couldn't wait to move out and go to uni!



I'd say.. talk to them, tell them how you feel and get them to talk to other parents, because their more likely to consider a bit more freedom if all the other parents are like that.



Good luck :)



</answer>



<answer from>



The One and Only CHAPNIS!
Member since: 20 September 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>

its up to you



</answer>



<answer from>



rmoore_6...

<answer>



Well, it does sound like they are slightly overprotective.  It's good that you realize that they are concerned for your safety.  With that said I would sit down with them and try to work out some sort of a plan where you can get a little freedom.  Ask if you and your sister can go to the mall during the day and only for a small amt of time to start out with. <question>



What toy does your 1 year old play with most?



My son will be turning 1 in a month and everyone is asking for gift ideas for his 1st birthday.  What are some good toys that your 1 year old loves to play with?



</question>



<answer from>



onetuffg...
Member since: 05 April 2007
Total points: 203 (Level 1)



</answer from>

<answer>



We bought a changing table but ended up making our dining room buffet our changing station since it was on our main floor.



I loved all the items like pack and play, exersaucers, bassinette, bouncy seat, swing... but they are really only useful for a few weeks or couple of months at best.  The pack and play is helpful if you travel.  I had sold all my stuff at a garage sale and then turned up preggo with #3.. so I borrowed all that stuff from other moms and it worked out fine.  Plus, it does make for a 'greener' earth ..



</answer>



<answer from>



Ellie04
Member since: 21 August 2006
Total points: 12425 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Clothes - especially newborn clothes. He outgrew them so fast and I ended up getting a ton as gifts. Most still had the tags on when he outgrew them.



Swing - He HATED it...but I think he was kind of an exception to the rule. Most babies love them...but I would suggest buying all that kind of stuff used because they use it for such a short amount of time.



Stroller - $300 wasted...its been used twice. But again we might be an exception. I prefer to wear him in a sling. The stroller is just too bulky for me to lug around. If anything I would suggest an umbrella stroller for when baby gets older and a sling or front carrier for when baby is still small.



Diaper Genie - a regular garbage changed daily works just as well and you don't need to keep buying refills.



Receiving blankets - he liked being swaddled for about a day and then I was stuck with dozens of little blankets that I couldn't do anything with.



Newborn shoes - baby doesn't need shoes until they are walking outside. Before that it is just a pain to keep them on and bad for baby's feet.



Pack and Play - we have yet to take ours out of the box and baby is 11 months. We bought it for traveling, but found that when we travel it is easier just to let baby sleep with us.



</answer>



<answer from>



Laura
Member since: 18 October 2008
Total points: 2248 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think the thing I hear people regretting splurging on the most is stuff like clothing.  You are much better off borrowing cloths from friends who have kids that out-grew the stuff.



</answer>



<answer from>



Racheal loves Holio

<answer>



Yeah there are three things i wished i wouldn't have bought:



1. play pen - my son hated it and i just throw his toys in it and used it as a toy box.. it was a pretty expensive toy box!!! lmfao



2.  bassinet - Not one time did he sleep in it.. but he slept with me also, because i was scared something would happen to him..



3.  so many clothes - he had some many clothes that we bought and everyone else that there was so many outfits with tags still on them.. lol



That is just me though.. you might would love a bassinet (my sister loved hers)  but i had no use for one where my son slept with me when he was a newborn.



----------------



Trust me.. you need a stroller..  not a $300 one like that woman said.. but when you go to the mall or go grocery shopping, you need one!!



and get as many recieving blankets as you can!!  they are mainly used for when your baby spits up and stuff.. and after my son outgrew his, i used them to clean with.. they make great dusting rags.. lol



</answer>



<answer from>



Michelle
Member since: 03 March 2006
Total points: 6066 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wish we didn't get a swing for my daughter. It took up space and was rarely used. Luckily, we got it used from my cousin for $80 instead of spending the whole $200 or whatever it was new.



I also wish I hadn't been in such a hurry to get a playpen. ... I got a pretty cheap, basic one that was barely used. Then my cousin sold me one of those 3 in 1 deals that's a playpen, a changing table, and a bassinet. ... I got a lot of use out of that one! Will definitely save up for a nice playpen the next time around.



My mom spent quite a bit of money on a nice high chair. But once again, it was in the way more than it was used. ... It did come in handy a few times :) But more often I found it easier to strap my kid in her car seat, hold her in my lap, or put her in the travel high chair we had. (it could be strapped to a regular chair or just used on the floor)



Too many pacifiers and too many newborn size diapers! While my daughter did enjoy the pacifiers, I still feel that we got too many before she was born. And she outgrew the newborn size diapers before she used half of 'em.



We really didn't get many (if any) toys before Cheyenne was born. ... Friends and relatives gave us a few small things including a mobile to go over her crib. For toys, I waited until I got to know her and started picking up little things here and there.



While it wasn't a problem for me, you have to be careful if buying used cribs. Make sure they are sturdy and the sides go up and down as they should.



Oh yeah, I did regret the new breast pump (OUCH! That thing hurt - I only used it twice) and I regretted the cheap baby monitor (walky talky like things) that I chose. You should probably look up reviews somewhere like amazon.com before choosing them.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ktloop
Member since: 18 August 2007

<answer>



We actually had two great baby showers and we really didn't have to buy anything.  I did buy a car seat way early in the pregnancy.  The only thing we could have done without was a day/night bottle warmer.  It's good for breast milk fed babies but the microwave was faster at warming the water for his bottles.



Yes I agree buy items used.  As I learned my kid only use certain items for a short while so I started browsing craigslist.org and found tone of items there.  I got my hands on a brand new car seat for my other car for half the price I paid for the first one.



Now that my son is 6 months I wish I purchased a convertible car seat instead of the infant carrier.  It's getting cold here and I got him a coat but he looks stuffed in the carrier and its difficult to buckle him in.  Now I have to either get a convertible car seat so he is comfortable or purchase a bundle me fleece thing so he I don't need to put a coat on him just to go from the house to car then into another building.  If I get the bundle me then I will have to take the carrier out of the car all the time.



I also use non-brand named formula and now walmart/target brand diapers.  I am starting to make my own baby food too so that will save me some money there.



I suggest whatever you buy, keep the receipt.  Your child may never use/wear something so you may want to take it back and get something else.



This was a very good question.



</answer>

<answer>

<answer>



I am done....but I just have one child and did not buy her that much as she will get lots from everyone.  Everyone loves my peanut butter fudge:
3 cups sugar
1 stick butter
5 oz can evaporated milk
1/2 jar pb?
1 teaspoon vanilla
small jar marshmallow cream



Combine sugar, butter, milk on medium heat.  Stir constantly until it boils.  Let boil about 4 mintues.  Add peanut butter, marshmallow cream, and vanilla.  Pour into a 9 x 13 or 2 round cake pans that have been well buttered.  Let cool.



</answer>

<question>



What would you think of your kid of who you've wanted to ruin their present teenage life,..?



,..such as by either verbally abusing them by telling them that they won't amount to anything or calling them stupid, or ruin their chances with getting girls by sending them to military school, or do the same by sending them to a boarding or private school, or whatever mean thing you've done to them in their teenage life,..



NOW, what if years later after they've grown up, they got all the action with women they wanted despite you trying to ruin their chances when they were teens, and they became successful, in fact, they became even more successful than you, and they confront you and remind you of the painful crap that you put them through when they were teenagers and say to you,



"HA, I proved you wrong!"



Would you feel bad about how you treated years ago?
Would you finally have some damn respect for them?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm too old to be a teen but too young to be some 40 year old something parent of a high school kid, I'm in the middle so I'm too old to be one and too young to be the other.



I'm right in the middle of that age difference between the high school kid and the parent, so I'm just wondering the thoughts of both ages.

<answer>



My father, when I was a 14 year old virgin, called me a **** because I had acne. He is a very detached and cold man. At times, he can be nice, though. (weird but true) I haven't seen him for many years and it is me who makes the contact and me who drives the 6 hours to see him. In my opinion, I think that it has to do with many things-



like how the parents were raised
how young they were when they had the child(ren)
was the pregnancy unplanned
etc. etc.
Sometimes, parents may have some resentment for their children. Maybe they grew up too fast and they look at their child as someone they are competing with, instead of someone that should be a role model. Did the parents drink or use drugs? this is a big factor.



I don't think that a child will be sent to military school so that they don't get any "action" . That is, unless the teen were sleeping with multiple partners and was bound to catch a disease or something.



As for the parent feeling bad about the treatment, I would have to say for the most part that even if they did feel bad, they won't admit it. When a parent calls a child stupid, I believe that the moment it comes out of their mouth, they feel bad.



Now, if this child is you or a friend of yours, please just try to move on. I'm sure your parents have.  When you ( or whomever you are talking about) have children of your own, just make sure you treat them different than how you got treated.

daughter of a mean man and a mom of 2 kids that probably think I am mean.

<question>



When do you take your kids to the hospital?



Please tell me all symptoms that would result in your taking your child to the hospital.
Ex, vomiting/diarhea- for how long?
fever- what temp, for how long?
etc.



</question>



<answer from>



JEAN W
Member since: 27 January 2007
Total points: 1096 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



as long as they dont feel well i am taking them to the doctor or the hospital, they cannot really explain how they feel and whats wrong with them so i will be very cautious. and run with them



</answer>



<asker's comment>



THANK YOU!!!! I agree, I would rather get told, "they are fine, go home" than sit at home and wish I'd gone.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Due with #2 June 09
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 6068 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



If she had diarrhea/vomiting and wasn't eating for a couple of days, and had a decrease in wet diapers.
Fever over 101 for over a couple of days.
Signs of ear infection.
Difficulty breathing not helped by inhaler.
Seizure or rapid, shallow breathing for prolonged period of time (an hour or more with other signs of distress).



And of course any serious injury or accident (serious fall, etc.).  Thankfully, we haven't had to deal with this yet!



I would first try to contact my doctor/nurse practitioner or call TeleHealth (Canada has a phone number where you can speak to a nurse practitioner 24/7 but they usually tell you to go to the hospital unless it's something minor to cover their butts) before going to emerg, but if it was the middle of the night or after hours, I would go to emerg.



</answer>



<answer from>



beetlemi...
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 15247 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Special Education



Toddler & Preschooler



</answer from>



<answer>



acute pain, lethargy, dehydration, confusion, change in mental status, vomiting for more than 24 hours and unable to keep down syringed 5cc pedialyte q'10min., diarrhea when dehydration symptoms aren't manageable i.e. no urine output &gt; q'8h, more quickly the younger the child.  Temp. going in when change of mental status, &gt;104*F, or at 104 but not responding to antipyretics or a febrile seizure.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 08 March 2007

<answer>



I check my children's symptoms with this website- http://www.seattlechildrens.org/child_he...  and follow the guidelines stated. Except for stuff I immediately know is an emergency (fever over 104, wounds needing stitches, serious head wounds, broken limbs, etc.) then I just pack 'em up and head on in to the ER.



</answer>

<answer>



Vomiting/runs- over 3 days with no improvement
Fever 105+ - immediately, otherwise I see if I can bring it down.
or fever 101+ over 2 days and nothing works
Difficulty breathing



That's all we've dealt with so far. My 16 month old has asthma though, so that's what we usually go for, and that works like this; No matter what level of attack, I immediately start treatment with Albuterol in her nebulizer. If 2 stacked treatments don't work, we go to ER.



</answer>

<answer>



I would say for more than 2 or 3 days. However, if the fever reaches temps of 104 or above you need to take them right away. Kids react different to adults for common colds and tend to vomit, so if this has been going on for a day or two with low temps wait it out. If it lasts longer than that, it could be a bacterial infection and you should take them just to be safe.



</answer>

<question>



Would you ever consider taking in a "friends" kids as foster kids?  How do you think that would work out?



I am slightly considering taking in a 9 yr old boy and a 5 yr old girl as foster kids.  My daughter is 5 and my son is 8, so it would almost be like 2 sets of older twins.  The kids have been pretty good friends for over 5 years & the mom (a friend of my husbands from way back) has got herself into some trouble.  She's on drugs and has not been caring properly for her kids for the past year or more.  She's always dropping them off here and there and disappearing for days or weeks at a time.  She got kicked out of her trailer over a month ago and has been living out of her car & letting her kids stay wherever they can.  Right now they are at their grandparents house, but I don't think that's going to be permanent.  They haven't been in school for over a month & their school keeps calling me asking if I know where the kids are.  I just found out today.  I just don't know how it would be since she is a "friend" of my husband and her brother and my husband are pretty good friends too.  As far as her wanting to come visit them whenever she wanted....being an old friend....how would I set boundaries.  Would you even consider doing something like that?



</question>

Wow, good point Katie!!  I'm only slightly considering it??  My husband will probably never go for it anyway.  I just feel so bad for those kids being shifted around & if they came to live with me, at least they would feel comfortable and safe.

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



I see Katie's point, but at the same time, I'd rather these kids be exposed to positive role models and family structures/values.  If you've already instilled these things in your own children, healthy discussions about the differences between your family and these kids' ought to keep your own kids from picking up negative behaviors/attitudes.



I had some students in my class one year who were good friends, but one mom didn't like her son going to the other's house b/c she didn't like their family values (or lack thereof, lol).  So instead of letting her son go over there, she was happy to invite her son's friend over to her house.  She liked the idea of him being exposed to their values and knew she could keep an eye on her own son at the same time.



As for the actual undertaking of such a large endeavor, my heart would totally be in the same place yours is in.  I know that if it weren't for my husband and his stubbornness, I would have a house full of foster kids from my school.  I think the kids who are a little older are the ones who are most critical.  They're at the cusp of falling into the same bad lifestyle, and if given the right direction, love, and support, they could change.  Talk with your husband about it, and if he's at least open to the idea, you should call your local DSS and see if they have some information on what foster families should know.  Maybe you could even talk with some other foster families in the area.  I do know from my own experience as a teacher that having the mom come over should be during scheduled visits.  The kids should be in counseling the entire time, at school and with an outside professional.



Best of luck with your decision!



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



That would be a life changing tough situation, you are going to have to do a lot of talking with your husband and really do what your heart tells you is the right thing to do . As far as the mothers rights are concerned I think the State will help you in all of the legal areas .



Good Luck and no matter what your decision you should be commended for considering this move.



</answer>

<answer>



I think you need to become a better parent! sorry but your child learns from you, perhaps your lack of discipline may have something to do it.



Could also be out of attention. Even bad attention is better than no attention. Talk to your kid - he is 10 and you should be able to have a conversation with him. Try to spend alone time with each one during the week. Even if it is a quick drive to the shops and a milkshake or something.



Seems like it is all down to a lack of parenting from you. No offence - but this site isn't called "tip toe around the problem". Sometimes we need someone to come straight out and say it. Also, get help from other people, family, friends, doctors etc.



And also, dont put your 10 year old in those situations - you are asking for trouble. It is like you are giving him a container of fuel and a match and saying "here you go darling".



</answer>

<answer>



People say mean things when they argue, so don't take his comments personally. As far as your husband goes, I would try to talk to him later on when you're both calmed down.  Gently tell him how you feel and why you are upset.



It sounds like you are so over-burdened with having to take care of the kids all the time that it's taking a serious toll on you emotionally.  Hell, I would have a couple of glasses of wine too!  I would suggest just relaxing and enjoying your kids, even with their difficulties.  I think it's good to have children with ADHD on a good schedule- nothing wrong with that.  But you might feel a lot better if you stopped trying to control some things and just "let it go."



Maybe don't worry about having the house perfectly clean?  When the kids are acting up, instead of letting it turn into a big ordeal, take a time out for yourself and think, "Is it really worth the battle this time, or can I be more flexible with them?"



Also, when your husband is with them, just let them do thier own thing together (besides letting them stay up late).
Kids suffer a great deal when their mom is stressed out, so focus on taking care of yourself whenever you can.



</answer>

<answer>



I know everyone hates the self help books but this one really worked for us and my husband even put some effort into reading (well listening to it because I ordered the CD for him to listen to while in drove back and forth to work).  It's called Love & Respect, The Love She Most Desires and The Respects He Desperately Needs by Dr. Emerson Eggerichs.  We have been married for 19 years and I learned things about my husband I never knew.  He also learned about my needs.  You can get it with a work book but we never did the work.  When we both were in the car we would listen to it together and I often found myself asking him....is such and such true for you too?  And he the same.  Also nothings wrong with having drinks but maybe while you guys are working through this you both should pull back.  Drinking intensifies the emotions and things are pulled out of perspective.  If you want to use the book or CD bring it to him in a way that you want to learn more about his needs and it would help if he read or listened to it with you so that he can comment.  Don't throw a marriage away.  It's a lot of work but no one said it would be easy.  Down the road after you've worked through all the ups and downs (trust me there will be more) you will see how each time it gets a little easier and how it all was worth it.



</answer>

<question>



To parents who'd ever lost a child, had anyone ever told you that your loss was "easier" than theirs?



First of all, I'm sorry for your loss, and I'm sorry if I remind you of that now.
But I've had people actually saying things like, "Your loss is nothing compared to (someone else), because of (this and that)."
They think that losing a child at younger age is "easier" than older, or when the child had been ill, it's "easier" because you are prepared, compare to those who had accidents, etc.



Personally, I don't see the difference. You lost a loved one, you grieve.
I don't think it's appropriate to tell someone that their loss was an "easy" one.
What do you think?



</question>



<additional details>



I didn't lost mine recently. It's in the past (I've lost two).
Now I have a beautiful healthy 1 year old, who makes my life so much better.



</additional details>

It is NEVER easy to lose someone you love. never.

Heather J
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 600 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My son was three weeks past his 6th birthday when he died after battling leukaemia for 7 months.



People said all sorts of stupid, thoughtless and sometimes quite nasty things to me during his illness and since his death.



One example was while we were in hospital.  The grandparents of a 6 week old who was having treatment at the same times as James said to me, 'It's easier for you because you have got to know your child and spent time with him.  We have hardly got to know Ellie'.



Ellie had one of the commonest types of leukaemia with a success rate of survival at 80%.  James had JMML with a survival prognosis of less than 50%.



I have also had all the 'God needed him' and 'he is in a better place' comments (I need him more than God and there is no better place for my son to be than with me)



I think the worst one was 'Well at least you still have Erin'. (Oh goody, I still have one child left, better not complain)



James died in January 2004.  Even after nearly 5 years I'm still grieving.  You don't get 'over it', you just find ways to 'deal with it' day to day.



</answer>



<answer from>



Hayley France
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 1535 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Oh, I'm so sorry for your loss.



I agree with you! I've never lost a child that was already born but my husband and I are desperate for a baby and have suffered four miscarriage...when we were in the hospital loosing the third baby I was whacked in a room on the maternity ward so I could hear happy new parents coming and going with their babies and I was dealt with by a heavily pregnant nurse. She looked me in the eye while I was crying and said "It's not so bad, you're young." I'm sure she was only trying to comfort me but I was tempted to punch her in the stomach and then scream "How do you like it? Don't worry you'll get another chance to make a new one!" (I feel awful about that now...)



I hate the way people think that because I'm young I wont be as affected by miscarriage as somebody who's older...



</answer>

mommy & wife due w/ #2 March 27

cathrl69

</answer from>



<answer>



I think one thing you do need to remember is that nobody's perfect. No, it's not remotely appropriate to tell someone that their loss was an "easy" one. But, when you're in that situation, you don't know what to say to a grieving parent, and you are desperately trying to say the right thing, it's dead easy for something to come out appallingly wrong. How _do_ you try to comfort someone in that sort of situation? I don't know. But I can easily imagine someone trying to gently help someone to see that their life isn't all bad, that maybe some of the things that happened were as good as they could have been in the situation, and it coming out horribly wrong.



And I'm sorry for anyone who's been in this situation too. I just know how often I open my mouth even in everyday situations and what comes out has a secondary meaning which is nothing like what I'd intended the person I was talking to to get from it.



</answer>

<question>



Hello to all parents of school age children--have  you ever felt overwhelmed by the demands of your dog?



I am asking this in the parenting section because I recently asked the same Q. in the Pets &gt; dogs section and they raked me over the coals!!(I feel most of then were not parents of HUMAN children who said nasty things!)Anyway,we adopted a 7 month old puppy 6 weeks ago.He's a Lab mix,and I knew he'd be a challenge...I just did not realize how all consuming caring for him would be.I have 4 kids--3 are teens and my youngest is a mildly autistic 9 year old boy.I purposely waited to even adopt a dog until my children were much older,so that I would be able to take care of the pet,get help from them,etc..This pup barks so much,needs so much attention,etc...that I am really worn out.The barking also REALLY bothers my special needs son.My next door neighbor used to be a dog trainer and has been helping,but the pup is feisty!!
I was wondering if any parents out there ever felt similarly after bringing a dog into the home.
There are days when I think that 're-homing' him may be what is best...but I know my children would be very,very sad if that happened.(Especially my 13 year old son,who is most attached to the pup.)
Thanks in advance for any advice.



</question>



<additional details>



I would never had adopted a dog when my children were babies.I feel that my biggest  mistake was to adopt an untrained puppy instead of a trained adult dog:-(



</additional details>

<answer>



My 5 year old daughter would love a dog but I understand the commitment they are and I am not prepared to make it.  Along with the fact that I am in rental housing so not possible.  I am one of those people who can't stand dog dirt on the pavement but yet know I couldn't poop and scoop so wouldn't take the responsiblity.  If you are prepared to take that responsibility and continue then I think pets are very important to children.  They teach responsibility and they provide comfort and a confidante to them.  This will be very important to your 13 year old.



As for your 9 year old I can understand your upset that it is upsetting him.  Can you find a way to cope?  What does you dog handling neighbour say - do they think things will improve and if so how much and how soon?  There is the problem that if you get rid of the dog because of your 9 year old your 13 year old may end up resenting you and the 9 year old.



A lab is a working dog so because of that is hard work but can be well trained I would have thought.  I would talk to your neighbour more and try and persevere but I understand how stressed you must be.



Personally I like cats - but that is not much help to you is it - LOL.  Keep going if you are following the training it is possible to get a obedient well behaved dog and a loving pet for your children.
