<answer from>



rachel
Member since: 19 March 2006
Total points: 29360 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



I got my puppy at 4 months and really that first 12 months was just about surviving. Re housing is not really fair on the dog. You are already at least it's 2 home. What you may have is a dog who needs more company, As we speak I have my friends 10 month old lab running around the back yard with my dog. I am off to work soon and my friend is at work. So it works for both of us. They keep each other company and wear each other out. My dog has settled so much since we started doing this. It has been over a week since I got him (things got a bit hectic and it was due to rain. i won't get him in the rain as he gets all wet, dirty and stinky then I have to put him in the car to take home lol) and my dogs behaviour has gotton a bit baughty again. I just went and got this other dog and I know she will be more settled.



I am not saying to buy another dog but do you have a friend with a similar age dog that could "come to play'? The barking could be a bored thing (does he get walked enough?) or it could be a stress thing. Talk to your vet on options. I would never ever use the electric shock collar but there is one that the dog wears and when he barks it gives out a spray of some natural scent that dogs don't like. It does not hurt them (unlike the electric one , which the owners should be made wear for a day, if they use them) but discourages barking. Labs are puppies for the first couple of years so he will settle. Continue with the training and work out a roster for your kids to take him for a run morning and night. This will help wear him out.
Good luck, it will improve.



</answer>



<answer from>



Dr. Diagnonsense
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 21058 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



What “nasty” things might they have said? I have a feeling it was more like “Why did you get a puppy when you don’t have time to deal with one?” Puppies are full-time jobs in themselves. Like little kids, they need a ton of discipline. An adult  shelter dog would have been a far better choice in your situation.



Get your dog in obedience school if you’re not familiar with basic training techniques. If your kids want to keep the dog so bad, make that dog their responsibility. They need to learn the training techniques and use them, and they need to be walking him DAILY. One of the biggest mistakes dog owners make is that they fail to realize the value of exercise. It’s not optional if you want a happy, well behaved pet.



</answer>



<answer from>



GOING ON 3 IM BRILLIANT ME 7
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3467 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



you might need to re-home him. i would do some research. some dogs are more dependent on humans than others, hence the consistant barking, hyperness etc.



i have had all sorts of dogs-boxers, labs rotweillers, sharpeis etc. they are all sweet and i loved them, but the best type i had was a boxer. the lab that i had, was very hyper,and alot of them are known to bark. if you have already taken measures for professional training (if you can afford it-it is ridiculous expensive!) you might have to look into a different type of pet. a lizard, cat, gerbil & hampsters, even exotic. dogs are high maintenence, period. i haven't had a dog in 5 years due to that. i want one bad, and i know my kids will love it, but if i can't give the dog what he needs, then there is no reason for him to be there.. your idea of an older dog might work also. they are already trained and if you get the right breed, very adaptable.



you have to look at your autisitc sons needs too-if the barking bothers him to the point that he reacts about it, that is bad news. i am familiar with autistic children and i see where you are coming from. a more docile and calm pet might be the answer for him. the kids may be attached, but you are the adult and the boss. you need to do what is best for your family and the dog. not just the kids' upset when you give the dog up.they will get over it, and it might be better to plan a day to give the dog up and get another type of pet.



</answer>



<answer from>



Denise G
Member since: 25 January 2007
Total points: 7222 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Okay, let's put this in perspective.  You have FOUR children, one with special needs.  I think you are perfectly capable of handling a dog!  I know it is frustrating, I know it can wear on your patience, but if you give it time and don't give up, you will really be rewarded for it!



We got a dog many years ago- she was the most difficult dog I had ever been around.  I wanted to take her back to the pound.  It took over 8 months, but eventually she got better and now she's great.



I don't have kids yet (i'm 38 weeks pregnant) and I have 2 dogs.  I know it is going to be difficult, but they are a part of the family.



I say give it some time, keep working with your trainer and learn to laugh about how difficult it can be.  Dogs are great companions!



</answer>

<answer from>



Kath
Member since: 16 March 2008
Total points: 516 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You are allowing her to be the leader. you need to step up and show some real leadership. It sounds silly but I watch Cesar Milan's "The Dog Whisperer" and it has actually helped me understand the psychology of a pack (family) more. I know the show is about dogs, but read between the lines and the same applies for parenting.



Exercise, Discipline and then Affection. She sounds like she has too much energy, not enough discipline and far too much affection.



By saying this, my kids still get heaps of hugs and kisses - but only when appropriate and when they have "earnt" them. It works for me. If I tell my 5 year old daughter to do something - she does it no questions asked. She knows the reward is a big cuddle and kiss which is better than saying "here you go darling, have your t.v back now".



</answer>

<answer>



Your first selection or both in the same dress.  The first selection the same but a little different but with the solid colored shirts does not clash.  The second selection, the plaid skirt on the one outfit and the plaid shirt on the other outfit are different and clash. The dress is really pretty and would be really cute if they matched.  So I pick either the first, if you want a more casual picture or the dress for both if you want a more formal picture.  Hope that helps!

<question from>



Helen S
Member since: 06 June 2008
Total points: 266 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How can you support a child's communication in bi or multi lingual enviroments.?



how to support Development of both/all languages and how not to confuse the child



</question>



<answer from>



Ariana
Member since: 15 February 2008
Total points: 3395 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well you pose a great question. Im actually on that situation... we're canadians and my oldest daughter is attending a french immersion school she's in SK but she wont have any English teaching till grade 2!



We speak English at home and she writes in English and think in English but her reading skills have slowed down dramatically. Last year she was able to do a great amount of reading and now this year she's even having trouble reading "easy " words.



So Im not sure, I guess it takes some time for the kids to live in tha bilingual world for a bit, till they learn how to fully separate one language from the other. But it will take time, and I dont think they're confused, my daughter certainly isnt, she's just paying much more attention to one language than the other, for a while.



Source(s):



Mom of Isabella 5.5, Matthew 4 and Gabriella 21 mos



http://answers.yahoo.com/question/index;...



</answer>



<answer from>



Brody's Mommy
Member since: 02 December 2007
Total points: 3815 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Babies will learn both languages as it is natural to them, if they are around both.
The same way a child learns english, they will learn spanish.
It just comes easy to them as their brains are developing.



My son goes to a home daycare, where they caretakers only speak spanish, so he is talked to, read to, sung to, in spanish all day long.
And then while I am with him, I can only speak english so I speak in all english.
He will learn both and speak both.



</answer>



<answer from>



Gumdrop Girl
Member since: 21 March 2006
Total points: 35830 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



This is a question only a monoglot could ask.



Don't underestimate a child's capacity to understand his or her environment. Kids pick up things quickly. They are the epitome of near-total ignorance, but near-infinite intelligence. By that, I mean they might have the answers right off the tops of their heads, but whatever info you throw at them will get absorbed and processed until it's eventually understood.



I wouldn't throw differential equations at the kid, but i wouldn't hesitate to try to immerse him or her in more than one language.



Children put the use of language into context, meaning if they see one group of people, they figure out that they use this particular language (i.e., English). But if they recognize a certain other group of people, like relatives, they know to use thier other language.



English wasn't spoken in my home -- my parents wanted to make damn sure I was bilingual. I started out learning English from the TV. Learned the rest -- and used it -- at school. But once I got home, I had to switch lingos.



And guess what! I was never confused. I might also add that I grew to be more adept in English than many of my solely-Anglophonic peers.



Anyway, what I'd recommend is immersion. The kid will pick up the local language from his or her environment. You provide the rest of the language-building instruction.



</answer>



<answer from>



desathom...
Member since: 25 October 2008
Total points: 316 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I have Swiss friends who had this situation. They speak German and English. When they came to stay near us for a period of time, they were in an all English environment but spoke German in their home.



Their kids were just at learning to speak age and ended up learning to speak English because of playing with the English kids. Yet they were also learning German at home and understood it. The parents noticed that when the kids were in 'play mode' they spoke English as this is the context they learned it in.



When they moved back to Switzerland, they ended up in an exclusively French speaking community. They didn't want the kids to lose the English, so they decided to alternate the languages they spoke daily. One day they spoke English, the next they spoke German.



Then they also started sitting down and teaching their kids French and taking them to the park often so they can play with French speaking kids.



There were moments where the kids would speak sentences with some English and some German, but as they learn the language better they will learn to separate them. I think the key is to 'isolate' only one language for a small period of time. I imagine if you speak 3 sentences to them in three different languages, it will take them much longer to learn the difference.



Kids pick up things shockingly fast though! Not sure if that helped :o)



</answer>

<question from>



Heidi's Mummy
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 5812 (Level 5)



</question from>



<question>



What is wrong with my daughter?



She's 18 months, she's not walking but she will crawl over to me and grab onto somthing pulling herself onto her knees and either rock or bounce like that or put one foot flat on the floor (like she's about to propose) but nothing more, she's not trying to pull up to stand.  She will stand if you hold her hands or her torso and she will take a couple of steps towards you, lately when I stand her up on the seat next to me on the bus she has started to move her feet into a more comfortable position. She should be walking at 18 months, surely - I know her daddy's side of the family were all late walkers between 18 months to 2 years and she's very tall, but I was 11 months when i was walking.



She only says two words, mamma and Dadda. She's only just come out of the cooing and screeching stage to start 'babbling' but she doesn't know the words for anything, even though I've spent hour upon hour with her showing her things and saying 'ball', 'nose' 'teddy' 'dolly' etc.  And she doesn't make the connection for anything, like if I ask her 'where's your nose?' and point at her nose and then mine, she doesn't point at her nose, even though I've been doing that for months.



She will finger feed but she will only put a loaded spoon in her mouth if I load it and give it to her.



She doesn't point at things she wants, she doesnt hand things to me. She doesn't make the sign for 'all done' even though I've been doing that for months. She's never waved goodbye, even though we do it every day when dropping her off at nursery and picking her up.



The other day, she was playing with her giraffe, it's a thing with a hole in the top that you drop a brick through and it then sings a little song as the brick comes out, so whe was putting the bricks in the hole waiting for them to come out then clapping when the music came on, so sometimes she does things and really surprises me.



I went to a party at the weekend for Hallowe'en, and it really brought it home to me, the other children who are around the same age, where walking, talking (the odd word, but still) pointing at things and handing things to their parents.  They all looked 18 months old, and Heidi looked like she was 12 months old.



I can't sleep properly worrying and I'm not eating because of it, we're gonig to the doctors on Thursday, but I'm scared to death she's got autism or has learning difficulties, or god forbid something really serious.



Has anyone else experienced their children being really late starters? If so can you share your experiences.



</question>



<answer from>



LisaHW
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 18909 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Since you're seeing the doctor that's the main thing, and I don't feel the least bit comfortable making remarks on this question.  Still, I can imagine how worried you are.



If her father didn't walk until 18 months that's something to keep in mind.  As far as speech goes, many toddlers don't say much of anything until they're two or so, and then they just start talking.



I do know a little girl who was kind of an across-the-board late-bloomer, as her mother was; and the doctor referred the mother to a therapist who would show her how to do exercises with the little girl to encourage her development.



Don't forget, too, she could have something like a couple of different things (a late-blooming father and something like a hearing problem, for example).



I saw a program on identifying Autism in one-year-old babies, and it was showing how the babies did not make much eye contact or otherwise seem tuned in to their mothers (at least to the degree that non-Autistic babies were).  If, by any chance, your little girl had even mild Autism getting it diagnosed early is important, because children who are diagnosed early can be treated quite successfully.  That's something to keep in mind too.



It is said that Mozart didn't talk until he was four years old, and I think something similar is said about Einstein.  Also, on www.askdrsears.com (a reputable child development site) it is mentioned that early walking isn't necessarily a sign of a child's being particularly (in their words) "thoughtful" (they are being polite).  So, between all those things, walking late is not necessarily a sign of limited intellectual capacity.



Try to keep in mind that if she has some developmental delay that needs addressing she'll be getting the help she needs.  There's a good chance, though, she's just not in a hurry to do some things.  Try to relax.  If it turns out to be something to address you'll address it.  That's what parents do.



Sincerest best wishes that there's no problems (or only minor ones if there are any).



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thank you, your kind words have really helped me.



Kez x



</asker's comment>

<question from>



missymou...
Member since: 13 September 2006
Total points: 1299 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Do you know how Leukaemia affects a family?



My daughter Mia was diagnosed with leukaemia in September, just 1 week before her 3rd birthday. I was totally shocked and cannot believe how poor my knowledge of childhood leukaemia was. so I am writing her leukaemia diary at www.everybodylovesmia.co.uk and am welcoming visitors who are keen to raise awareness or learn a bit more about this cancer and the effect on family life. There is also a group on facebook under exactly the same name so please join up and spread the word. Thank you XXX



</question>

<answer>



I know.



My son, James, was diagnosed with Juvenile Mylomonocytic Leukaemia when he was five and a half years old.



He had a BMT in November 2003 but it failed and he died January 15th 2004 shortly after his 6th birthday and 4 weeks after the birth of his new baby sister.



Nobody will understand what you are going through and keeping a blog is an excellent idea.  I always thought of it as a way of 'downloading my brain' as there was such a mess of thoughts and emotions in there.



I have a website for James but tend not to post the link to it publicly.  Shockingly there are a lot of nasty people in the world who take pleasure in being abusive to families in crisis.  I will send you the link privately though.



</answer>

Curfew

Make Up
Internet

Cell phone & texting

HooKooDo...
Member since: 12 September 2007
Total points: 13080 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy

</answer from>



<answer>



No boys in the house alone behind closed doors.
No smoking in my house (and if your cloths smell of smoke, you wash them).
No going over the limit on cell phone expenses (if I'm paying the cell phone bill).
No driving under the influence, or you loose the car (assuming I'm the legal owner).



Otherwise, at 19, they are an adult.  You can mostly only hope that you've raised them well.  Beyond that, at that age, the only athority you realistically have over them is what behaviors are and are not tollerated under your roof.



</answer>

<answer>



For me it would greatly depend on my child.  Was she in school?  Did she have a job?  Was she lazy and just want to be supported?  I would not allow my child to live with me if they weren't going to school or had a job.



If she had a job and/or was in school, I wouldn't really care about her curfew as long as her grades were high and/or she was helping with housework, bills, etc.  She's an adult.



Boys-I'm not sure I would like boys coming over but I wouldn't mind as long as they behaved.  She still is living under my roof.



Clothes, makeup, internet, myspace- that is all her business as long as I'm not buying it for her and she's safe on the internet.



Driving- is also her perogative if she has her own car and insurance.  If I was paying for it, that would be a bit different but I woudln't pay for it unless she was in school full time (same with clothes, makeup, internet).



cell phone and texting- is also her business if I'm not paying the bill.



</answer>

<answer>



This is how it was when I was 19:



Curfew: 12am, unless I was working
Boys: I had a boyfriend (I'm married to him now) but if he slept over, he slept on the couch and I slept in my room
Clothes: I could wear what I wanted- but I had respect for myself so I dressed decently.



Make-up: Allowed, people would laugh at only me if I went out looking like a hooker or a clown, so I used minimum make-up and it looked decent
Internet: Allowed
Myspace: Allowed
Driving: Allowed, I had my own car and license.



Cell phone & testing: I had to pay for my own phone bill



My parents rule was: If you live under our roof, you will obey our rules. Which is fair.

<question>



Kids TV not Beneficial?!?



Well, I just wanted your opinions on Kids TV, Good or Bad?



As I live in a top floor flat with my 2 year old and unless my partner is home we dont get out much because I have alot of trouble with my back and the stairs, so we spend alot of the day watching the Cbeebies channel. All I hear from parents is how bad kids TV is nowadays and how kids should be outside not watching TV. (Which we would given the chance!!) But I have found this channel to be extremely good! Everyday my little girl is speaking more and more and its all what she has learnt from watching the shows. (Some like the green balloon club and the pop shop thing are just awful) But most are great. She was counting to ten (With my help) before she was 2, she knows the difference in colours and can speak them, She knows a variety of animals and their calls, she is starting to sign with justin, She is telling the presenters what they are going to do before they do it lol And she only turned 2 at the weekend! It may just be me being biased but I honestly think this channel has made her the way she is along with my encouragement.



</question>

<question from>



blowinki...
Member since: 04 November 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do you feel marriage and becoming parents have to be a package deal?



Im just wondering how many people believe in "first comes love, then comes marriage, and then comes a baby carriage"? And if so, does marriage actually guarantee an ideal parenting/upbringing situation for a child? How do you guys feel?



</question>



<answer from>



GOING ON 3 IM BRILLIANT ME 7
Member since: 29 May 2008
Total points: 3456 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



i believe a stable relationship with the parents is what is needed first, not necessarily marriage. i got pregnant at 19 years old, with my boyfriend of 2 years. we got married directly after, becuase it was the "right" thing to do. we divorced a year later-we weren't ready. i think it depends on the people in question, completly. i am now re-married ( @29) and my hubby and i have our hard times, but we were ready and we can face all we need to together.



just becuase you are married doesn't mean it is the best enviroment for the child. i have met & admired many single parents (myself among them) and i will continue to. in fact, i think from my expirience, it is worse to be married have a kid and divorce, than it would be to have a child and wait a little . im not saying i think everyone should get pregnant and then get married, it just depends on the parties involved. alot of people, my self included, need to get their heads on straight before they make huge decisions.
i think the worse thing for a kid to deal with is his parents fighting over financial, general dicsipline & upbringing, and petty crap that could have been avoided. that is never an enviroment for a child-
i do agree with proud texas mommy, getting married before you have children but not because you are having children. it would be ideal if there were no mistakes, but there are. even the precious, loving kind of mistakes that you never regret.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



good points have been brought out on this question that are greatly appreciated, ex. marriage does not guarantee longevity, how divorce affects children, and marriage not equaling good parents. Also, marriage does show commitment, makes it harder to walk away & sets a potential positive ex for kids



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Proud Texas Mommy
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 10769 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



I feel that it does have to be a packaged deal.  That is the way God intended it to be, so that is the way I believe it should be.  Love, marriage/sex, then children.



If the marriage is a healthy one, then it will ensure a healthy upbringing for the child(ren).  I strongly believe marriages would be healthy if people followed the traditional save sex for marriage and then marry before children.  This is the most effective way, in my opinion, to secure a loving stable relationship therefore you can raise a stable, healthy family.



</answer>

<answer>



Stable relationships don't have to include marriage.Hell, my mom's friend and her boyfriend have been dating for thirty years and are still going strong without marriage (now they are getting married for legal issues because he is having health issues)



My child is a perfectly content and intelligent child.Me and my fiancee had him when we were 16.We didn't plan on getting married right away.We knew that if we were going to be together, marriage wasn't necessary right away.We will eventually, but it's not our main goal.



If you think about it, marriage is nothing but a legalized ceremony.Of course it's a great thing, but me and my fiancee made a commitment when we became parents.



But that's just my opinion.
:)

<answer>



I think that it would be best for you to be married to your BF or GF before starting a family together. I feel that way, because it shows a sense of commitment from both parts. <answer>



I agree with the others, you need a loving and stable relationship but that does not always include legal marriage. My partner and I are not married but have a wonderful relationship that many of my married friends envy.



Marriages split up just as often and just as fast as other couples, only difference is the price tag. If my partner decided to leave tomorrow he will be gone.. I won't have to pay someone thousands of dollars to have him out of my life.



We do have kids together, but we have a separate parenting contract taking care of them.... it is actually better than a marriage certificate because  child support and custody and all those issues have already been agreed upon...



we chose not to marry because I am a status native canadian woman who has a legal right to live and work here...if I marry an american I have to give that up. and I rather not give up my native status so if we choice to move to canada and live there we can.... and we hope to retire there..



</answer>

<answer from>



Courage
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 5341 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Too many times people are looking at your son because he's cute, and adorable, and then they look up at the parent slightly embarrassed because it's sort of taboo to show interest in someone else's child, even innocent interest.  Are you sure they're not looking at your son?



I can't guess your age, because I'm terrible at that.  :P  But to me, if someone looks too young to be a little kid's mom I assume they're an aunt, a sister, or something like that.  Are you sure they're judging you?  I  mean... like did you do a Jedi mind trick on them to find out?



Joking aside, don't judge other people.  They might be glaring at you for a number of reasons, or they might be just making eye contact because of how beautiful your son is.  Sure, there's the odd one who might be looking at you and thinking "OMG she's too YOUNG to have a child!" but... teens in general are pretty self-conscious, and I don't think you're being stared at because of your age as much as you think you are.



You're probably being stared at because you're beautiful, your son is beautiful, when you're with him the love the two of you are sharing and such is beautiful, and it's wonderful to look at something beautiful.



</answer>



<answer from>

<answer>



There are medical conditions that can cause teenagers and even adults to wet the bed.  Please don't threaten to put nappies on your teenage daughter.  Speak to her and try to find out if she's not waking up, not making it to the toilet in time, etc.
If it sounds genuinely accidental (which I suspect it is) you need to visit the doctor.



I started wetting the bed at 10, when I never had as a younger child.  My parents initially put it down to the death of my grandmother, turns out I had raging Diabetes.  Please get your daughter checked out.



</answer>

<answer>



Assuming you mean 15 months and not years.  She probably is reverting because of the new baby, not uncommon.  My daughter I had her help with caring for her new baby brother, feed him, help change him etc..  15 months and nighttime trained, wow.  My daughter was about 2 when she decided to stop wearing diapers to bed.  Only problem was that she hadn't figured out the pooping and the potty.  She had waited each day to have a bowel movement in her diaper at bedtime.  The problem was when she stopped wearing diapers, she stopped pooping.  She literally screamed, she was scared to go.  My recommendation is to make sure they are comfortable going both pee and poop before night time training.

Mom of 4 ages 16, 15, 14 and 9 years

<answer from>



I wonder
Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 234 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Bed wetting can be divided into two main types:



Primary Nocturnal Enuresis - which refers to persistent involuntary nighttime urination where the child has never had a dry night.



Secondary Nocturnal Enuresis - which refers to an onset of nighttime bed wetting after a dry period of at least six months.



Three of the most common reasons for primary nocturnal enuresis are:



Genetic predisposition - 75% of children who wet the bed have parents who had the same problem as a child.



Deep sleeping - studies suggest that children who wet the bed are very hard to wake up and have a hard time waking to an alarm clock.



Reduced production of vasopressin - an anti-diuretic hormone that directs the kidney to concentrate the body's urine so your bladder doesn't overfill.
Two of the most common reasons for secondary nocturnal enuresis are:



Urinary tract infection.



Stressful situations at home or school. A bed wetting preteen is not lazy. They are not undisciplined. They have a problem and will need the help of a physician. Even though most preteens will grow out of this condition in time, it will benefit your child to get this help, as during this time their self-esteem is being affected.



Tips



Don't make a big deal out of a wet bed. Show your preteen how to strip the sheets and do a load of wash.



Never punish your preteen for wetting the bed.



If you were a bed wetter, share your experiences with your preteen.



Keep this between your preteen and yourself. Sharing this problem with other family members or friends will only serve to embarrass your preteen.



Find positive things to focus your conversations on. Don't let the only communication you have with your preteenager be about bed wetting.



Suggested Reading
Links: Bed Wetting
Parenting Quizzes
Parenting Quiz: Is Your Teenager Using Drugs?
Parenting Quiz: Are You a Pushover Parent?
All Parenting Quizzes



New posts to the Parenting of Adolescents forums:

Related Articles

How To Keep Your Child In Bed...All Night!
Bedtime habits
Your True Tales - July 2004 - Page 12 - The Dark Shape



Source(s):



me - because I am the smartest



</answer>

<question>

My parents have always had trouble getting my younger sister to do anything (clean her room, clean anything in the house, keep her clothes washed, showered, etc). Nothing they do has helped. Bribing, grounding, NOTHING helps. She has no job, no car, and uses my dad's cell phone sometimes. She's the complete opposite of me and my older sister. She has talked to a psychologist AND school counselors and is NOT depressed at ALL. She doesn't care about going anywhere, has friends, and is socially ok (not popular, but not a "freak")



She's a high school senior, and has a huge project (research paper, so many hours with a mentor, so many hours community service, and a project). The dead line was next Friday (they supposedly extended it). However, she has done nothing but the paper so far. If she doesn't pass this, she does NOT graduate.



They've done everything they can think of to get her to do it. She knows if she doesn't do it, Mom will make her repeat her senior year (no GED). She STILL won't get off her butt and do it. She claims if they stay on her case about doing it she doesn't want to do it even more (stupid, I know) but if they DON'T stay on her, she won't do ANYTHING...



Like I said, grounding doesn't work. What would you do if this was YOUR teen? Any and all suggestions are appreciated

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Sometimes, you have to just let them learn their lesson the hard way.  That means that she will probably repeat senior year.  Nagging her repeatedly does no good, just makes them dig in that much deeper. Try not just grounding, but absolutely not letting her do anything, no tv, ipod, computer, etc., Make her life so boring that she will do just about anything to get her life back.  The parents have to be the parents and mean what they say and say what they mean.  It won't be easy, and hopefully, she will come around.



Source(s):



mom with 2 teens.

<answer from>



cats3to2
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 932 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well, as a youngest child, I think I can say, she knows how to work you all.  We youngest children can watch what works and what doesn't work for our older siblings and can really work our parents.



For Example: My parents gave all my older siblings (7 of them) a hard time about getting a driver's license.  Then when they got licensed they had to run errands for my parents every day to be allowed to use the car.  So when I was old enough to drive, I announced I didn't want a license, while joining several after school clubs and making my mom drive me around 7 days a week.  She had to BEG me to get my license.  I never was asked to run an errand.  I never had to pay for my gas. I saw the mistakes my older siblings made and used the opposite approach. It's called manipulation.



And your sister knows how to manipulate.  She's not doing anything because she simply doesn't want to.  She knows she has a free ride at home, meals and board.  Instead of threatening to make her repeat a grade, a better threat would be to kick her out of the house so she HAS to support herself. If she has a deadline of when the free room and board ends, she may be motivated to be able to support herself by that deadline.



As her sister, however, it's out of your hands.  You can't do anything but sit back and watch.  Actually you might learn a few things from her.  But this is your parent's problem.  And your sister already knows what they'll put up with.  She's probably very happy being an underacheiver.  Good luck with that.



</answer>

<question from>



ann.vant
Member since: 15 September 2008

<question>



Things that change when you have a baby?



I found this a few minutes ago, please feel free to comment or add or disagree:



1. You finally stop to smell the roses, because your baby is in your arms.
2. Where you once believed you were fearless, you now find yourself afraid.
3. The sacrifices you thought you made to have a child no longer seem like sacrifices.
4. You respect your body ... finally.
5. You respect your parents and love them in a new way.
6. You find that your baby's pain feels much worse than your own.
7. You believe once again in the things you believed in as a child.
8. You lose touch with the people in your life whom you should have banished years ago.
9. Your heart breaks much more easily.
10. You think of someone else 234,836,178,976 times a day.
11. Every day is a surprise.
12. Bodily functions are no longer repulsive. In fact, they please you. (Hooray for poop!)
13. You look at your baby in the mirror instead of yourself.
14. You become a morning person.
15. Your love becomes limitless, a superhuman power.
16. You discover how much there is to say about one tooth.
17. You finally realize that true joy doesn't come from material wealth.
18. You now know where the sun comes from.
19. You'd rather buy a plastic tricycle than those shoes that you've been dying to have.
20. You realize that although sticky, lollipops have magical powers.
21. You don't mind going to bed at 9 p.m. on Friday night.
22. Silence? What's that?
23. You realize that the 15 pounds you can't seem to get rid of are totally worth having.
24. You discover an inner strength you never thought you had.
25. You no longer rely on a clock — your baby now sets your schedule.
26. You give parents with a screaming child an 'I-know-the-feeling' look instead of a 'Can't-they-shut-him-up?' one.
27. Your dog — who used to be your 'baby' — becomes just a dog.
28. You take the time for one more hug and kiss even if it means you'll be late.
29. You learn that taking a shower is a luxury.
30. You realize that you can love a complete stranger.
31. You find yourself wanting to make this world a better place.



32. If you didn’t believe in love at first sight before, now you do!



</question>



<additional details>



Here's the website:
http://www.babycenter.com/0_thirty-two-t...



</additional details>

<question from>

<question>



Parents, how old would your child have to be before you let them trick-or-treat without you?



Honestly. Please put a little thought into this its for a report.



</question>

In a group? Alone?



Sorry forgot that piece.

I hope you know that my report was to do a survey of any kind. I've already asked my family and friend's parents and I'm getting averages now.



So if you don't know what you are speaking of I ask you not to speak at all. Or at least not on my question.



</additional details>

<answer>



In my town (which I grew up in) I would let my children go trick or treating in a group when they are ten to twelve, depending on their maturity level. I don't think I would let them go trick or treating alone, first because it's not as safe, although my town is very safe and I wouldn't be worried to have them go out on a normal day, but I wouldn't want anything to happen with teenagers acting crazy, and secondly, because it's not as fun.



If they were alone I would want them to be at least thirteen. If I let my own children go in a group I would want the oldest to be at least twelve and the youngest to be at least eight.



Sorry, it's hard to give one age because there are so many factors to go with it. But I'll say ten with a group and thirteen alone.



</answer>

<question from>

</question from>



<question>



Does your brain grow throughout your life until you reach adulthood or does it stay the same from birth?



My inquiring mind wants to know! :)



</question>



<additional details>



No need for rudeness, it's an honest question.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Mum to the Terrible Three!
Member since: 08 July 2007
Total points: 10743 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



As far as I remember, the brain does grow in size, but more importantly it acquires additional 'connectors' as you gain knowledge.
These connectors form mainly in early childhood and continue to grow and be built up on throughout adulthood.



Source(s):



What I remember from basic development courses.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



JohnOSev...
Member since: 26 December 2007
Total points: 3404 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It grows in size as you grow up.



It also develops in capacity as you age.



Despite what MADD and other ill-informed purveyors of pseudoscience will tell you, your brain does not continue to significantly develop into your late 20s. In fact your mental facilities - including reflexes and the ability to heal injury to your brain - peak somewhere around 17, and it's mostly downhill from there. "Development" in the form of the continued accruing of experience and memories continues into old age.



</answer>



<answer from>



wordweav...
Member since: 03 January 2007
Total points: 2437 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



In order to pass through the birth canal an infant is born with an underdeveloped brain.  The most startling growth occurs in the first few years, but there are stages throughout life in which the brain will expand slightly.  Most of these stages occur before age 35, but studies have shown increases in the fifth and sixth decade as well.  Unlike the other organs in the body, the brain cannot replace lost cells, so expansion is the only option it has.



</answer>



<answer from>



Doctor Music
Member since: 09 July 2007
Total points: 911 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



O.K., from doing actual research in the past I know this as a fact. First of all, know your brain doesn't grow wrinkles from gaining knowledge. Your brain grows in size, yet your brain cells always remain the same. When you're born you have 50,000 (I think) Brain cells, you never get any more. It is simply the way you choose to use your memory, you may lose brain cells which is why you forget things. Your brain cells will grow back when your young, but takes longer when you get older. You do learn more when your a child, but old dogs can learn new tricks, it is simply harder. To answer your question, you brain does grow in size to become proportionate to your body. It does not simply grow because you get smarter.



</answer>



<answer from>



TiffanyD...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 216 (Level 1)



</answer from>

I dont really think your brain grows as in changing sizes.
but then again it might since our heads dont stay the same size from the day were born to the day were officially grown..



</answer>

what happens is your brain does grow along with your body of course. however, there is a illness called dementia and its when you brain starts to shrink. usually that is when you are older and then you get Alzheimer's

<answer>



No, you only pay for what she has done.  I think she has to get a self certification or doctors note if she wants some sort of benefit from the government for the days she is going to have away from work.  I think the ball is in her court to sort this out and she can ask the local council who she is registered with about the legalities or the CAB.



p.s.  Can the local council give you a number of a childminder that can take your daughter on for just these days?  Would you be okay with that and most of all will your daughter?  For a one off is your work place okay with her coming with you?

<question>



Parents having trouble with teen?



My parents have always had trouble getting my younger sister to do anything (clean her room, clean anything in the house, keep her clothes washed, showered, etc). Nothing they do has helped. Bribing, grounding, NOTHING helps. She has no job, no car, and uses my dad's cell phone sometimes. She's the complete opposite of me and my older sister.



She's a high school senior, and has a huge project (research paper, so many hours with a mentor, so many hours community service, and a project). The dead line was next Friday (they supposedly extended it). However, she has done nothing but the paper so far. If she doesn't pass this, she does NOT graduate.



They've done everything they can think of to get her to do it. She knows if she doesn't do it, Mom will make her repeat her senior year (no GED). She STILL won't get off her butt and do it. She claims if they stay on her case about doing it she doesn't want to do it even more (stupid, I know) but if they DON'T stay on her, she won't do ANYTHING...



Like I said, grounding doesn't work. What would you do if this was YOUR teen? Any and all suggestions are appreciated.



</question>



<additional details>



She's not depressed or any other mental problems, just lazy and unmotivated...



She's always either at school or at home. Never WANTS to go anywhere.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Sharon M
Member since: 02 January 2007
Total points: 17793 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You say she isn't depressed but this isn't the behavior of someone who is healthy mentally. How is she doing socially? If she never goes anywhere, does this mean she doesn't have any friends. I think she needs to be evaluated by a professional. Otherwise, the only thing you really can do is let her fail. She'll have to learn by getting the consequences.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

Dark Angel

<question>



Kids TV not Beneficial?!?



Well, I just wanted your opinions on Kids TV, Good or Bad?



As I live in a top floor flat with my 2 year old and unless my partner is home we dont get out much because I have alot of trouble with my back and the stairs, so we spend alot of the day watching the Cbeebies channel. All I hear from parents is how bad kids TV is nowadays and how kids should be outside not watching TV. (Which we would given the chance!!) But I have found this channel to be extremely good! Everyday my little girl is speaking more and more and its all what she has learnt from watching the shows. (Some like the green balloon club and the pop shop thing are just awful) But most are great. She was counting to ten (With my help) before she was 2, she knows the difference in colours and can speak them, She knows a variety of animals and their calls, she is starting to sign with justin, She is telling the presenters what they are going to do before they do it lol And she only turned 2 at the weekend! It may just be me being biased but I honestly think this channel has made her the way she is along with my encouragement.



</question>



<additional details>



Oh yes, she has plenty of toys and books (Loves her books! Lol) and we love to do things together with them since we dont have much else to do right now. =)



Im glad I have found some people that do not have the 'Television is bad' attitude, thank you for your answers, I shall let it go to voting for the best answer as they are all interesting =)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Jenna M
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



What could really be bad about kids tv, it makes them happy so its gotta be good :) hope your backs ok.



</answer>



<answer from>



cigaro19
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 4595 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think when people are talking about tv shows being bad for children they are speaking maybe of cartoons such as spiderman, barbie etc, uneducational 'fun' programmes. At least thats what I think. A moderate amount of tv shows such as numberjacks, shiny show etc, are beneficial to children and entertaining. But there has to be a balance too, because a child also needs plenty of physical activity such as going outside to the park, or playing action songs with you. So yes the tv is great but not all day long!



</answer>



<answer from>



Eternal Dragon
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3109 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the show (or channel)
I normally let my kids watch some of the shows on Nick Jr because they are educational and encourage learning.
One of my kids had to be on serious meds for febrile convulsions - the meds make the child "slow". She also had slight brain damage.
She was given a Dora The Explorer doll that talks and sings in both spanish and english (it also lights up lol). This encouraged her to talk, whereas nothing else did beforehand.
Now if it wasn't for the show Dora The Explorer, this particular doll would not have existed and I don't know what I would have done to help my daughter speak.
It's done her the world of good, not harm
Those shows I let them watch encourage them to count, spell and awareness of the world around them.



</answer>



<answer from>



gbridle2...
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 166 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't think there is any harm in children's television - most of them are made with education in mind - although some are probably more educational than others. I think all of them stimulate the child to one extent or another though.



I would just make sure (and you're probably already doing this) that she has some books, toys etc., around her as well so that television isn't her only form of education.



So, I would say it's a good thing when mixed with other forms of stimulation too.



</answer>

<answer>



If a child is left in front of the tv all day with no interaction from you then it would be detrimental, but with interaction, motivation and collaboration with an adult as you are doing it can be very informative and educational. Even things like Spiderman as the other poster mentioned COULD be used for education IF the supervising adult interacts and uses it in the right way for example right & wrong, helping others, etc. Obviously more educational shows are better than Spiderman but if that is the only way to get a child to contribute and involved ( i have had Professional experience of this!) and the adult uses it in the right way it could help.



The way you are using it is great, hope your back improves x



Source(s):



Nursery Nurse 10 years, mother of 2

<answer>



It is all about how you use kid's TV.



If you watch it WITH your children, and interact with them and talk to them about what they have seen, it is a really useful tool for learning and I think for bonding with your child as you have a shared interest and can talk about the characters, etc.



If you just plonk your kids in front of the telly and leave them to their own devices it is not good.



My daughter who is now nearly 4 is a very bright child and I thank CBeebies for some of that as it has exposed us to things that I would not have known about, all the craft type things on the making programmes, the signing with Justin, all of it basically.

aitchbee...

</answer from>



<answer>



Way too early! The best thing about Christmas is having to wait for it. The money-grabbing retailers have brought it to us earlier and earlier each year; some stores put up their decorations in September now. They're just trying to make sure that every moment in the year is presented to us as a spending opportunity (witness the growth of 'festivals' like Halloween and Father's Day).



Take your daughter out and have her awestruck by the colours of autumn leaves, for example, (or equivalent - I don't know where you live). She'll be bored of Christmas decorations by Christmas which will spoil everything.



Don't put anything up before December 1st - three weeks before is plenty.



</answer>

<question>



Two questions about talking to my dad...please help?



Ok well this is sort of complicated but I'll put it as simply as I can. I'm English and I have just moved to USA to live with my Dad about three months ago. I never knew him before this, he used to pay my boarding school fees but that was it. But he stopped paying and because my mum didn't want me at home all year she said my dad had to take me instead.



My dad doesn't like the way I speak and he gets really annoyed about it because English words don't have the same meaning as American words, like I call my evening meal tea and he calls it dinner. He doesn't like my accent either and when people ask him if I'm British he denies it. He wants me to say I'm American but I'm not. He gets really mad when use  English slang and he is always trying to get me to speak like an American. How can I tell him to stop without offending him? I can't change the way I speak, it's just part of me.



My second question is how do I get him to stop spanking me, I'm really uncomfortable with him doing it. My mum never used to hit me. The first time he did it I thought he was bluffing until he took his belt off and put me over his knee. It hurt and I barely know the guy really. I'm 14 and please don't suggest I hit him back like my friends have, I'm seriously short for my age and he is huge. I'm 4”3 and he's 6”4. I told my mum and she says it's up to my dad how he wants to deal with me.  Any ideas?



</question>



<additional details>



for you information, my mum is working class and yes i was from the north, Newcaslte. That's why he hates the accent



</additional details>

Charli ♥ NOT-SO-PERFECT MUM
Member since: 07 April 2008
Total points: 7763 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



I depends on the employer.

I part-own a business, and am a Mum. My work partner, is a Dad, and he is also a Grandfather. We both have very high family values.
We both understand that kids come before anything. We don't discriminate, and to be honest we both are more likely to hire a family oriented person. We pride ourselves on our business and all staff, are family. 
I don't work in the field you have chosen, and to be honest I am unsure how they work. But for us, it's important for our staff, to be friendly with our clients, and we have a LOT of children coming into our workplace. So being *child-friendly* knowing how to communicate with young children, is a definite advantage, for us.

I personally think if people do judge parents who have young children, are missing out on a lot of potential. We have a couple of Mums who work part-time on reception, and they are FANTASTIC.
They are willing to learn, tuned in, and don't crack under stress.
It is discrimination to not hire someone because they have young children, but I don't think you can prove that's why *you* aren't hired.



</answer>



<answer from>



celtic.p...
Member since: 09 February 2008
Total points: 2239 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Good and bad.



You will have to take time off work to tend to your kids, and you won't be able to work as much as someone without kids. That's just obvious. 
But you do have the experience of having children, which is great, and the ability to deal with that stress, which is always good.

I'd say make sure that you have someone, or someway, of dealing with the children that doesn't involve you leaving the workplace.



I wouldn't employ someone if they had multiple children, and no help. If anything happened, and it happens a lot in minor ways, you'd have to leave. As an employer, that would irritate me obviously.



Make sure that you can prove to your employer that unless anything major happens, you'll be at work. You need to have someone else able to deal with the scratches, headaches, and lost my pencil case and won't stop cryings.



</answer>

<answer>



First control how long and with whose children you are interacting with.  A friend who has two children ages 5 and 18 months would be best.



You learn about children by observing them, so I would just sit quietly.  Let them come to you. The older one may have questions, or want you to do something like read a book with her.  the little one will find things to do.  PUT your purse in another room, have mom bring some of the child's toys along.



They like music.  ask mom to bring their favorite music and you can all sing.  It is fun. But you have relax and have fun too.  The kids can tell if you like them.  if you stiff and uncomfortable make the visit short.  fifteen to twenty minutes at a time until you can tolerate more.



Some people are just not Kid people.  Nothing bad in that.  IF you cannot feel comfortable with kids now, don't fret over it.  Try it again in six months or a year.  People change.



</answer>

<question>

Jake is 7 and Lily is 4, they are my step children by the way but i love them like i love my child who is 5 weeks and 3 days old.

My daughter Ella is 5 weeks and 3 days and taking up quite alot of my time at the moment with feeds ( my husband is out on call - he is a surgen and been out since 3 with a number of emergencies.) it isn't an ideal situation but i am left with with all 3!



Just wondering if you guys have any ideas - that can entertain Jake and Lily. Nothing to big because Ella is going to wake up in the next half hour so she will be needing a feed and i am still breastfeeding and not feeling to well today so i cant be too energetic.
Thanks! Liv



</question>



<answer from>



gwyneth
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 481 (Level 2)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



first congratulations on ella and lots of respect for your concern for your step children.there are lots of things you can do with children to keep them occupied without resorting to t.v. or computer games,but you could always keep them as last resort.first you must find out what the children like,are they the sporty type,the creative type or the academic.the answer can make a difference to how you occupy the children.if the weather is nice you could go to the play park or for a nice nature walk.all children will appreciate the fresh air and it might recharge your batteries also.if it`a rainy day you could do jig-saw puzzles or board games like memory.how about when ella is sleeping having a baking session together.most children like that.or do something with crafts or painting,maybe they can paint a picture to send to their mother.i`m sure the children are missing her and this way it shows the kids you are not trying to take the place of their real mother.could only strenghen the relationship between all concerned.try to get them involved with ella so no  jealousy can come between them.if you live not so far away from where the children were living with their mother invite some of the children`s friends round to play.maybe then later to give you a break they could go round to play with their friends.try to involve them so much in your daily routine so they don`t feel left out and that they don`t feel they have lost their father to your daughter.at the same time let them go at their own pace don`t forget they are going through a lot at the moment.their mother is no longer the main person in their life,that`s a big upheaval.they also have anew sister which can course all sorts of emotions in their mind.they will be very uncertain and be doing their best not to show it.have patiance with them,allow them to go at their own pace.try not to but to much pressure on them or yourself.things take time.i wish you every luck.don`t give up and always look on the bright side.



Source(s):



been a mother and before i had my children had worked for over 20 years with children.8 years of that time as refuge worker for women`s aid.where i experiance lots of children that had to leave their homes a parent that they love and lots of their toy`s and friends etc.that is a lot for young children to cope with who might not have the ability to understand it all.



</answer>

<answer>



The obvious answer is a DVD if you need time with the baby. Otherwise, get them painting (put down newspaper!) or cooking, if it's daytime where you are (I'm assuming it is as they aren't in bed) send them to play in the garden.
Get them to help you with the baby, make a card for daddy - or mummy.

Have you any cards? Dominoes? Games? Get them to plant some seeds? You could read to them whilst baby is feeding.

Don't forget that children don't need entertaining all the time. they need free time to play. Put some blankets over some chairs to make a den - or get a big old box in and let them run wild with their imaginations.

Good luck. I'm sure you won't need it.



</answer>

<answer>



Arts and crafts are always good..painting, gluing and sticking, card making are always good. Or Making play dough then playing with it :)

Play dough mixture:

2cups of plain flour
1 cup of salt
1 cup of water..add food colouring to the water to give the play dough colour
1 tsp of cooking oil
Add extra floor if the texture is still sticky.

Enjoy and good luck x

<answer>



You do what you gotta do. It is your choice, and at this age, your child will be fine whatever you choose even if at first he/she doesn't like it.  It always gets some getting used to.  I think with your first you will always want to spend more time with them because you don't want to miss something, and it is your first time.  I know I didn't work for the first almost 3 years of my first son's life.  They are 23 months apart exactly.  My other son was a few months shy of 1 year and I had felt guilty getting a job and leaving him.  I felt like I was neglecting my younger son but he was fine.  I only worked for a couple of months though, because my older son would only go to the potty for me.  Go figure.  Now they are 4 and 5 and I work again and I have since the end of March.  At first, they didn't understand why and they were a little upset because I work third and they didn't see me as much.  We explained that I worked to pay the bills and buy them stuff and that worked for the older kid, but he was kinda sexist.  He thought only men should work even though we explained that grandma worked.  I think it was just because mom was working.



My other son was quite upset.  He grew more clingy to Daddy and wanted me when I was home, but it was okay.  They had never been to school, but now that my oldest is in Kindergarten and my youngest is in preschool, it makes it easier.  They are happier now.  I am not sure that it makes a difference.  I hope this helps and good luck.  Let me know what you decide.

<question>



Working with down syndrome/autistic children?



i am wondering how i can start working with down syndrome/autistic kids/do i need to take classes from college?



</question>



<additional details>



i am not saying both together, i'm talking about seperately.
i know they are not classified together.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Amy G
Member since: 26 April 2008
Total points: 314 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



your question didn't have a lot of details.What do you want to do?One thing that is very fulfilling for both you and the children you want to work with is a speech,occupational,developmental,physic... all of them work with children who have special needs and are disabled.You do however need college classes and diplomas for all of them.Or if you wanna just get a taste of it to see if it is right for you try your local park district and special recreation services department,you could be a coach or a camp helper or something with people with these types of disabilities.Good luck.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



TY



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Amy W
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 1991 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You must be certified to work with any special needs child.



</answer>



<answer from>



BoSox27
Member since: 15 September 2007
Total points: 18235 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on how you mean you want to work with them.  You can probably start immediately as a volunteer in your community.  If you mean you want to teach them, you'll need a master's degree.
By the way, Down Syndrome and autism are two entirely different diagnoses that can't be lumped together.  I highly suggest researching both of them before trying to work with people who have such diagnoses.



</answer>



<answer from>



beetlemi...
Member since: 17 April 2008
Total points: 12759 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Toddler & Preschooler



</answer from>



<answer>



They are 2 different diagnosis but children can have both.  what you can do now is a paraprofessional also called an aid provided you don't have a record, and have a H.S. diploma.  You could shadow 1 student also.  Also you could work at a respite care, afterschool care program right now.  Suggest for finding what is local to you is going on your states autism chapter website.  There will be lots of info there, so start calling places.



</answer>

<question from>



larey
Member since: 16 February 2007
Total points: 1125 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



How late do you allow visitors stay when you have small children?



My hubby and I just had our first child; she's 5 weeks old.  While she is still too young to be expected to be on a sleep schedule, I want to create a routine for going to bed as soon as possible.  We have family that likes to come over at 8 or 9 and stay until 11.  While they are quiet (ish), they all have to hold the baby and kiss her goodbye which wakes her up.  Inevitably, after we've had guests that late, we have a very rough night and morning.  Plus, we can't go to bed early either and catch up on sleep.  I was thinking 8:30pm would be a decent visit cutoff time and would allow us to bath her, feed her, and create a calmer environment for her to sleep in.  Does that seem too strict or early?  I need some outside perspective on this.  Thanks.



</question>



<additional details>



These family members are coming specifically to visit the baby this late.  If we tell them they can't hold her because she's asleep, they won't want to come.  They see the baby for at least 4-5 hours on the weekend each week anyway.  I don't think they'll be baby deprived.  :)



</additional details>



<answer from>



Bra Burner
Member since: 28 August 2006
Total points: 526 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I don't have a cut off time if the company is quiet. However I do not allow them to play and kiss and hold him and get him all excited. I put him down to sleep at the same time (most of the time) every night and I don't allow anyone to interact with him after that.

EDIT:
if they are coming specific for the baby then they should have more consideration then that. but 8:30 is very reasonable. More reasonable then I would be.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks.  We tried letting this bunch of the family visit after bedtime and they ended up being very loud.  My goal is to encourage them to visit earlier during the weekdays at least.  They all finish work up by 3pm each day anyway so I don't know why they come so late.



</asker's comment>

Children under 10 or so should go to bed much earlier. 8:30-9pm should be a late bedtime, not time to start getting ready for bed. Be strict with your rules for guests. If people need to be gone before you can put her to bed, then select an earlier time that people need to leave by so that you can get her to bed at a decent hour. Baby comes first, not guests. <answer from>



queentut...
Member since: 19 June 2007
Total points: 698 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



As a parent and a grandmother I have to say you are on the right track with your thinking.

However, I would move the time up to 7:30 for ending visiting hours.  The reason why is because as your child gets older you will want her used to being in her bed between the hours of 8 and 8:30 p.m.

You will want your quality time with your child as well as a family.  You will also want to get all of your feeding and bath done before bed time and have quality time to read to your child or just hold the child for that one on one bonding before the child goes to sleep.

Eventually you will want and actually can't wait for your child's bed time so you can have quality time of your own and have private time with your mate especially if your time is already on a schedule due to working or going to college.

You are a family now and are now in the phase of parenting and its time to change your path and make plans to secure your bonds of just the three of you and it is hard at first to divide up your time but your child is more important and the child and your self need all the rest you can get now because when the child is old enough, you will find your time limited and it will seem there is not enough time to get everything done.

It's ok to have family and friends around, however, those who care about your family need to realize that you have a family now and a new life to lead.  They will understand and won't get their feelings hurt because they know that you are only thinking of the child.

I would let everyone know your schedule for visiting hours so no ones feelings get hurt.  That way they can plan in advance and you can be prepared for their visit and the baby will be a wake.

Also, you may want to limit the number of visits especially since your child is such a young age.  Little babies can catch everything because their amune system is not as strong as ours.  So make sure they all wash their hands before handleing the baby and make sure no one holds your child or gets near him/her that is feeling sickly.

I'm not saying put a bubble around your child, I am saying take the percautionary measures to protect your child.

Best of luck and congrats on your new arrival.



</answer>



<answer from>



Tia K
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 142 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I had massive problems with getting my 3 month old son to sleep.  He would just lie awake and cry for hours, then when he finally went to sleep he would wake every hour or two hours through the night and cry again!  Talk about pulling our hair out .... we were absolutely desperate for sleep!

It was a baby sleep audio program recommended by a friend that finally saved us. We followed the advice and began by creating a baby sleep routine which included bathtime, dimming of the lights, putting Paul into his crib, final nappy change and then lullabies. We also made recommended changes to his naps during the day and used some of the other recommended techniques. Within two weeks he was sleeping through the night most nights with just the odd night where he would just wake once!



Definitely start by creating a good baby sleep routine though and you could find that solves most of your baby sleep problems.

Good luck!



Source(s):



If you want to take a look, the audio program is at http://www.babysleepsolution.com



</answer>



<answer from>



What A Look is TTC #2
Member since: 10 June 2008
Total points: 3316 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Not at all. From day one I had my son on a "schedule". I couldn't control my sons crying, feeding schedule but I could give him scheduled baths, scheduled "play times and daily scheduled walks. At 8pm(I coslept for the first 7 months of my sons life) I would take my son into bed, lay with him until he slept. Now at 8pm he goes to bed on the dot in his crib.



It is not rude to ask vistors to leave but you could still have people over late at night once your schedule gets aligned and your baby sleeps through the night. Especially if you have the baby schedulized.



I found my schedule helped promote an active social life, I could plan baby free social time with friends knowing I could enjoy my time because I KNEW my baby was okay.



</answer>



<answer from>



CEM
Member since: 21 May 2008
Total points: 4620 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



If they come over at 8 p.m., then a 1/2 hour visit isn't worth it.



Is this a daily thing, once a week?  She's only 5 weeks old and the baby is still very new to everyone.  Try to stick it out for a bit longer.

Next time they come over at 8 p.m., then at 9 p.m. say "I have to go give the baby a bath and ready for bed.  The last few times she's gone to bed late and it screws up her and my sleep schedule for the night, and she was really cranky the next day."  Go give her a bath, and if they are still there, come out and have them kiss the baby goodnight and go do the rest.

After a few times of this - maybe up the time each time, they will start to figure out (hopefully), that the baby needs to go to sleep a certain time.



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Parents: Am I too young to consider having sex?



I'm 17 years old and I am still a virgin.  My boyfriend and I have been together for two years now and we plan on marrying in the future.  We have seriously discussed having sex but I am not sure that we are ready.  I've always been raised to believe sex is for marriage, but it's such a strong temptation.  Should we continue to wait?



</question>



<answer from>



Texas Mommy of 2
Member since: 21 March 2008
Total points: 8406 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Given the fact that you are still unsure about it, I would say wait.  Think about all the possible outcomes.  Pregnancy, STDs, heart break, or even guilt over having sex.  If you both truly love one another then you both can wait for marriage.  I can think of no better gift than to give yourselves to each other on your wedding night.  Stand out from the crowd.  Wait and I'm sure you won't regret it :)

Temptation is strong I know this from personal experience.  Both my husband and I maintained our virginity until we were married.  Boy was it difficult!  But we are glad we waited.  I believe you can.  True love waits.  It shows you both have the self control that far too many lack.



Source(s):



If it were my daughter I'd tell her the same thing.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I'm glad to know you'd tell your daughter the same.  I think I will wait after all.  What you said about standing out from the crowd is what I really liked.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Are you married now?  No. Then you should not be having sex, age out of the equation.  Be stronger than the temptation and wait.  It is possible. They forget the emotional consequences of having sex outside of a committed relationship (committed in that you have committed to spend the rest of your lives together) where real love, the deep real love where respect is at the forefront, not sex, rules the relationship.



You will be much happier with yourself if you wait.  Why do you think mental disease is so rampant in society now? You already know that if he loves YOU which he probably does, he will wait too : )



</answer>
