<answer from>



Skylark
Member since: 25 January 2008
Total points: 10470 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's awesome that you have a good relationship now, but that doesn't mean that you will continue to have one when she is living in a strange place away from her mom who "doesn't want her anymore" and the pain of this all settles in. I had an amazing relationship with my dad my entire life - I seriously thought he was just so freaking cool - UNTIL I chose to move in with him at 14 instead of moving with my mom & stepdad overseas. The dynamics of our relationship completely changed when he went from being the fun weekend dad to the primary parent who suddenly enforced curfews & got on my case about things. I was very close to my mom (still am, she rocks), and I missed her so much it was literally a physical pain. Even if your daughter isn't close to her mom, chances are she will begin to miss her. It's just the way humans are wired.

I would very strongly recommend that you have your daughter see a therapist for a little while so that she can have a totally neutral adult to talk everything through with, to be a soundboard, and support her. It would be almost impossible to be completely honest with either of you about her feelings without worrying it would hurt you or something, and this is way, way, way too much to put on her shoulders. There is just so much going on - the divorce, issues with her mom, the idea of moving to a new country at 16, the middle of high school & an awful time to try to break into a new social circle, worrying about how that might affect college..... Yowsas. My parents had me see one to help make the decision, and had wanted me to keep seeing her  after the move, but I had too many things going on & didn't have the time. I really regret not making the time because it would have been incredibly beneficial to have talked things through, to have expressed everything instead of bottling it up or acting it out.



I also think a therapist would be helpful for her because I cannot imagine a deeper cut than having your mom not want you anymore. Just reading those words made me wince because I would be beyond devastated if my mom felt that way about me. It would be acutely, unbearably painful, a deep betrayal, & I'd probably self-destruct.



My parents divorced when I was really young, and have always been on great terms (not once have they ever bashed one another in front of me or pulled me into drama), but I've witnessed the turmoil my friends have gone through during divorce, and it's awful. Teenagers need to feel like we have some control over our lives, and the reason so many girls (so, so many, seriously) cut, sleep around, 420, or are Ana / Mia is because it gives her complete control when there is chaos spinning around them, and because they need to distract themselves from the emotional pain with physical pain. Parents are almost always clueless about all this.

Focus on her emotional health and well being rather than the legalities. Understand that however stressful the divorce is on you, it's even more stressful for her. Please don't ever badmouth her mom in front of her (not saying you do, but UGH my best friend's parents do all the time & it's so infuriating). Let her vent if she wants, but don't ever talk about her mom in a negative way, no matter what she's done, because your daughter still loves her despite whatever she says to the contrary & will be hurt.



I don't know why the lawyers don't want her to go with you to Canada, but I wouldn't share any of that with her. Deal with that with your lawyer and ex-wife.



Sorry this is so long & raw. I just came across this question randomly & felt compelled to answer because I think dads, even the best of intentioned & awesome ones, can be really out of touch sometimes about what it's really like to be a teenage girl & I wanted to give you an honest perspective.



Best of luck to you both.

~ Pax



Source(s):



Senior in high school w divorced parents living in different countries



</answer>

<question from>



chrstnwr...
Member since: 20 April 2006
Total points: 28600 (Level 7)



</question from>



<question>



Would you consider that some teenagers in today's society are ungrateful?



Back when my dad was a teenager (late 60s, early 70s), he took his punishment without complaint.



When I was a teenager, I hardly ever got into trouble but I never told my parents, "that is so not fair" when I got grounded.  I never whined to my parents to buy me designer clothing (interestingly enough, my mom thinks I dress too frumpy now but that's a different story).



Nowadays, you see kids as young as 11 or 12 begging for a cellphone (I was happy to get a pager at 16).



When they screw up and get grounded, they'd cry "that is so not fair" because they wouldn't be able to text or email or call their friends to hear the latest gossip because they were out too late at night.



I've heard of this show on MTV called "My Super Sweet 16" where stupid parents waste their hard-earned money to give their kids expensive crap that they really don't need.  When I was 16, I had a dinner party at a local Mexican restaurant and that was it (I didn't have a lot of friends then).



Do you think that some teenagers (I'm not saying all kids, just some) act too whiny and ungrateful?  If you have teenagers, what do you teach them about being grateful and obedient?



</question>



<additional details>



There are tons of really good answers here and unfortunately, I can't pick more than one answer.



So I'm going to put it to a vote.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I would agree with you on most of your points.  The only reason I wouldn't fully agree is that I have a hard time blaming them completely for their behavior.



I'm only 23, but when I was a kid, I felt very much the same.  Looking back, I was so very ungrateful for all my parents gave me.  Now that I've grown up, I realize that they were actually quite generous, and that life at home was good!



That said, we are now in an age we are given instant gratification for almost anything.  Anymore, it's not enough to call a friend's house and leave a message on their answering machine (who has those anymore anyways, right?).  We don't just wait patiently.  We can text them, e-mail them, page them... there are many more possibilities for instant gratification in our relationships than there were even ten years ago.



I think perhaps because of this instant gratification in many aspects, thanks to the Internet, teens today are used to getting or knowing what they want immediately in many areas... and they think it ought to be the same at home.  The media also portrays the rich teens on TV because it encourages them to aspire for wealth, and motivates teens to acquire expensive computers, clothes, phones... you name it!  Kids don't understand that not every cute blonde teenager in California gets a $10,000 birthday party.



If we'd kept limits on the Internet and TV when it had first come about, this might never have happened.  But on the other hand, everyone would agree that the Internet is probably the innovation of our time...  I guess that it is going to be a challenge for me, when I become a parent, to come up with innovative ways to teach my children about what life is really about.  Think of it as blazing a trail to a new way of parenthood!  :)



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, of course some do, but I also think some teens from the past were also like that. I'm not being mean or degrading to past generations, but there's no way none of them were spoiled or ungrateful.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



I see a lot of ungrateful teens but it stems from their parents.  If you spoil and let your kids get away with things then they grow up the same way.



I have 4 kids (14, 10, 3, 1) and none of them run the show in my house and neither do their friends.  They've always known I'm the boss and there are consequences to their actions.  Those kids on those tv shows were obviously always given what they want.



When my eldest daughter was about 8, I was getting my nails done and she was sitting nearby watching me.  As my nails were drying, some richy prissy lady said "is that your daughter" and I said "yes", she continued to say "she's being really good over there, you should get her something for being so good."  I quickly responded to "Are you serious?  I'm not giving her a gift for being good, she's supposed to behave without a prize.  She'd get a foot in her butt if she doesn't behave."



Same thing with chores, I don't pay my kids to do household chores.  It's their responsibility.  I do give allowances but they have to earn it.  I've heard kids tell their parents "I'll take the garbage out only if you pay me?", that made my mouth drop when the mom gave him $5.  And this lady wondered why she had no control of her son.



I know there is always that small exception of an out of control kid where the parents did everything right but the kid just came out that way but it is always usually the parents and spoiling a child is one of the worst things you can do if you don't want to create a monster.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<answer>



I think it has to do a lot with where you grow up and who you grow up with. From a young age my parents taught me the value of a dollar and how far I could stretch it.



I know a lot of people my age (19) who are the same way as me. However I also know some people my age who are so immature about things like that, that they actually seem so much younger than me.

<answer from>

</answer from>



<answer>



My mom's generation was considered lost, the gyrating-hips-Elvis/Beatles/drugs/free love/pregnant-teen/Me generation.



My generation was the oversexed/Madonna/drug-using-Hard-Rocker... generation.



Both of our generations supposedly represented disrespectful, ungrateful, irresponsible teens who had



My mom was doing some on my great-grandmother, who was born in 1894. While looking for her birth record in the paper she noticed a news store about how terrible teenagers were, how they were using drugs, were disrespectful whiners and OMG they would be the youth who would be running the country eventually.



Go back to the ancient Greek times and you will find writings of the ancient philosophers that complain about the disrespectful, uncaring, greedy and generally useless youth.



No, nothing has changed. Every generation makes this kind of complaint about the next generation(s). The older you get the better your generation was.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>

<answer>



"My Super Sweet Sixteen" isn't a very good example of all teens. Those girls are like that because their parents let them be like that.



I don't think it's that teens nowadays are naturally ungrateful, rather it's their parents not teaching them to be grateful. Being a teen myself, my parents taught me to appreciate what I have, even if it's not a lot. I'm astonished when I hear girls whine about not being able to go tan because they failed or call their parents inappropriate names because they wouldn't let them hang out with their friends.



So please don't put all the blame on the teens, the soft and passive parents have a lot to do with it too.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah I've seen my share of that in my high school, although I'm not saying I'm perfect by any stretch.



We've had several guests to our school from places where people live much harder lives, things like Invisible Children and refugees from all around. Sometimes just hearing their stories (or watching movies in some cases) does have an impact... I think a number of us honestly do walk out of there and feel like our own rebellious attitudes and superficial needs are a bit ridiculous...



I don't really think I can give any great suggestions... Luckily I have tended to notice that many of my peers have matured now that college is around the corner...



Just wanted to share some thoughts. :)



Source(s):



Life



</answer>

<question>

I really don't know where to put this but I am just so thrown right now.  These two boys I went to school with a while ago committed murder.  They put a ladder to the window and looked inside to see the poor woman was sleeping, but they armed themselves anyway.



One brought a rifle and the other brought a metal bat. They cut the screen on her window, snuck in, unplugged all the phone jacks in the house, cut the power in the home.  The woman woke up during the burglary and they beat her to death, all because they wanted her damn xbox(yes i know she was old, she had grandchildren who liked to play it) and now people are sticking up for them.



It's sickening, really. The aunt of one of the kids said 'our town is a prejudice one, and these kids are going to be made to look like monsters because they killed a white woman'- what does race have to do with anything?! they killed a woman for her xbox, they ARE monsters!



Oh and another person said 'You people don't understand the whole situation. Before you judge someone you should know all the facts. Yes, it's a shame that this had to happen, but none of you know what the circumstances where that lead them to commit this crime. I'm not saying it's right by any means, but they both had rough lives in the little time they have been on this earth. So think about that before you say anything. This could be your family member some day. Also to everyone who says they should rot in prison..........just remeber they are still children. If your going to blame anyone blame the mothers. Just because they aren't showing emotions doesn't mean they don't regret what has happened.'



...what the HELL does that have to do with anything?  "oh my mom doesnt pay attention to me..i think ill kill the neighbor"..what!  They're 14 and 15..they knew what they were doing, being children doesn't make it any better. Parenting has nothing to do with how they acted, even if your parent never tells you killing is wrong, it's common sense!  I hope they both get sent to prison and are beaten, so they can see how they like it :(



God, I cried when I heard about this.  Does anyone agree that this is messed up? Or does anyone side with the kids families? Would you honestly say that the parents are at fault for this?



I'm sorry this was so long :/

<question from>



JAY
Member since: 05 August 2007
Total points: 781 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Please help me am having alot of trouble with my 6 year old daughter and dont know how to cope with her?



Every morning is a battle with her first its the sleeves on her school uniform cardigan they have to be just above her wrists or she has a fit then her shoes must be pulled so tight they leave marks on her feet we are often late for school as she has to stop many times and pull them tight on the way. She doesn't sleep very well either and a few times Ive gone to the toilet early hours of the morning and found her wide awake playing with her barbies.She is a very emotional child and always wants lots of kisses and hugs which I give her but she is constantly crying. She always says that I love her brother more than her which isn't the case and I always make sure we spend time just us two going to the cinema or shopping I just don't know what to do for the best when I drop her off to school in the mornings I think that god for that Im physically and emotionally exhausted.



</question>



<additional details>



Her brother is only 4 and its not just the shoes and cardigans her ponytail has to be in a certain position on her head and be pulled really tight she wont wear shoes with laces and her tousers have to be pulled up really high untill they touch her ankles.



</additional details>



<answer from>



vampwith...
Member since: 10 June 2007
Total points: 3760 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Ask the school what she's like there... does she have similar behaviours there?
If she does, explain your concerns and ask for them to get the Educational Psychologist involved.



Also get your GP involved to see if there's another problem.



She may just be an emotional child, but better to get it checked out.
Also before you go to the GP make a list of all the "odd" things you experience with her, like the sleeves and shoes etc.



Good luck



</answer>



<answer from>



girley_0...
Member since: 29 April 2007
Total points: 3135 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there,  i understand this must be so hard for you to see your daughter in this way - my niece had a similar OCD, she HAD to have her socks on perfectly, the front had to be exactly pulled across her toes and she wouldn't put her shoes on until they were - used to drive my sister mad as she'd spend over 15 mins every morning before school, trying to get her socks right, then she had to put her shoes on really carefully so the socks didn't move into the wrong place!



My niece just eventually grew out of this, it lasted a good 5 months though! We think back now and realise it was around the exact time she was having problems with her dad, she must have been worried/stressed/anxious about what was happening and so used the "sock" obsession to take her mind off of it!



This sounds like what is happening with your daughter, talk to her and find out what is worrying her - maybe her brother is being a typical mean big brother telling her that you love him more than her (i'm not saying this is the case, but it's just an example) she may be worried or upset that it's the truth, so she's developed an obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) to take her mind off of it - so she can think about her cardigan and shoes, rather than what is upsetting her!



You can either talk and try to find out what's wrong, then try to fix it - or wait for her to grow out of it and realise for herself there is nothing to worry about, it's up to you!



I hope you mange to find out whats wrong and i hope i've helped!



Source(s):



a niece with an sock OCD



</answer>



<answer from>



The Casual Observer
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



She may be cranky in the morning because she doesn't get enough sleep. It's a cycle where she sleeps late, wakes up early, groggy all day. Suggest you modify her sleep habits by:



1) Get HER lots of physical exercise after school. This will be good for her and tire out for the day.



2) Diet- Have dinner earlier and regularly at the same time so her food digests well. No late night snacks, which can energize her at night.



3) No mentally intensive activity before bed- (no video games, movies, etc)



4) Sleep earlier.



5) Have a calm light chat with her before bed...let her speak her mind and express her concerns. Try to understand her problems and talk until she falls asleep. Something must be bothering her, so see if you can find out what that is.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



chip2001
Member since: 23 December 2006
Total points: 18924 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's no harm in seeking some expert advice via your GP, but it sounds like she's a very intelligent child - not many 6 year olds would compare the love given to her, compared to what she perceives her siblings getting; this could explain why she's so sensitive. She probably has a very active brain and finds it hard to switch off at night, spending time thinking about things when other children of that age would just go to sleep. One of the above answers is good in suggeting a very relaxed wind down to bed time, including a good story which will hopefully occupy her brain instead of all her personal thoughts.
In some ways she reminds me of my son at that age - he hated labels in clothes, we had to cut them out. He was also very aware of his socks not being straight (said it felt wrong) and his sleeves being the same length.He was very sensitive too. If it's any consolation, he grew out of it and is now a normal - but intelligent and still sensitive - 21 year old.
But if it really is worrying you, do ask to see a child psychologist, or whatever your doctor advises.



</answer>

<answer from>



Nikkispa...
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 722 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think you need to speak to her teacher and find out if this behaviour is happening at school too.  To me it sounds as though she may have some form of OCD with the socks and the cardigan thing.  I suggest you have a chat with your GP too, because they may be able to help with behavioural therapies.  Behavioural Therapists sound scary, but my sister is having problems with her son at the moment, and he's being assessed, and they've been great.  Basically they help by observing the way children play and using games to sort the problems out.  If she is constantly crying have you asked her why?  Maybe she is being bullied at school, or maybe she is a little jealous of her brother, especially if your son is at home with you all day while she is at school.



Good luck anyway



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



I shoved my mom and was going to hit her?



My mom is a single mother. It's just her, my older brother who is about to turn 19, me 16 and my 15 year old brother.
My brothers always follow the rules and stuff, I'm a bit more of a handful for my mom.
My mom and I got into a screaming match Monday morning, and I left, went to school and didn't get home until about 9:00 p.m. that caused another screaming match, she said I was grounded. Tuesday I didn't get home until about 7:30 p.m. and she was totally ticked off because I was supposed to be grounded. So that caused yet another screaming match. I went to leave, and my mom grabbed my arm, I turned around and shoved her to the ground and was going to start fighting her.



My brother (the soon to be 19 year old) interviened.
He and I then started getting into a shouting match, I pushed him.
And then he grabbed me and put me down on the floor over his knee and starting spanking me. He's never done that before. He was yelling how sick and tired he was over me never listening and being disrespectful and disobedient.
When he was done, he made me apologize to our mom.
And now he's saying he's taking over parenting responsibilities, and my mom agrees!!!!!
She's going to allow him to discipline me if I get out of line.
I was going to go to a party tomorrow night, but now I don't think I can because I'm afraid my brother might spank me again, what should I do?
Is it legal for my brother to do that? Should I call the police?



</question>



<additional details>



I'm a girl!!



</additional details>



<answer from>



hyperhau...
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I think you have a very unique opportunity ahead of you. You seem to get upset easily and can even be irrational at times, but you're capable of recognizing your situation for what it is. A lot of people would have left several details out of the story that you did just to get people on their side, but you were very honest and open even though a lot of people will bash you for it.



You might be upset at the way things are turning out for you right now, and I know you don't like the idea of your brother disciplining you, but I think it will be beneficial for you in the long run. You might not realize it now, but the way you are acting right now is affecting your future. If you continue to act unruly and even start getting violent, your personality will gradually shift to accommodate that. Eventually, you will become someone that you don't want to be. You will realize one day that you are unhappy with who you've become and you'll want to change. Which is good, but it will be much harder for you to change then.



If you go with the flow now and put forth a genuine effort to try doing a few things differently, I think you'll find that your attitude will gradually adjust to be happy with it. Try to reestablish your relationship with your mother. You might even get to the point that you see her as a friend. Good luck.



</answer>

Pregnancy & Parenting

<question from>



Marlene
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 1 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How do I convince my husband into having children?



We've been married for almost 12 years. We both agreed to never have kids before we got married. Now I've changed my mind and I do want a kid. But my husband still doesn't want them. I tried changing his mind, but he refuses.



I love him with all my heart. What should I do? How can I convince my husband?



</question>



<additional details>



He wants a vasectomy.



</additional details>



<answer from>



SCruzMom
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 495 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You'll likely never convince him to have kids.  You married him knowing he didn't want any and for the last 12+ years, neither did you.  All you can do is tell him exactly how you feel and why you want to have kids now.



If you still want them and he still doesn't, there may be some serious soul-searching in store for you to decide which you want more, your husband or children.  If it's children, you will likely have to do it on your own or with a new partner.



Tricking your husband into parenthood is definitely a bad idea.  Don't start sabotaging condoms or diaphragms, creating that kind of deceit will definitely send you careening into divorce court.



Best of luck to you!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I understand. I will go back to my word.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



anon
Member since: 05 March 2008
Total points: 2127 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



My husband decided that the two (school-age nowe) children we have are enough and that we were not going to have any more.  I don't know if he ever really wanted kids because we never discussed whether or not to have kids--I just ended up pregnant the first time and we did plan the second.  Despite wanting more, I recently came to a place of acceptance.  He is a writer and I work outside the home, so I realized that it was unfair of me to ask him to have to care for an additional child, an infant to boot.  We don't make enough to justify paying daycare fees.  I'm also over thirty.  We're done with the baby stage and are looking forward to the next phase.  I sent all the baby stuff I was hanging onto to Goodwill.  A couple months later, I find out I'm pregnant.  Telling him was difficult, but I knew he wasn't going to leave me or make me abort.



That said, I don't recommend "accidentally" getting pregnant.  I'm one of the "lucky ones", as they say.  Unless you know how your husband really feels, you could find yourself having to choose between him and your child.  That being said, if having a child is that important to you, you may have to try to find someone else to have a child with or have a child on your own.



</answer>



<answer from>



Katrina M S
Member since: 29 September 2008
Total points: 127 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



What a tough position you are in, but you can not hold it against him, you knew what you were getting when you married him. I do not say this to be cruel, but so that you do not blame him. You can't convince people to make such life altering decisions.



It would be great if he were to say yes, but even if he does at this point I think down the road he will struggle & it will show in your marriage. My philosophy is one NO & 1 YES = a NO. When it comes to an innocent child both people must be on board.



I think you need to decide what you want more at this point: a child or your husband.



</answer>

<question from>



Bub
Member since: 07 July 2007
Total points: 12901 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Languages



History



Programming & Design



</question from>



<question>



How do you prevent your children?



From being overly jealous and/or envious?



</question>



<answer from>



rrm38
Member since: 01 July 2007
Total points: 12694 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Marriage & Divorce



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



When kids are very young, it's almost impossible.  They are going to be jealous of each other, what friends have and they don't, when one gets to go somewhere that another doesn't, etc.  My two used to be maddening with this.



"You never do ____ with me"
"She never gets in trouble for ___"
"You don't like me as much as ___"
"___'s mom lets them do ___"
"___ got a ___ for their birthday, why can't I"



These are just a few from the list of things I've heard from mine.  All you can do is teach them that everyone isn't the same and everyone doesn't have the same things.  Of course, you should treat your children equally and not favor one over the other.  That's not going to keep them from accusing you of favoritism at some point, though.  When they're being unreasonable with their statements, tell them they're being unreasonable.  At some point, a switch turns and they begin to understand it all a little better.  There's just that period of time in which they're so focused on themselves that they don't realize it all very well.  I've seen a big change in my two with regard to this type of thing as they get older.  They're 10 and 12 now, and I rarely hear things like this from them any more.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



LuvlyBee
Member since: 22 April 2008
Total points: 1512 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



tbh, you really can't no matter how you raise them. since every child is unique, one may require more attention than the other. the child can't help but be jealous. also it is an age issue. your 17 might be able to go out alone, but then your 13 year old will ask, why s/he can't do it and you say that s/he isn't old enough and the kid gets jealous. all children are jealous, it's kinda a natural thing, but it is the way that they act on their jealousy! to work with that, then teach them good morals and the love of God.



Source(s):



experience. i'm an 18 year kid who's sometimes jealous of my 20 year old brother.



</answer>



<answer from>



Ace
Member since: 18 February 2008
Total points: 628 (Level 2)



</answer from>

Yet you may find instances where the others understand, and not beg or plead to get what the other got. it all lies withing raising your kids, values, morals, and affection, one can say treat them equally, yes it helps, but are you really raising them in understanding that concept.

<question from>



Katkat - cloned Mum of two :)
Member since: 10 September 2008
Total points: 1302 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



As a Mum, do you think this is an unreasonable thing to say/do to my sons Dad?



My little boy's Dad is notoriously uncaring and terrible at keeping to contact arrangements. He hasn't seen him for 2 weeks now, and has no intention of doing so. He has missed 75% of contact, and chosen other things over seeing his son constantly.



I've now reached the end of my tether - he has changed him number, and the one number I do have he refuses to answer. I've been trying to get him to stick to a routine and he won't.



After trying to contact him for a week, I really cannot be doing with this anymore. For my son's sake - he needs stability that he just doesn't get from his Dad.



I want to tell him (via text so at least he has no choice but to hear me out) that if he doesn't contact me by tomorrow night to arrange to see the little one at the weekend then I will assume that he doesn't want to see him anymore - based on this and his past behaviour and therefore if he wants to make that decision, it's fine by me, but that has to be his FINAL decision. No second chances, no going back, and he won't be able to see him again until Finn is at an age where he can choose to see him.



Do you think that sending this message would be unreasonable?



</question>



<additional details>



I don't want to cut him out at all - I want HIM to make a decision now, not when little one understands (he's 18 months now). I'm hoping it will give him a kick up the bum more than anything else.



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Not unreasonable but not the right thing to do I don't think. You can send the text by all means, it might get it "off your chest" so to speak  but I would hold back, you are angry, rightly so but the child's father does have access rights unless a court decides otherwise, you can't assume that by ignoring your text that is the end of the matter.



I would just back off, see how things go. Let him contact you if he wants to see the child. Try not to burden your son with details or criticise his Dad in front of him, just say "Daddy is busy but he'll try to come another day" if he asks where he is. Kids are adaptable.



Keep note of all the information you have told us, dates he let you down, the fact he can't be contacted etc. Go and see a solicitor and ask for advice.



My ex (my kids' Dad) was fairly useless too, he kept letting me down not collecting them, showing up late, never showed up for parents evenings at school, that sort of thing. Pretty much the same scenario as you, but he was still their Dad, they didn't choose him I did.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Don't text!



You have no way of being sure that he has received and read a text. Write a letter and send it recorded delivery or registered post, that way he has to sign for it and you will know for definite that he has received it. You would actually be better off having a solicitor send the letter.
Your son needs stability and he may at a later date decide he wants to see his dad so don't 'bad mouth' his dad, just love your son and look after him.



Source(s):



common sense, personal experience



</answer>

YES!! That is a very unreasonable thing to do. You are now putting your son in the middle. Something the counselors tell you not to do. That sounds very controlling on your part. I am sure you are sick of his behavior. But the only behavior you can change unfortunately is your own.



When the mother bans visitation for any reason...SHE turns into "the bad guy" for the rest of her kids life. I say let HIM be the "bad guy"...he seems to do it so well.



What I would do is just be calm. That will tick him off to no end anyway...(he wants to use you as the big biotch, so that he can weasel out of seeing his kid....the blame game...). What I would do...is get a fresh calendar. Write in when he is SUPPOSED to see Finn. Then if he does....pencil it in...like how long what they did, where they went, ect. Do not tell him that you are doing this. (but something like this could be a very accurate record in court). Your child will undoubtedly have issues in the future with his dad. Then you can just hand him all the many calendars and be totally out of it. ere is the evidence dude. Whatever your dad is telling you...is it in there? Let him be the judge. You are no longer the bad uy.



In the meantime...just take time and connect with your son. And try not to be too biter. Kids can sense that. Let dad e accountable for what dad does...and you be accountable for what you do.

<question>

I really want to take my husband away for the weekend as a birthday treat....only problem is we would have to bring my 4 yr old and 6 month old as we dont have anyone to look after them for a whole weekend...I was thinking about bringing our 13 yr old neice too (who is very sensible and grown up for her age)....so she could babysit the kids one night for us to go out for a meal and meet up with some friends for drinks??...I heard it is illegal for under 16's to be left to babysit??...is that true??

<answer>



On a technical note, under 16 is illegal.



If something unfortunate happened, eg, freak storm, house struck by lightning, fire, gas leak, stuff like that, which are unpredictable and almost unpreventable, then not only would the 13-year old not be responsible for any injuries your children may suffer, if she herslf gets hurt, her parents or the police may press charges against you.



But in the end, you and your husband will need to make a judgment call on it.



</answer>

Ginger

<answer>



I think if it were me I would prefer to have her babysit at home whilst we went out for a meal.  My reason is that at home she has access to people she knows if she needs help, your house is more familiar to her and obviously your children.



I haven't heard that it is illegal for under-16s to babysit but if you leave your children in the care of someone under 16 then you are still legally responsible for them.  That means that if something were to happen to them you would be prosecuted for neglect.  If you have her babysit at home she will be able to call her Mum or one of your neighbours if she needs some extra help.



Lots of people heven't noticed that you are suggesting taking your neice with you and have her babysit for ONE EVENING whilst you go out for a meal.  I had a second thought that if you really want the trip away why not have the meal in the hotel restaurant - you will still be in the building and can pop back upstairs to the room to check everyone is OK.



</answer>



<answer from>



retrosto...
Member since: 19 March 2008
Total points: 77 (Level 1)

<question>



At what age do u put your?



kids in school my friend has a 1 1/2 yr old and she told me to start looking for schools my daughter is almost 1 1/2 she told me they put kids in school around 3 yrs old ?



also how meny hrs a day do they go to school for the first 5 yrs



</question>



<answer from>



princess...
Member since: 26 September 2008
Total points: 570 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If there is a specific place you want her to go you shouldput her name down now.  However, when she is about two the local council will send you a form to fill out with your choices.
Where I live in UK, children are able to go to nursery from the age of three this is usually only for about three hours a day unless you pay for them to go to a private nursery and then start real school aged four.  The school day usually starts at 9 and finishes between three and half past.



Hope this helps



</answer>



<answer from>



desmeran
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 1901 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Daycare is available for kids whose parents need or want it even from infancy.



In the U.S., preschool generally starts at age 3 or 4 and kindergarten starts at age 5.  In some places where good preschools are in high demand, it's wise to look into preschools a good year (and in some cases more than that) before your child would enroll.



Number of hours vary wildly by preschool.  They run the gamut from full-day, 5-day-a-week preschools to half-day, twice-a-week programs, with lots of options in between.



</answer>



<answer from>



Insanity...
Member since: 11 July 2008
Total points: 502 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yeah, generally kids start school at 5 years old. it is probably a good idea to start looking for schools now so that you have time to find a good one. lol.



</answer>



<answer from>



mom2prec...
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 461 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Preschool is optional.
If you so choose to send your kids to preschool for some early learning and socialization then they can usually start at 3, or you could choose to send them at 4.



Typically, depending on the preschool or early learning center they may just be early socialization skills that your child will be learning, which is great for them! Some schools, teach some letters and numbers, writing their name, and many do more than that. You just have to research what you are looking for when the time comes.



I personally started looking about 6 months beforehand.



Grade school typically starts when your child is 5 or turning 5 by a certain date in that calendar school.



What the date is will be determined by the state in which you live.



The time in which they are school also depends on your district.
For example my kids start at 7:55 and go to 3:15, my friends start at 8:30 and go until 3:40.



For kindergarten (1st year) they may have either a half day or a full day, depending on what your chosen school offers.



I'd say you have a little while to think about it all ;)



</answer>



<answer from>



Naanie
Member since: 19 March 2007
Total points: 638 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Here is Western Australia kids can start school at 4. They MUST turn 4 by June 30 of the year starting Kindy. If you have a July child they will have to wait a year longer. Some schools do offer 3 year old kindy which is suited for the kids born after July.



The first 2 terms Kindy has 4 half days. From 08.30 - 11.15 or from 12.15 - 3pm (2 morning and 2 afternoons). Then from 3rd term they go 2 full days.



Pre-Primary onwards is 5 full days from approx. 08.45 - 3pm



But it all depends on the school and state.



Source(s):



own experience



</answer>



<answer from>



sEXy giRL
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 210 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



5 years old is best...cz maybe then they could manage theirselves as well they could

<answer from>



RanaBana...
Member since: 08 March 2007
Total points: 15708 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Hobbies & Crafts



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



Where I live (Quebec) kids must turn 5 by October 1 to be enrolled in Kindergarten.  If you want your child registered younger than that they have to go through an evaluation and meet certain requirements.  Then they will repeat Kindergarten until they are "of age" because they must turn 6 by Oct 1 in order to advance to grade 1.  Kindergarten is a regular school day (8:30am - 3pm), 5 days a week.  They also go on the same buses as not only the grade 6 students at the same school, but since we're in a rural area the high school students up to grade 11 -- when they graduate) are on the same bus as well.



Some provinces have Jr K and Sr K.  They are usually half days, every day.  Kindergarten students have their own bus.



In Quebec, there is a pre-K program that is not mandatory, it's half a day, 5 days a week or every second day depending on the school board.  You have to pay for it, but children can start at 3 years old as long as they're out of diapers and buses are not available.



Children and babies can be in daycare starting at any age, depending on the facility.  Some of them are very structured, like a school, but it's a daycare.  Calling them schools, to me, is wishing your kids will grow up faster than nature will age them...and they grow up too fast to begin with.



So as you can see, it all varies greatly by where you live.  Which you don't mention.



</answer>



<answer from>



cathrl69
Member since: 10 July 2007
Total points: 18693 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Are you in the UK?



If so there's a date by which you have to apply, if I remember right it's in the autumn before your child would start school, so she'd be three and a bit. It's illegal for state schools to favour kids who are put on the list early, all kids who are registered by this date are treated equally.



No, kids don't go to school at 3. They generally go the September after they are 4, so some kids will be just 4 and some will be nearly 5 - and the younger ones will often go for half a day until they are 5 or nearly 5. But you might want to look around for a playgroup for her, many kids start playgroup at 2 1/2.



</answer>

furfur

<question>



New Yorkers and car seats???



I do not live in NY city. My question is, if so many of you rely upon public transportation such as cabs and the subway, how do you transport your children? Do you drag around a car seat or are there ones available for you to use on the public transportation? Or is this just a misconception and you all have your own cars?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't live in NYC but we visit there sometimes with our kids.  On the subway or bus, you wouldn't bring a carseat.  In a cab, we, at least, would bring the carseat.  It's easy for infants if they have those carriers that are both carseats and things that snap into the strollers.



</answer>

<answer>



At 24 weeks I still wore my regular size jeans completely buttoned up with all 4 of my kids. Only my second baby was little (6lbs. 5oz.) 2 of them were almost 10 lbs. (9-12 and 9-13) and my last baby was 10-5...your daughter just carries deep in her pelvis...at some point her uterus will rise up high enough for the top of the uterus (fundus) to fall forward and she will go from not showing much at all to showing ALOT...after all the baby is only 8-9 oz in weight and 6" long right now...it is not unusual for your daughter NOT to show at this point, especially with a First baby...she will.

ER RN/Mother of 3

<answer>



It's awesome!



My hubby and I always talked about raising a large family.

Anyhow, for me, raising healthy, happy, loving and well adjusted kids is one of the most rewarding things.



You truly get back what you put in and the love we fell is amazing.



It's a lot of work for sure, but so worth it.
My kids are all 7 and under right now and they are so close. It's a great thing to watch the relationships build between them and watch the bonds that they have.
Now that I have a couple in school, I see that the younger ones miss them when they are gone.



For our family personally, it is also important to have some one on one time with each of the kids on a regular basis too. We go out for mommy time and daddy time and have one on one, hot chocolate date or the bookstore, or shopping, you get the idea.



Good luck!

<answer from>



Jennifer L
Member since: 22 October 2006
Total points: 12787 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would tell my 19 year old son and his 17 year old girlfriend that it's time to sit down and have a long talk. I would insist upon a sit-down, with adults.  If there is a compelling reason that the girl's mother should not be told of this, I would want to know why.  I would want to be absolutely sure that this girl was not being pressured or coerced into an abortion and that she understands that there are other options.



Mostly, I'd want to make sure that they understood they were not alone in this and that I would be able and willing to offer support.



ETA: I don't like the no-consent laws for minors having abortions.  Take the controversy out of it, abortion is a surgical procedure with the same risks as any other surgical procedure.  How can the parents of this girl be aware of possible post-surgical complications, possibly life threatening complications, if they don't know there was a surgical procedure performed in the first place?



</answer>



<answer from>



Jaclyn S
Member since: 04 September 2008
Total points: 231 (Level 1)

I don't know how you personally feel about the situation but i would tell your son that he's an adult now and he needs to step up! Good luck!



I'd also like to add that i dont know what state you are in but in the state of TX a minor has to have there parent there to sign for the abortion. So, she might have to end up telling them herself.



</answer>

Any idea's? Please help!

<answer from>



Dennie
Member since: 03 June 2008
Total points: 336 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Joshua,



You should let your parents know about this.  You are depriving yourself of sleep and help.  Your parents love you and want you to be healthy and happy.  In the mean time, do not drink caffeine. Caffeine causes your kidneys to expel most of the fluid that passes through them, causing you to have to go to the bathroom more often. Do not drink anything at all a couple of hours before bedtime. Please talk to your parents.



</answer>

RanaBana...
Member since: 08 March 2007
Total points: 15708 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Hobbies & Crafts



Parenting



</answer from>



<answer>



Talk to your kids and make sure they know about good touches and bad touches, and ones that make them feel uncomfortable.  Let everyone in your family know you're doing this, but not because you suspect something might be going on...because it's a conversation every parent should have with their children.



People who know your kids are educated on the subject are less likely to molest them.  Having the talk with your kids opens the lines of communication and will make them more comfortable going to you should something ever happen (God forbid).



You don't have just your brother to be concerned about.  It's not being paranoid, it's being prepared.  Crap happens like this all the time, from people you would least expect.



Source(s):



Personal experience



</answer>

<answer>



hes probably only tickling them there because he can see thats where it tickles the most....he makes fun of your son to upset him then takes him to his room to play games probably as a way of saying sorry... this could all be very innocent as you have said he is very immature for his age....



however..... if your gut instinct is telling you otherwise then you must act on it in the only way you can .. and that is to very carefully chat with your children about what is exceptable and what is not when adults.. regardless of whether they are family or not.. touch them... talk to them or ask them to do things...



when i was 9 a family friend started playing cards with me and my sister when we were at his house and my mom thought nothing of it..he was very good with kids and she would check on us all the time....he new this and bided his time.... gained her trust.... but slowly and over a period of time those games of snap turned into strip snap.. and whenever we lost we had to take an item of clothing off.. he did the same so as far as we were concerned it was a game... it wasnt till my mom came in and saw me and my sister in just our knickers and him in his pants that we reolised it was wrong... he never touched us tho... but who knows if my mom hadnt came back early what could have happened.. it took him a month or two to develop the game and im sure he would have waited another month or two to go to the next level.... people like that dont rush in... they manipulate.. gain trust and only when they are certain they have the innocents in a position where they wont say anything do they do something...



i wouldnt advise mentioning this to your brother as he will become angry with you and then you will never no... the key here is to be vigilant and instill in your children what is not exceptable.. and that if anyone ...anyone at all regardless of who they are .. does or says or asks anything of them that requires anything other than normal play that they should tell you straight away....



your youngest is only 4... but even at that age they will understand...



my kids were told younger than that...and theyve never forgotton...



good luck ...



</answer>

treedle

<answer>



I had very bad feelings about this when I read "he constantly tickles my children on there high inner thigh" because when I was around 9 that was exactly what happened to me.  I was molested by my great grandfather who lived so far away we rarely got to see him.  I was sitting in the living room alone with him watching TV and that is exactly how it started.  My mom had looked in on us and all she saw was me giggling  when it first started. He was very old and I wasn't sure  what was happening at first....but soon his fingers were places they shouldn't have been.  I finally squirmed away from him and ran to mom, but I never said a word until a few years later. I wasn't sure about what had happened and felt very uncomfortable and confused.  I also was afraid of saying a bad thing about my Great Grandpa.



It came out in the family a few years later, that some of the grandkids who lived near him were much more seriously molested. There was a huge scandal as it unfolded and more and more children had been effected on various levels.  I was young enough that I really wasn't sure what it meant or if he had just " accidentally" touched me  wrong .



Some instinct sparked  your concerns here ... so I would certainly be on the alert.  I would make a rule that your son was not allowed up in the room alone with him. Maybe ask him if the " tickling " makes him feel uncomfortable? Hopefully everything is fine but the similarities worry me here and it is much better to be safe than sorry.



On a side note:  I have one friend who was molested by her father years ago and it too started with tickling.  Tickling is such a fun happy  innocent seeming thing but apparently it can often be used as a gateway for this type of thing.



</answer>

28weeks* *#3* *It's a GIRL*
Member since: 21 February 2008
Total points: 17791 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Parenting



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



If you do sign, then MAKE SURE you take full use of them paying for schooling! To ensure that you have a good job after you are finished! Too many of the people don't take use of that, and then get stuck in low paying jobs post military. To my knowledge they will allow you to go to school for anything you want at little to no cost!



Another tip I have heard from people that we knew that went in...list your deployment preferences in the order you DON'T want to go!



Most times if you put your least preferred place last, that's where they send you for some reason. (don't know how true that actually is, but it's what we've been told.)



Make sure that the babies mom has a good support system for when you'd be away, or live on base together.



My best friends husband signed on with the Air Force last year, and only got a $1500 sign on....so if your only doing it for the money...don't let the recruiters b/s you saying you'll get a $20k sign on. If it isn't in writing, don't believe it.



I can't really think of much else right off the top of my head. It's your choice. Just know that you will likely be sent over to Afghanistan, because it seems like the troops are going to be there for quite a few more years.



</answer>

<question>



New Yorkers and car seats???



I do not live in NY city. My question is, if so many of you rely upon public transportation such as cabs and the subway, how do you transport your children? Do you drag around a car seat or are there ones available for you to use on the public transportation? Or is this just a misconception and you all have your own cars?



</question>



<answer from>



desmeran
Member since: 27 May 2008
Total points: 1905 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't live in NYC but we visit there sometimes with our kids (and we sometimes take public transportation with the kids in our own area, as well).  On the subway or bus, you wouldn't bring a carseat.  In a cab, we, at least, would bring the carseat.  It's easy for infants if they have those carriers that are both carseats and things that snap into the strollers.



</answer>



<answer from>



Vpot
Member since: 10 April 2008
Total points: 3255 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't live in NYC, but I do rely on public transit. I tend to shy away from cabs if I don't have the car seat with me, but on the bus or subway my daughter sits in her stroller.



In a cab I would definitely bring a car seat.



</answer>

<question>



What should I do about the welfare of my children?



I have separated from my children's father for now 4 1/2 years. We have no parenting order or custody order in place. He has the children every second weekend and a couple of weeks in the christmas holidays. He smokes quite a bit of pot and he has a bad temper, and I try to avoid heavy arguments as much as I can as it makes me quite anxious. My daughter is now 10 and she is starting to click on what he is doing? He now wants to have access to the kids a few nights a week extra, but personally I don't want him to as it does disrupt the girls schooling and other commitments we have. Im also worried about the welfare of my second daughter as she was diagnosed with mild anxiety and I have gone to the ends of the earth to help her through this. Their father doesn't know about this, as he doesn't believe their is anything wrong with her, and has never really supported me.



I want to know what are my rights as a parent to protect the well being of my children? Who would be the best people to talk to regarding this matter?
If anyone could help me, it would be appreciated...



</question>

Member since: 22 October 2007
Total points: 6234 (Level 5)

<answer>



You need to get a custody order in place.  Without one then either parent has just as much of a right as the other parent as far as seeing the kids and spending time with the kids.

Drug use will probably come up so be prepared to open up that can of worms... but it's for the safety and well being of your children.

<question>



My 5 year old wets every night?



I have a five year old son that has to wear pull ups every night because he wets the bed.I don't know what to do,I don't want to keep pressuring him about it.I have been to my doctor and she just said that it's common in boy's his age and that there's nothing to worry about,but my partner and I think different.
If anyone has any advice I would love to hear it.



</question>



<answer from>



scoutma5...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 2031 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes it is more common in boys. Assuming that you are restricting his fluids after say 6pm, have you also tried taking him to the bathroom about midnight or whenever you go to bed? He will hardly wake up at all and should be dry the rest of the night.



</answer>



<answer from>



Emily
Member since: 14 February 2006
Total points: 2243 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



my sister used to wet her bed until about age 12.  She just slept so soundly her body never woke up to pee.  It wasn't every night, but if she had a late night snack (including drink) it always happened.  Best advice is what others said, restrict the drinks after dinner and maybe wake him up mid-night.  But seriously, 5 years old is still really young.  He should grow out of it.



</answer>



<answer from>



oar1963
Member since: 31 May 2008
Total points: 1510 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



my doctors said not to worry until age 6.. for a girl.  right.. sure.. you don't worry cause i've enough for both of us..



they had me use a jar.. with a rubber band.  have him pee in the jar.. mark it with the band.  during the day..have him practice holding in his pee a bit longer than normal.  after a week.. repeat the jar.. mark the difference in how much he can hold.. this proves to him that he can do it.



sometimes.. remember.. this is an emotional thing.. not a physical.  maybe you an think of talking to the school and see about counseling.. there might be something going on that they can find out that no way on earth he would tell you.. many things can make him that emotional.  he's young and can't process things well.. he's no experience to draw off of, and may be shy to ask for assistance.



don't worry too much.. but find ways to work it.. get the help you need.  maybe going to a urologist or pediatrician instead of a pcp for the entire family can help, if that is the doc you are talking to...



</answer>



<answer from>



rachel_relaxed mum
Member since: 19 March 2006
Total points: 28387 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>

<answer>



Teenager here!



1. I'm 14 turning 15 soon
2. Not old enough for a job, but a babysit and petsit some weekends.
3. Not pocket money, allowance. For actually doing chores, my homework, and going to school.
4. A parent is expected to love, feed, and house their child, and then have them get an education in some way. My mother buys meals, but I buy recreational stuff, as well as sugary treats and magazines and such.
5. As of right now, any and all of my allowance goes to getting my dog spayed, which I guess could be selfless in that way. I also usually purchase paper products and milk, which we both use.



You're welcome.



</answer>

PEACHES & CREAM

</answer from>



<answer>



This behavior is perfectly normal at his age.  My son is 16 months old & he's starting to hit now.  Just tell him no whenever he hits and he'll gradually pick up on it and stop.



What you can do



•  Establish rules, but keep them simple and limit yourself to a few — a toddler isn't capable of keeping track of more than a few basic expectations. Make your enforcement of household rules consistent.



•  Maintain a sense of humor. Remember that your toddler is a work in progress and you can't expect him to always act the way you want him to.



•  Spanking does not teach children anything but fear, and that aggression is a way to solve problems.



•  You must find ways of setting limits (and use your words) to assure him that even when he is doing something you don't want him to do you still love and accept him. You can kindly and firmly stop him from hurting himself or someone else by saying, "No, I can't let you do that," and remove him physically from the area, and then reassure him that you love him.



</answer>

<answer>



Hi, I am so shocked about some of these answers.  Any child no matter what age goes through a mourning process when someone that has always been around is all of a sudden not there anymore.  I agree that your 19 month old is doing age appropriate stuff but don't neglect the issue about Dad not being around anymore.  I would do Play Therapy with him.  Make two houses out of boxes and decorate them inside.  Explain to him through play that daddy lives in that house and mommy lives in this house.  Point out specific stuff that features in your different houses.  Example : Daddy's got a dog, Mommy's got a swing.  Do it once and leave it for a few days.  He might even ask you to play with the houses.  Good Luck!



Source(s):



Teacher and mom



</answer>

<question from>



She Didn't Choose This Role

<question>



What's your opinion on the whole Santa Claus deal?



I think it's kind of mean.  I mean kids get all excited year after year for Christmas Eve because that's when Santa delivers presents and sooner or later someone breaks the truth to them and it's like "oh".  I found out in 4th grade.  I asked my Mom if Santa was real and she was like "what do you think?".  Then she said that it's his spirit that we're celebrating and yeah.  I felt kind of foolish and let down.  I don't think I'm going to "lie" to my kids about the whole thing.  What's your opinion on it though?  Thanksss!!!

<question from>



aliciali...

</question from>



<question>



Do you expect your toddlers to have temper tantrums?



Both at home and publically?  Do you think you can raise children in such a way that they never have temper tantrums?



</question>



<answer from>



shanmw22
Member since: 21 March 2007
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I think there is no way around it. I think it is a normal part of growing up.



</answer>



<answer from>



erica88
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 262 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



No, I think it's part of them getting older and testing boundries. It's called the terrible twos! My parents were strict, and me and my brothers all respected our parents, and did as we were told. But each one of us went through the temper tantrum stage. I remember my youngest brother... phew. Haha. Some kids might not - it depends on their personality too. But I'd say the majority of kids definitely have them.



You need to ignore them generally. If you hiss and tell them to be quiet, they'll just get worse. Often walking away shocks them in shutting up - but be prepared! After doing this a few times they'll clue onto the fact that you will come back! Teach him/her that it's no acceptable, but they'll just grow out of it. If they're attacking and biting, you'll want to stop that. But the screams, red face and throwing themselves on the floor in the middle of your weekly shop/coffee with friends is pretty standard.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



Stephanie M
Member since: 22 March 2007
Total points: 4820 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's a psychological part of their development.  There isn't really any way around it.  Some kids are more dramatic and the tantrums are worse but it still happens to some extent.



</answer>



<answer from>



sparrow_...
Member since: 25 August 2008
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Haven't you ever seen an adult throw a temper tantrum?  It's an emotional response to stimulus, and it's more or less unavoidable in all ages.



</answer>



<answer from>



magician...
Member since: 29 December 2007
Total points: 753 (Level 2)

It depends on the child, My daughter NEVER I repeat NEVER had a tantrum. She is now 7 and still has not done this, not at home and most deffinantly not outside of the home.

<question>



What time does your toddler go to bed?



mine goes to bed really late no matter how early he wakes bc his dad works late hours.. :o( what do i do??



</question>



<answer from>



cigaro19
Member since: 03 July 2006
Total points: 4531 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Well if you are happy with him stayin up late then thats fine.



But it sounds like you have a problem so the only thing to do is have a bedtime routine, bath, story and bed, and be consistent with it. A normal bedtime would be around 7.30 - 8pm. I understand he doesnt get to see his Daddy very much but I'm sure he has days off and you need your evening times to relax!



</answer>



<answer from>



Jacob's Beloved
Member since: 23 October 2008
Total points: 133 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your toddler will sleep better and longer if he goes to bed earlier. If his dad wants to spend more time with his son, they should do it in the morning rather than at night. This is more about the health of your child. Read The No-Cry Sleep Solution.



</answer>



<answer from>



Beth
Member since: 17 October 2008
Total points: 518 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



My husband works late hours too so until they started school this year their actual bedtime was 1-2am and then they slept until like noon...it worked for us because I stayed home with them, they still got the same amount of sleep as anyone else just on diff hours that worked for our family so they could have dinner with daddy everynight and spend time with him.  Now that the oldest started kindergarten and middle started preschool this year they go to bed by 9pm an are up around 8-9am (afternoon prek and kindergarten) butwe did it by moving bedtime up by about 30min everynight to get them used to it



Beth
www.modern-mommies.com

skylarbr...

<answer>



My husband works nights, so my 2 yr old and i try to stay on his schedule to spend time with him, i am a stay at home mom so the being up late doesn't affect me, but my daughter goes to bed around 11pm, and we get up at 10am, have lunch and all with my hubby, He has to nap so we nap with him from 12 or 1 in the afternoon, and then she sleeps til 4 in the afternoon, we do this this way for now, but when she starts preschool i'll have to have her in bed by at least 8pm. But of coarse alot of people will probably tell you a child being up late isn't good, but with my experience as long as they're sleeping good hrs. at night and have a good nap, i think they're fine, i mean some of us have to do what we have to in order for our kids to see their dads that work weird hrs!



Source(s):



personal experience

<answer>



If you're sure it's not a diet issue, you could try talking to a chiropractor. If her lower back is out of kilter, the nerves to her bowels might be squashed, in which case nothing will work properly. Only 10% of a nerve has pain receptors, so it's possible to be out of alignment and not feel it.
