<question from>



KathyJan...
Member since: 17 June 2008
Total points: 136 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Looking for advice, when is the right time?



My boyfriend and I are in college right now. He is in the Pre-med program and I am studying to become a nurse. we have been dating for almost 3 years, and know that we are getting married and spending our lives together.
The thing of it is, we are having such a hard time deciding what to do as far as our future. yes, we know we have time. we have no intentions of rushing into anything. But it is always nice to have an idea, and we have none.
I want to stay home after I have children. And he agrees. But i want to  work a couple of years to pay off student loans and help build up our financial status.
He will also be in med school for quite a while, he won't be an official doctor until he is around 32. and I want to have 2 or 3 kids that are pretty spread out in age. His grandparents had his mom when they were in medschool and that worked for them, and they are really pressuring us to have children, as they feel they are getting old and want great grand children.



My question is, When do all of you think we should start trying? I know it is a personal matter and in the end it is up to my boyfriend and I and our families, I just want some different opinions. Did anyone experience anything like this? I want children more then anything  I don't know how long I can wait.



</question>



<additional details>



**Also- There are certain health issues I have that I would need to clear up hopefully as early as 2 years before I even start trying, which is another reason I feel the need to know.
I just can't stop dreaming of the day I will have children, how can I make this feeling go away and find patience until the time is right?
I am an aunt to the 3 most adorable children in the world and that surely doesn't help!



I am fully aware that being an aunt is nothing like being a mother. But I feel that being a mother is my calling, it is something I have dreamed of all my life. I know we need money, but I never said it would be easy.



Having all the money in the world stillwouldnt make parenting easy, and I know we need money before we have our kids.



I suppose I shouldn't have asked this quesiton on here as none of you know me or my boyfriend or our circumstances personally.



Bottom line, I do not want patronizing answers. Just helpful and concerning. I am not an idiot that is trying to jump into pregnancy. Just wondering with my future HUSBAND so tied up in med school (though I WILL be working as a nurse while he is in med shcool) when the best time would be.



zee-lee I wasn't referring to you...  :]



</additional details>



<answer from>



ZeeLee
Member since: 28 August 2007
Total points: 12456 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Pregnancy



Trying to Conceive



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Firstly, do not feel rushed into having kids because of your family. That is a bad reason to have kids.



If you've got health issues you need to deal with, deal with them now, so that in two years time, you will be physically ready to have kids. This will also give you time to finish your degree, and possibly work for a bit. And then you can revisit the situation then.



If you know you want kids, then get your health in order ASAP so that when you're really ready, you can just go for it!! :D I wish i had been able to lose a bit more weight before i got pregnant, as well as get a little fitter.



Edit: Dude, you're being a bit harsh on me here!! I wasn't being patronizing... or anything. I think my answer was good. Get your health under control, get more college under your belt and see if you're ready when your body is ready.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks! that really is good advice, just get in shape and when my body is ready I wont be so worried and I can just 'do it' when it feels right! I do need to get more in shape too! :[



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



ladyren
Member since: 02 May 2006
Total points: 16423 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Kids aren't adorable when you can't afford them.  It's rather like living in a house you really can't afford.  The house is wonderful, but the responsibilities of it make it way less fun that you thought it would be.  And after awhile you wonder, "Why didn't we wait to buy this????"



Pay off your loans, get your finances in order, get your degree, and then follow the four rules my mom hammered into me beginning at age ll.



1. The most important decision you will ever make is who you marry. Choose with your head as well as your heart.
2. Have no children until your bond is strong, and have no more than you yourself can support. You may just have to
3. At any and all costs finish your education to qualify for those high paying jobs. It is likely that you will work sometime during your marriage, probably for decades…. Get paid for it. And remember, your kids and your education are forever…. Husbands, lovers and promises are not!!
4. Have a stash of cash no one knows about even if you are sure you will never need it. You absolutely will, and the more the better.



And being an aunt is far different than the 24/7 of parenthood,  hon, waaayyyy different.  Children change your relationship forever.  Get some counseling before you jump in.  You want to be the best parents on the planet, and it won't be that way if you think is has no problems......



Truly there is nothing more beautiful than two mature, educated, prepared adults awaiting their child.  And surely nothing closer to hell on this planet that a child plopped into your cozy relationship and you had no idea how  crowded three really were.



You are in lala land if you think parenting is all a bed of flowers.



Ignore the 13 year olds who write on here hon.... Get educated, and get prepared, so you can enjoy being a parent.



Source(s):



dad and husband both mds.



</answer>



<answer from>



Bella &lt;3
Member since: 30 September 2008
Total points: 290 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



ok well firstly u definitely shudnt rush into anything! Listen to ure heart and it will tell u wen the right time comes. Secondly, ull have to have a talk with ure spouse and decide together how to work it out. Also to ensure a secure and comfortable future for your children perhaps you should work a little at first in order to be financially able to support them when they come around. Also talk to your family perhaps mother or father who have more experience and ask for their opinions! Then look deep within ureself and consider the pros and cons of having them sooner or later. Think about the things u would be missing and besides since u r young u have plenty of time. I suggest, since parenting is SUCH a big responisibility, to take some more time to gain more experiences perhaps with ure neices and finish ure education or u mite be regreting not having finished it later on when u need to find a job to support the family (desperate times call for desperate measures). Therefore i suggest be practical, realistic, wait awhile because nothing bad can come of that and hopefully later ure heart will tell u wen the time is right! Good lukk and best wishes ^^



</answer>



<answer from>



Lucy O
Member since: 22 October 2008
Total points: 123 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



listen, once you have kids you will be tied down to them and it will be hard to make it financially if your future husband is still in school.  I'm speaking from experience.  If you have health issues you should probably wait at least two years after you get married to start trying.  Make sure he can support you financially before you have them....you know i didnt plan either one of my kids and we are still working towards our bachelor's degrees living at my in-law's house it's a hard road.  Kids are great, but make sure you are financially stable.



Oh PS--I work as a caregiver only two days a week and make pretty good money and stay at home with the kids for the rest of the week.  Nurses can work schedules like that.  There is no reason why you can't work if  you can get child care for two days.  You spend most of your time with the kids and you get the break you need from them working a couple days



</answer>

<question>

I have been taking care of my 3 year old nephew and my 2 year old niece for the last 2 years,my sister sarah left them with me when my nephew was 13 mos and my niece was 6 days old,she decided she didn't want to be a mom.I have not heard from her at all since she left,no letters,no calls-nothing.I have been thinking and i decided that i might adopt them,i have gardianship of them but its not the same,my family is torn by this descision,my parents are against it,and my seven brother's and sisters have mixed feelings.None of them have heard from our sister and no one knows where she is or if she even alive.The kids call me mommy and my boyfriend daddy,there own dads are unknown.I love my sister but i deeply love my niece and nephew and i think that 2 years is a long enough time for my sister to come back for them if she wanted.My parents and siblings don't want to care for the kids-my parents for health reasons and my siblings have either kids of their own or just don't want the responsibility of them,although they love them.what would you do in this situation?should i wait or adopt them?

<additional details>

<answer from>



jenaeck
Member since: 18 July 2007
Total points: 129 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You are a wonderful sister. If your sister comes back and has her life together, then she should have a second chance with her children. But stay close by. I would also contact a lawyer or legal counsel just to find out what chances you have of getting them if she comes back and doesn't have her life together. You didn't mention any drugs or anything. Some people just are not ready to be parents and are afraid to mess their kids up. They need to come back when they are more mature.



You have been taking care of these babies as your own. You have been their mother and are and should be very protective of them. You should definitely adopt them if your sister hasn't come back for them by now.  You obviously love them and family is the best way. You can share the good stories with them about your sister, and make them feel like they will always be loved.



</answer>

<question from>



Exotic Green Eyes
Member since: 15 November 2007
Total points: 1271 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



know this is a silly question, but does the influenza virus stick to clothing?



I asked this and put it in a category that only got one answer, so I'm asking again... Just a concerned Mom... I got jeans from eBay in the mail today and it came from someone who had the flu and I forgot and touched them... I just don't want to bring it in our household. I have the clothing in the washer on sanitize. Please don't say I'm stupid for asking because some viruses can stick to clothing...  I stupidly tried them on too, I totally forgot she had told me she had the flu and that was the reason for the delay in shipment.  Somebody please ease my mind!!



</question>



<answer from>



Cola
Member since: 21 October 2008
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Always remember that no matter where you go there's viruses everywhere.  On your shopping cart, public toilets, door handles, someone sneezing next to you, but if you keep the simple rule of washing your hands throughout the day you will be safe most of the time.  Hope the jeans look cool!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



You are right, you are right, and by the way, the jeans really are very cool! =D  Thanks everyone else for answering, I'm not worried anymore.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



It's Sweet M, bitches
Member since: 08 October 2008
Total points: 532 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The flu is usually transmitted by saliva, mucus, or airborn bacteria.  Bacteria lasts longer on a hard surface than it does on clothing.  You should always wash clothes that you buy from people who previously owned them before you wear them, but if they were shipped to you, the bacteria on the jeans will not have survived the trip.  This isn't a stupid question, but you're overreacting a tad. Just wash the jeans and you'll be fine.



Source(s):



R/N



</answer>



<answer from>



Shaun and Nikolas's Mom.
Member since: 25 March 2008
Total points: 8072 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Actually, viruses can stick to clothing,objects,walls etc.



Not really sure if that means your pants are contaminated or not.It's a good idea to wash them anyways.You never know and don't worry you are NOT over reacting.



I think this world is so sick because people don't think about things like this nor do they wash their hands after using the bathroom or cover their mouth/nose when they sneeze.



You should be fine though.



</answer>

<answer>



Not a stupid question at all!  Yes it can be transfered on clothing if the clothing has been sneezed, coughed on or had any other bodily fluids on it.



HOWEVER, you are washing them and as long as you washed up right after touching them, you should have nothing to worry about.  You should be fine, even after you have tried them on.  Viruses generally last a couple of days on surfaces.  Just wash up and use hand sanitizer.  I'm sure you'll be ok.  What's to say that some one in Wal-Mart didn't have the flu and sneezed on the new shirt you just bought or tried on?  As long as you wash up and wash the clothes, you should be fine.



Source(s):



I'm a germaphob too :)



</answer>

<question from>



Mrs. P.
Member since: 23 July 2008
Total points: 150 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



What to do with a child who is starting to become out of control?



My daughter is almost 7 years old. She does really good in school, she is an excellent reader, I am so proud of her. But when she comes home from school, or just at home in general she likes to hit her younger brothers who are 2 years old and younger. She is lying about hitting them, until I raise my voice and then she finally admits what she did. And then sometimes she goes back and forth between telling stories that I don't know what the truth is. I do firmly believe in discipline. I have taken her toys/video games away.. that doesn't work. I have put her in "time out" in the corner.. that doesn't work. I have taken treats away (lollipops, ice cream etc.).. that doesn't work. She has been on punishment so many times its like its not enough anymore. I have taken away TV time, everything and nothing is working, she still wants to hit them, and tell lies. Today she pushed the baby down as he was crawling and made his lip bleed, and then 2 minutes later she hits her other brother in the stomach. Sometimes I feel like maybe she is jealous because she was "the baby" for a long time. But I just don't know what to do anymore, shes becoming out of control and I'm at my wits end!



</question>



<answer from>



jqp
Member since: 03 May 2008
Total points: 2136 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Sometimes when we think our kids are getting out fo control it´s us parents who need to change. Taking everything away from her won´t do much because she´ll always find something else to do. At this age kids are so creative that not watching TV will only give her ideas to do something else. If she can´t have ice cream she´ll replace it with some cookie. So I believe in your case, you should spend some time with her alone. For example, take her out once a week for two hours, just the two of you, whether it is for errands and stop by ice cream and talk with her, just be with her alone, away from the other babies. Try to share moments with her as the "older" ones in the house, give her chores only she can do because she´s the oldest. Make her feel important because she´s older than the other two and talk to her as to how important it is for you to have her as your oldest child.  She needs to feel important and appreciated by being the older one.
If she was alone for a long time, she´s definitely jelous and that´s why she´s acting like this. You can talk to her teacher and ask her to help in the sense of talking to her about taking care of her siblings and how important it is to be the older sister. Focus on her age to make her feel special and constantly comment on things that you wouldn´t be able to do without her, and how happy you are that she´s there to help you.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks I wish I could give you (and hnj52103always) thumbs up on your answer but Im level 1 for now so Yahoo wont let me. Anyway I think this will be a good approach at how I was trying to do things. I will definately take the advice of you and several others that said to spend more time with her.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



blsdca
Member since: 21 September 2006
Total points: 1138 (Level 3)

<question>



Child contact question?



Can anyone give me an idea of how much it costs in total and how much time it might take to secure a contact order? I am an unmarried father and I am at my wits end...



</question>



<answer from>



SO CRAZY!!
Member since: 11 October 2007
Total points: 2882 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I wasn't aware you had to pay for this.  Yu need to see a solicitor



</answer>



<answer from>



Paris Rose
Member since: 12 September 2008
Total points: 1155 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You do need a solicitor! You can usually get a free initial appointment and find out more there! It could take months, but they usually initiate contact sooner than that, it just takes that long to finalise the order!



You may have a problem if your name is not on the birth certificate and if she denies your paternity! This would mean paying for a DNA test before you could have any contact at all!



Can you not agree out of court?



Good Luck!



</answer>

<question>



Do you think this is wrong of me?



I have a 17 month old little girl who of course I think is one of the prettiest little girls around. I tell her about 6 times a day how pretty she is and how smart she is and I was wondering if you think this is over the top and I might be doing more damage than good. I know it's good to tell your child positive things but I just can't help myself telling her all the time that she's so smart and pretty but I was thinking the other day that maybe this will turn her into a snob or something when she is older coz she will think she is better than everyone else and I don't want her to think this. Do you think Im going over the top by telling her a few times a day or do you think Im doing good.



</question>

<answer>

Just be more aware of it as she grows and blossoms into a young adult.. Of course she'll be beautiful but, don't let it go to her head!

<answer from>



meow22
Member since: 22 August 2006
Total points: 3199 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



its all about balance - telling her she is pretty /clever when she has done something is fine, but not all the time for no reason, as soon it will mean nothing and you will have to do/say even more to have the same effect on her.



a friends sister was spoilt so much whilst growing up! told she was the best, the prettiest, always got what she wanted, screamed and shouted if she didn't get what she wanted. etc and they are having so much trouble now with her now shes 15 and wants to do everything and have everything, have her bf over, shes acting like a 25yr old but with the immaturity of a 15yr old!....



its good to encourage your child without a doubt, telling them they are good/ clever/ pretty when its earned and appropriate. but its all about balance like I said above, and its also good to tell them when there wrong and got things wrong, so they are aware its not all positive etc.



you don't want her to be deluded and go to school and fail at an exam or test and not be able to deal with these feelings of failure, one of my old school friends ended up having anorexia as she couldn't cope with the pressure of school/uni and not always being the a student.



Source(s):



personel experience.



</answer>
